For best success, read the recipe and recipe notes before beginning.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "sprinkle cake, birthday cake", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/03/easy-funfetti-confetti-cake-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/03/easy-funfetti-confetti-cake-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/03/easy-funfetti-confetti-cake-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/03/easy-funfetti-confetti-cake.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/easy-homemade-funfetti-cake/", "recipeIngredient": ["1 and 1/2 cups (177g) cake flour (spooned &amp; leveled)", "1 teaspoon baking powder", "1/4 teaspoon baking soda", "1/2 teaspoon salt", "6 Tablespoons (85g) unsalted butter, softened to room temperature", "3/4 cup (150g) granulated sugar", "2 large egg whites, at room temperature", "1/3 cup\u00a0(80g)\u00a0sour cream, at room temperature", "1 teaspoon pure vanilla extract", "1/3 cup (80ml) whole milk, at room temperature", "1/2 cup (70g) sprinkles", "3/4 cup (12 Tbsp; 170g)\u00a0unsalted butter, softened to room temperature", "3 cups (360g) confectioners\u2019 sugar", "3 Tablespoons (45ml) heavy cream, half-and-half,\u00a0or\u00a0whole milk, at room temperature", "1 teaspoon\u00a0pure vanilla extract", "salt, to taste", "optional: sprinkles for garnish"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat oven to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C). Grease a 9&#215;2-inch round cake pan, line with a parchment paper round, then grease the parchment paper. Parchment paper helps the cakes seamlessly release from the pans. (If it&#8217;s helpful, see this parchment paper rounds for cakes video &amp; post.)\u00a0", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/easy-homemade-funfetti-cake/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Whisk the cake flour, baking powder, baking soda, and salt together. Set aside.", "name": "Make the cake", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/easy-homemade-funfetti-cake/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Using a handheld or stand mixer fitted with a paddle or whisk attachment, beat the butter on high speed until smooth and creamy, about 1 minute. Add the sugar and beat on high speed until creamed together, about 2 minutes. (Here\u2019s a helpful tutorial if you need guidance on\u00a0how to cream butter and sugar.)\u00a0 Scrape down the sides and up the bottom of the bowl with a rubber spatula as needed. On high speed, beat in the egg whites until combined, then beat in the sour cream and vanilla extract. Scrape down the sides and up the bottom of the bowl as needed. Pour the dry ingredients into the wet ingredients. Turn the mixer to low speed and as the mixer runs, slowly pour in the milk. Beat on low speed just until all of the ingredients are combined. Do not over-mix. You may need to whisk it all by hand to make sure there are no lumps at the bottom of the bowl. The batter will be slightly thick. Gently fold in the sprinkles.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/easy-homemade-funfetti-cake/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Pour batter evenly into prepared cake pan.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/easy-homemade-funfetti-cake/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake for around 27-31 minutes or until the cake is baked through. After about 18 minutes, tent the cake with aluminum foil to prevent the top and edges from over-browning. To test the cake for doneness, insert a toothpick into the center of the cake. If it comes out clean, it\u2019s done.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/easy-homemade-funfetti-cake/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Allow cake to cool completely in the pan set on a wire rack. The cake must be completely cool before frosting.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/easy-homemade-funfetti-cake/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "With a handheld or stand mixer fitted with a paddle attachment, beat the butter on medium speed until creamy, about 1 minute. Add the confectioners\u2019 sugar, heavy cream, and vanilla extract. Beat on low speed for 30 seconds, then increase to medium-high speed and beat for 2 full minutes. Add up to 1/4 cup (30g) more confectioners\u2019 sugar if frosting is too thin or a splash of heavy cream if frosting is too thick. Add a pinch of salt if frosting is too sweet. (I add a small pinch.)", "name": "Make the buttercream", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/easy-homemade-funfetti-cake/#instruction-step-7"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Spread frosting all over the top. Spray donut pan with non-stick spray. Set aside.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/crumb-cake-donuts/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Mix the brown sugar, granulated sugar, and cinnamon together in a medium bowl. Stir in the melted butter using a fork, then add the flour. Mix and crumble with a fork. Set aside.", "name": "Make\u00a0the crumb topping:\u00a0", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/crumb-cake-donuts/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Whisk the flour, baking powder, baking soda, salt, cinnamon, and nutmeg together in a large bowl. Set aside. Whisk the melted butter, eggs, brown sugar, milk, yogurt, and vanilla together until completely combined. Pour the wet ingredients into the dry ingredients and mix until just combined. Do not overmix. The batter will be very thick.", "name": "Make the donuts", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/crumb-cake-donuts/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Spoon\u00a0the batter into the donut cavities\u2014I highly recommend using a large zipped-top bag for ease. Cut a corner off the bottom of the bag and pipe the batter into each donut cup, filling about halfway. Grab a handful of crumb topping and press down onto the batter of each donut. Pressing it snug into the batter helps prevent the crumb coating from falling off the donuts. (If you only have 1 donut pan, keep the remaining batter in the bowl at room temperature until you can bake the next batch.)", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/crumb-cake-donuts/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake for 10-11 minutes or until the edges and tops are lightly browned. Allow to cool for about two minutes then transfer to a wire rack set on a large piece of parchment paper. Bake the remaining donut batter and once baked, transfer to the wire rack. Dust the tops of each with a light coating of confectioners&#8217; sugar, if desired.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/crumb-cake-donuts/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Donuts are best served immediately. Review video tutorial and recipe notes below before beginning.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "garlic knots", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/garlic-knots-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/garlic-knots-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/garlic-knots-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/garlic-knots.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/garlic-knots-recipe/", "recipeIngredient": ["1\u00a0and 1/3 cups (320ml)\u00a0warm water (between 100\u2013110\u00b0F, 38\u201343\u00b0C)", "2 and 1/4 teaspoons (7g) Platinum Yeast from Red Star instant yeast\u00a0(1\u00a0standard packet)*", "1 Tablespoon\u00a0(13g)\u00a0granulated sugar", "3 Tablespoons (45ml) olive oil or (43g) melted butter", "1 teaspoon\u00a0salt", "1/2 teaspoon garlic powder*", "3 and 1/2 cups (about 450g) all-purpose flour\u00a0(spooned &amp; leveled), plus more for hands and work surface", "5 Tablespoons (71g) unsalted butter, melted", "3 garlic cloves, minced; or 1/2 teaspoon garlic powder", "1 teaspoon Italian seasoning*", "1/4 teaspoon salt", "optional after baking: 1/4 cup grated Parmesan cheese", "optional after baking: 2 Tablespoons chopped fresh parsley"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Whisk the warm water, yeast, and granulated sugar together in the bowl of your stand mixer fitted with a dough hook or paddle attachment. Cover and allow to rest for 5 minutes. *If you don\u2019t have a stand mixer, simply use a large mixing bowl and mix the dough with a wooden spoon or silicone spatula in the next step.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/garlic-knots-recipe/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Add the olive oil (or butter), salt, garlic powder, and half of the flour. Beat for 15 seconds, then add the remaining flour. Beat on low speed for 2 minutes.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/garlic-knots-recipe/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Keep the dough in the mixer (and switch to the dough hook if using the paddle) and beat for an additional 5 full minutes, or knead by hand on a lightly floured surface for 5 full minutes. (If you\u2019re new to bread-baking, my How to Knead Dough video tutorial can help here.) If the dough becomes too sticky during the kneading process, sprinkle 1 teaspoon of flour at a time on the dough or on the work surface/in the bowl to make a soft, slightly tacky dough. Do not add more flour than you need because you do not want a dry dough. After kneading, the dough should still feel a little soft. Poke it with your finger\u2014if it slowly bounces back, your dough is ready to rise. You can also do a \u201cwindowpane test\u201d to see if your dough has been kneaded long enough: tear off a small (roughly golfball-size) piece of dough and gently stretch it out until it\u2019s thin enough for light to pass through it. Hold it up to a window or light. Does light pass through the stretched dough without the dough tearing first? If so, your dough has been kneaded long enough and is ready to rise. If not, keep kneading until it passes the windowpane test.", "name": "Knead the dough:\u00a0", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/garlic-knots-recipe/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToSection", "name": "Rise", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Lightly grease a large bowl with oil or nonstick spray\u2014just use the same bowl you used for the dough. Place the dough in the bowl, turning it to coat all sides in the oil. Cover the bowl with aluminum foil, plastic wrap, or a clean kitchen towel. Allow the dough to rise at room temperature for 1\u20132 hours or until double in size. (Tip: For a warm environment on a particularly cold day, heat your oven to 150\u00b0F (66\u00b0C). Turn the oven off, place the dough inside, and keep the door slightly ajar. This will be a warm environment for your dough to rise. After about 30 minutes, close the oven door to trap the air inside with the rising dough. When it\u2019s doubled in size, remove from the oven.)", "name": "Rise", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/garlic-knots-recipe/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Use the video tutorial and step-by-step photos as your guide for this step. When the dough is ready, punch it down to release the air. Using floured hands on a lightly floured work surface, shape the dough into a 16&#215;5-inch (13x41cm) log. (5-inch width really isn&#8217;t as important as the 16-inch length here\u2014no need to be exact.) Using a very sharp knife, pizza cutter, or bench scraper, slice into 16 1-inch strips. Roll each strip into 8-inch ropes. Tie each into a knot. You can tuck the 2 ends of the knots underneath or leave them out\u2014that&#8217;s up to you. Arrange the knots on 2 baking sheets lined with silicone baking mats or parchment paper.", "name": "Shape the dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/garlic-knots-recipe/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Lightly cover the shaped knots and let them rest for at least 30 minutes and up to 45 minutes. They will slightly puff up during this time, producing softer rolls.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/garlic-knots-recipe/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Towards the end of the rise time, preheat oven to 400\u00b0F (204\u00b0).", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/garlic-knots-recipe/#instruction-step-7"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "\u00a0Stir the melted butter, garlic, Italian seasoning, and salt together. Brush on the knots. Reserve some of the topping for when the knots come out of the oven.", "name": "Make the topping", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/garlic-knots-recipe/#instruction-step-8"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake for about 20\u201323 minutes or until golden brown on top. Remove from the oven and brush the warm knots with remaining garlic butter. Sprinkle with parmesan cheese and/or parsley, if using.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/garlic-knots-recipe/#instruction-step-9"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Serve plain or with marinara sauce for dipping.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/garlic-knots-recipe/#instruction-step-10"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cover and store leftover knots at room temperature for up to 2 days or in the refrigerator for up to 1 week. Beat in the egg whites on high speed until combined, about 2 minutes, then beat in the sour cream and vanilla extract. Scrape down the sides and up the bottom of the bowl as needed. With the mixer on low speed, add the dry ingredients just until combined. With the mixer still running on low, pour in the milk and mix just until combined. You may need to whisk it all by hand to make sure there are no lumps at the bottom of the bowl. Gently fold in the sprinkles. Add the butter. Using a pastry cutter or two forks, cut the butter into the mixture until it resembles coarse meal (pea-sized bits with a few larger bits of fat is OK). A pastry cutter makes this step very easy and quick. Drizzle the cold water in, 1 Tablespoon (15ml) at a time, and stir with a silicone spatula or wooden spoon after every Tablespoon (15ml) added. Do not add any more water than you need to. Stop adding water when the dough begins to form large clumps. I always use about 3/4 cup (180ml) water. Transfer the pie dough to a floured work surface. Using floured hands, fold the dough into itself until the flour is fully incorporated into the butter pieces. The dough should come together easily and should not feel overly sticky. Form dough into a ball. Divide dough in half. Flatten each half into 1-inch thick discs using your hands. Wrap each tightly in plastic wrap. Refrigerate for at least 2 hours (and up to 5 days) or freeze for up to 3 months. Thaw overnight in the fridge before using.", "name": "Make the pie crust", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/apple-slab-pie-maple-icing/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Mix all of the filling ingredients together in a large bowl.\u00a0Set aside.", "name": "Make the filling", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/apple-slab-pie-maple-icing/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat oven to 375\u00b0F (190\u00b0C).", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/apple-slab-pie-maple-icing/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Remove 1 disc of pie dough from the refrigerator.Keep the other in the refrigerator as you work. Carefully place the dough into a 10&#215;15-inch jelly roll pan; there will be overhang on the sides\u2014trim it to be about 1 inch. Sally\u2019s work has been featured on TODAY, Good Morning America, Taste of Home, People, and more.", "sameAs": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"]}, {"@type": "Question", "@id": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/peach-bundt-cake-with-brown-butter-icing/#faq-question-1723800789029", "position": 1, "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/peach-bundt-cake-with-brown-butter-icing/#faq-question-1723800789029", "name": "My Bundt cakes always stick to the pan; how do I get them to release cleanly?", "answerCount": 1, "acceptedAnswer": {"@type": "Answer", "text": "If you need a recommendation for a new Bundt pan, I highly recommend <a href=\"https://amzn.to/49FvJhO\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noreferrer noopener sponsored nofollow\">NordicWare Bundt pans</a>. I\u2019ve been using them for years\u2026 great quality, great price, and they come in so many beautiful shapes. (Not working with the brand, just a fan!) Even though these Bundt pans are nonstick, I always grease them just to be safe; the syrupy peach layers have a tendency to stick to the sides of the pan. I recommend a light dusting of flour over the greased interior to help the cake release cleanly, too. Finally, let the cake cool in the pan for exactly 1 hour and then invert onto a cooling rack or serving platter/cake stand. Trying to invert the cake too soon or after too long always makes it harder to get the cake to release; I find that 1 hour is the sweet spot for this cake.", "inLanguage": "en-US"}, "inLanguage": "en-US"}, {"@type": "Question", "@id": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/peach-bundt-cake-with-brown-butter-icing/#faq-question-1723800886202", "position": 2, "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/peach-bundt-cake-with-brown-butter-icing/#faq-question-1723800886202", "name": "Can I make this peach Bundt cake in a loaf pan?", "answerCount": 1, "acceptedAnswer": {"@type": "Answer", "text": "Absolutely, but I recommend halving the recipe for an 8.5x4.5-inch or 9x5-inch pan. The bake time is similar to this <a href=\"https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/peach-quick-bread/\">peach bread</a>; use a toothpick to test for doneness. For best success, however, just make the quick bread recipe and top with today's brown butter icing. Feel free to halve the icing. If you would rather use a springform pan, I recommend this <a href=\"https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/peach-cake/\">peach cake</a> instead.", "inLanguage": "en-US"}, "inLanguage": "en-US"}, {"@type": "Question", "@id": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/peach-bundt-cake-with-brown-butter-icing/#faq-question-1723800952200", "position": 3, "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/peach-bundt-cake-with-brown-butter-icing/#faq-question-1723800952200", "name": "What are the best peaches for this Bundt cake?", "answerCount": 1, "acceptedAnswer": {"@type": "Answer", "text": "You can use any variety of peaches\u2014yellow, white, or even doughnut peaches\u2014but you want slightly firm (not hard) peaches with no soft spots. Your best bet is to purchase or pick about 7 firm peaches, then let them sit in a paper bag for 1\u20132 days to ripen. Some may have soft spots after this time, so that is why I suggest buying a couple more than you actually need. Eat any overly soft peaches or use them in these <a href=\"https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/peach-streusel-muffins/\">peach muffins</a>.", "inLanguage": "en-US"}, "inLanguage": "en-US"}, {"@type": "Question", "@id": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/peach-bundt-cake-with-brown-butter-icing/#faq-question-1723800991795", "position": 4, "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/peach-bundt-cake-with-brown-butter-icing/#faq-question-1723800991795", "name": "Can I use frozen peaches?", "answerCount": 1, "acceptedAnswer": {"@type": "Answer", "text": "Fresh peaches are the best option for this peach Bundt cake, but you can use frozen if needed. You just don't want them to be too wet, so either keep them frozen, or, if using thawed peaches, be sure to blot them dry before tossing with the cinnamon-sugar and using them in the cake.", "inLanguage": "en-US"}, "inLanguage": "en-US"}, {"@context": "https://schema.org/", "@type": "Recipe", "name": "Peach Bundt Cake with Brown Butter Icing", "description": "Homemade peach Bundt cake is super moist and tender with pockets of cinnamon-soaked peaches throughout each slice. Finish it with a delicious brown butter icing that eventually sets on top.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "peach Bundt cake", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/07/peach-Bundt-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/07/peach-Bundt-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/07/peach-Bundt-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/07/peach-Bundt.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/peach-bundt-cake-with-brown-butter-icing/", "recipeIngredient": ["3 cups (375g) all-purpose flour (spooned &amp; leveled)", "2 and 1/2 teaspoons baking powder", "1/2 teaspoon baking soda", "1/2 teaspoon salt", "1 cup (240ml) vegetable oil (or canola oil)", "1 cup (200g) granulated sugar", "2/3 cup (133g) packed light brown sugar", "4 large eggs, at room temperature", "1/2 cup (120g) full-fat sour cream, at room temperature", "2 teaspoons pure vanilla extract", "2 and 1/2 cups (430\u2013440g) peeled and chopped peaches (about 5 peaches)", "2 Tablespoons granulated sugar", "1 teaspoon ground cinnamon", "6 Tablespoons\u00a0(85g)\u00a0unsalted butter", "1\u00a0and 1/2 cups (180g)\u00a0confectioners\u2019 sugar, sifted", "3 Tablespoons (45ml) whole milk", "1/4 teaspoon\u00a0pure vanilla extract", "pinch salt"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat the oven to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C). Grease and lightly flour a 10- to 12-cup Bundt pan (I like this one and this one).", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/peach-bundt-cake-with-brown-butter-icing/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Whisk the flour, baking powder, baking soda, and salt together in a large bowl. Set aside. Using a handheld or stand mixer fitted with a whisk or paddle attachment (or you can use a whisk) mix the oil, granulated sugar, brown sugar, eggs, sour cream, and vanilla together until combined. Pour the dry ingredients into the wet ingredients, and beat on medium-low speed or whisk until the batter is completely combined. Batter is thick, yet silky. You should have about 4 cups (1300g) of batter.", "name": "Make the cake batter", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/peach-bundt-cake-with-brown-butter-icing/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a medium bowl, gently stir the peaches, sugar, and cinnamon until the peaches are coated.", "name": "For the peaches", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/peach-bundt-cake-with-brown-butter-icing/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Pour and spread 1/3 of the cake batter evenly into the prepared Bundt pan. Arrange half of the peaches on top (including any juices), and try to keep them in the center of the batter and not touching the edges of the pan. Pour and spread another 1/3 of the cake batter evenly on top, followed by the rest of the peaches. Again, try to prevent the peaches from touching the edges of the pan. Finally, pour the remaining cake batter on top. Use a spatula or back of a spoon to smooth over any exposed peaches as best you can.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/peach-bundt-cake-with-brown-butter-icing/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake for 55\u201370 minutes or until a toothpick inserted into the cake comes out clean (with just a couple moist crumbs). This is a large, heavy cake so don&#8217;t be alarmed if it takes a little longer in your oven. As it&#8217;s baking, after 30 minutes, loosely cover with aluminum foil to prevent over-browning.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/peach-bundt-cake-with-brown-butter-icing/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Once done, place the cake on a cooling rack and allow to cool in the pan for 1 hour. Run a knife around the edges to loosen the cake from the pan, then invert the Bundt cake onto a cooling rack or serving dish and allow to cool completely.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/peach-bundt-cake-with-brown-butter-icing/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Slice the butter into pieces and place in a light-colored skillet. (Light colored helps you determine when the butter begins browning.) Melt the butter over medium heat, stirring occasionally. Once melted, the butter will begin to foam. Keep stirring occasionally. After 5\u20138 minutes, the butter will begin browning\u2014you&#8217;ll notice lightly browned specks forming at the bottom of the pan and it will have a nutty aroma. Once browned, remove from heat immediately and pour into a medium heatproof bowl or liquid measuring cup. Allow to slightly cool for 5\u201310 minutes. Whisk in the rest of the icing ingredients until smooth. Add more sifted confectioners&#8217; sugar for a thicker texture, if desired. Likewise, add more milk to thin out if needed. Taste and add another pinch of salt if desired.", "name": "Make the icing", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/peach-bundt-cake-with-brown-butter-icing/#instruction-step-7"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Immediately drizzle the icing over the cooled cake. Set aside.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/reeses-peanut-butter-white-chocolate-bark/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Place half (8 ounces/227g) of the chopped white chocolate and 1/2 teaspoon of oil in a medium microwave-safe bowl or liquid measuring cup. Melt in 20-second increments, stirring with a silicone spatula or spoon after each increment, until completely melted and smooth. White chocolate can overheat easily, so it&#8217;s important to do this in increments. Pour the melted white chocolate into the prepared pan and spread it evenly with an offset spatula to cover the bottom of the pan. Place the pan, uncovered, in the refrigerator to chill for 10\u201315 minutes, to soft-set the white chocolate.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/reeses-peanut-butter-white-chocolate-bark/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a medium bowl with a hand mixer or in the bowl of a stand mixer fitted with the paddle attachment, beat the peanut butter and butter until smooth and creamy, about 2 minutes. Scrape down the sides and up the bottom of the bowl as necessary. Add the confectioners&#8217; sugar, vanilla, and salt, and beat until combined, about 1 minute. Spoon dollops of the peanut butter mixture onto the bottom layer of white chocolate, and spread it evenly with an offset spatula as best you can. Place the pan back in the refrigerator while you melt the remaining white chocolate.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/reeses-peanut-butter-white-chocolate-bark/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Repeat step 2 to melt the remaining white chocolate and 1/2 teaspoon oil. (You can also leave it in the refrigerator for up to 1 day, but cover it loosely after an hour. If refrigerating it for more than 1 hour, you may notice the top white chocolate layer cracks when you&#8217;re cutting the bark into pieces. This is normal and expected, because the layer is quite cold.)", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/reeses-peanut-butter-white-chocolate-bark/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Lift the bark out of the pan by holding onto the edges of the parchment paper, and place it on a cutting board. Overall, the pumpkin flavor is faint but the spices are strong. Choose cream cheese icing or maple icing as the final finishing touch before serving. Review recipe notes and watch the video before starting.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "pumpkin spice roll cookies", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/09/pumpkin-spice-roll-cookies-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/09/pumpkin-spice-roll-cookies-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/09/pumpkin-spice-roll-cookies-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/09/pumpkin-spice-roll-cookies.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/pumpkin-spice-roll-cookies/", "recipeIngredient": ["3/4 cup (12 Tbsp; 170g) unsalted butter, softened to room temperature", "3/4 cup\u00a0(150g)\u00a0granulated sugar", "6 Tablespoons\u00a0(86g)\u00a0pumpkin puree (moisture blotted, see note)*", "1 and 1/2 teaspoons pure vanilla extract", "2\u00a0and 1/4 cups (281g)\u00a0all-purpose flour\u00a0(spooned &amp; leveled)", "1 and 3/4 teaspoons store-bought or homemade pumpkin pie spice", "1/2 teaspoon ground cinnamon", "1/2 teaspoon baking powder", "1/4 teaspoon salt", "3 Tablespoons (43g) unsalted butter, melted and slightly cooled", "2/3 cup (135g) packed light or dark brown sugar", "1 and 3/4 teaspoons store-bought or homemade pumpkin pie spice", "1 teaspoon ground cinnamon", "4 ounces (113g) full-fat brick cream cheese, softened to room temperature", "1 Tablespoon (14g) unsalted butter, softened to room temperature", "3/4 cup (90g) confectioners&#8217; sugar", "1/4 teaspoon pure vanilla extract", "optional: pinch of salt"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "First, make sure you have removed excess liquid from the pumpkin puree by blotting it as much as you can with a clean kitchen tea towel or paper towels. This dough will not turn out properly with the pumpkin&#8217;s excess moisture. After blotting excess liquid, you should have about 1/3 cup (75g) to use in the recipe. See recipe note.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/pumpkin-spice-roll-cookies/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a large bowl using a hand mixer or a stand mixer fitted with a paddle attachment, beat the butter and sugar together on high speed until completely smooth and creamy, about 3 minutes. (Here\u2019s a helpful tutorial if you need guidance on\u00a0how to cream butter and sugar.) Add the pumpkin and vanilla extract, and then beat on high speed until combined, about 1 minute. Scrape down the sides and up the bottom of the bowl and beat again as needed to combine. It&#8217;s ok if the mixture looks curdled. Add the flour, pumpkin pie spice, cinnamon, baking powder, and salt. Beat on low speed until combined and a thick dough forms.", "name": "Make the dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/pumpkin-spice-roll-cookies/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Divide the dough into 2 equal parts. If you want to be accurate and weigh the dough, each half should be around or a little more than 12 ounces each. On a floured work surface using floured hands, pat each into a small rectangle. Then, using a lightly floured rolling pin, roll each portion of dough out into a 10&#215;8 inch rectangle. It should be about 1/4&#8243; thick. As you&#8217;re rolling, use your hands to help keep the sides straight as you see me do in the video. Spread half of the melted butter onto each rectangle\u2014doesn&#8217;t need to be exactly half, just eyeball it. It will be a thick layer of butter. Mix the brown sugar, pumpkin pie spice, and cinnamon together then sprinkle evenly over each. Using the back of a spoon, pat the brown sugar and spices down into the butter to help it stick.", "name": "Shape and fill", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/pumpkin-spice-roll-cookies/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Working slowly using your fingertips, tightly roll up each rectangle into a 10-inch log. If the dough is cracking at all, use your fingers to smooth it out. (See troubleshooting above if needed.) Wrap the dough logs in plastic wrap, parchment paper, or aluminum foil. Chill the dough logs for at least 2 hours and up to 3 days in the refrigerator. (Or freeze for up to 3 months, see freezing instructions below.) The pictured cookie dough logs chilled in the refrigerator for 1 day.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/pumpkin-spice-roll-cookies/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat oven to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C). Line large baking sheets with parchment paper or silicone baking mats.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/pumpkin-spice-roll-cookies/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Remove dough logs from the refrigerator. Using a sharp knife, cut each into slices that are slightly less than 1/2 inch (between 1/4 and 1/2 inch is perfect). You&#8217;ll have around 24-26 cookies per log. Arrange sliced cookies onto baking sheets 1.5-2 inches apart. If the slices have lost their round shape, use your fingers to help mold them into perfect circles again. Not necessary of course, but you can see me do it in the video.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/pumpkin-spice-roll-cookies/#instruction-step-7"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake for 13-15 minutes or until very lightly browned around the bottoms. (As the cookies bake, you can make the icing in the next step.) Remove finished cookies from the oven, allow to cool on the baking sheet for 10 full minutes, and then transfer to a wire rack.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/pumpkin-spice-roll-cookies/#instruction-step-8"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a large bowl using a handheld or stand mixer fitted with a paddle or whisk attachment, beat the cream cheese on high speed until completely smooth and creamy, about 1 minute. Add the butter and beat until smooth and combined. Add the confectioners\u2019 sugar and vanilla extract, and then beat on medium speed until combined. Taste. To guarantee the best results, use sour cream, buttermilk, and extra ripe bananas\u2013these power ingredients make all the difference in this spiced cupcake recipe.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "banana cupcakes", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/09/banana-cupcake-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/09/banana-cupcake-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/09/banana-cupcake-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/09/banana-cupcake.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/banana-cupcakes-with-cinnamon-cream-cheese-frosting/", "recipeIngredient": ["2 cups (250g) all-purpose flour\u00a0(spooned &amp; leveled)", "1 teaspoon baking soda", "1/2 teaspoon baking powder", "1 teaspoon ground cinnamon", "3/4 teaspoon salt", "1/2 cup (8 Tbsp; 113g) unsalted butter, softened to room temperature", "1/2\u00a0cup (100g) packed light or dark brown sugar", "1/2 cup (100g) granulated sugar", "2 large eggs, at room temperature*", "1/4 cup (60g) sour cream or plain yogurt, at room temperature*", "2 teaspoons pure vanilla extract", "1 and 1/2 cups (345g) mashed bananas (about 4 medium or 3 large ripe bananas)", "1/2 cup (120ml) buttermilk, at room temperature*", "8 ounces (226g) full-fat brick cream cheese, softened to room temperature", "1/2 cup (8 Tbsp; 113g) unsalted butter, softened to room temperature", "3 cups (360g) confectioners&#8217; sugar, plus an extra 1/4 cup if needed", "1 teaspoon pure vanilla extract", "1/2 teaspoon ground cinnamon", "1/8 teaspoon salt", "optional: banana slices and/or crushed Nilla Wafer cookies"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat the oven to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C). Line a 12-cup muffin pan with cupcake liners. Line a second pan (or bake in batches) with 6 liners\u2014this recipe makes about 18 cupcakes. Set aside.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/banana-cupcakes-with-cinnamon-cream-cheese-frosting/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Whisk the flour, baking soda, baking powder, cinnamon, and salt together. Set aside.", "name": "Make\u00a0the cupcakes", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/banana-cupcakes-with-cinnamon-cream-cheese-frosting/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Using a handheld or stand mixer fitted with a paddle attachment, beat the butter, brown sugar, and granulated sugar on medium-high speed until creamed together, about 3 minutes. (Here\u2019s a helpful tutorial if you need guidance on how to cream butter and sugar.) Scrape down the sides and bottom of the bowl with a silicone spatula as needed. Add the eggs, sour cream/yogurt, and vanilla extract, then beat on medium-high speed until combined. Scrape down the sides and bottom of the bowl as needed. Beat in the mashed banana. (Buttermilk is in the next step.)", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/banana-cupcakes-with-cinnamon-cream-cheese-frosting/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "With the mixer on low speed, add the dry ingredients until just incorporated. With the mixer still running on low, slowly pour in the buttermilk until combined. Do not overmix. You may need to whisk it all by hand to make sure there are no dry flour pockets at the bottom of the bowl.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/banana-cupcakes-with-cinnamon-cream-cheese-frosting/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Pour/spoon the batter into the liners\u2014fill only 2/3 full to avoid spilling over the sides. Bake for 18\u201320 minutes, or until a toothpick inserted in the center comes out clean. For about 36 mini cupcakes, bake for about 11\u201313 minutes, same oven temperature.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/banana-cupcakes-with-cinnamon-cream-cheese-frosting/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cool the cupcakes in the pan set on a cooling rack for 20 minutes, then remove them from the pan and return to the rack to\u00a0cool completely before frosting.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/banana-cupcakes-with-cinnamon-cream-cheese-frosting/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a large bowl using a handheld or stand mixer fitted with a paddle or whisk attachment, beat the cream cheese and butter together on high speed until smooth and creamy. Add 3 cups (360g) confectioners&#8217; sugar, the vanilla, cinnamon, and salt. Beat on low speed for 30 seconds, then gradually increase the speed to high and beat for 2 minutes. If you want the frosting a little thicker, add the extra 1/4 cup of confectioners sugar (I usually add it).", "name": "Make\u00a0the frosting", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/banana-cupcakes-with-cinnamon-cream-cheese-frosting/#instruction-step-7"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "If desired, to help ensure the frosting holds piped shape, refrigerate the bowl of frosting for at least 20 minutes. Frost cooled cupcakes. For the pictured cupcakes, I used piping tip Ateco #826. I also like Ateco #808 piping tip for cream cheese frosting. Instead, you can skip the piping tips and use a knife or icing spatula to spread on the frosting. Garnish with banana slices and crushed Nilla Wafer cookies, if desired.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/banana-cupcakes-with-cinnamon-cream-cheese-frosting/#instruction-step-8"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cover leftover cupcakes tightly and store in the refrigerator for up to 3 days. Make pie dough the night before because it needs to chill in the refrigerator for at least 2 hours before rolling out and blind baking (next step).", "name": "Pie crust", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/coconut-cream-pie/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat oven to 375\u00b0F (190\u00b0C). Fully blind bake the pie crust. (Follow how to blind bake pie crust instructions through step 9. I skip the optional dough strip trick in step 4, though that trick guarantees thick pie crust edges. Crimp or flute the pie crust edges before baking.) \u00a0Cool pie crust completely. You can do this up to 3 days ahead of time. Cover cooled crust tightly and refrigerate until ready to fill.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/coconut-cream-pie/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Whisk the egg yolks and cornstarch together. Set aside. Whisk the coconut milk, half-and-half, granulated sugar, and salt together in a medium saucepan over medium heat. Whisking occasionally, bring to a boil. Boil for 2 minutes, then reduce temperature to medium-low heat. Once boiling, remove about 1/2 cup of the mixture and, in a slow and steady stream, whisk into the egg yolk and cornstarch mixture. Keep those egg yolks moving so they don\u2019t scramble. In a slow and steady stream, pour and whisk the egg yolk mixture into the pot.", "name": "Make the coconut filling", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/coconut-cream-pie/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "The pudding will immediately begin to bubble and thicken. freeze the 2nd half for later use)", "1 cup ricotta cheese, at room temperature", "2 large eggs, at room temperature", "3/4 cup shredded parmesan cheese (or other favorite cheese)", "2 teaspoons minced garlic", "1 Tablespoon favorite fresh herbs or 2 teaspoons dried herbs (I use a mix of thyme, rosemary, and parsley)", "1/2 teaspoon salt", "pinch black pepper", "1-2 cups thinly sliced vegetables such as sweet potatoes, zucchini, carrots, mushrooms, asparagus, brussels sprouts*", "topping:\u00a02 Tablespoons olive oil, coarse sea salt, more pepper + herbs"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Prepare my pie crust recipe or all butter pie crust through step 5.", "name": "The crust", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/savory-vegetable-cheese-tart/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "After the pie crust has chilled, preheat the oven to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C).", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/savory-vegetable-cheese-tart/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "\u00a0On a floured work surface, roll out one of the\u00a0discs\u00a0of chilled dough (you can freeze the 2nd for later use, see note). Turn the dough about a quarter turn after every few rolls until you have a circle 12 inches in diameter. Carefully place the dough into a\u00a09-inch tart pan.* Tuck it in with your fingers, making sure it is smooth. Fold the overhang edges back inward. See video above for a visual. Flute the pie crust edges. Chill for 20 minutes in the refrigerator or freezer. (Crust will shrink otherwise!) Line the chilled pie crust with parchment paper or aluminum foil. Fill with 2 sets of pie weights or dried beans. Bake for 15 minutes. Remove tart from the oven and carefully lift the parchment paper/aluminum foil (with the weights) out of the crust.", "name": "Roll out the chilled pie dough and blind bake", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/savory-vegetable-cheese-tart/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Using a handheld or stand mixer fitted with a whisk attachment, beat the ricotta, eggs, parmesan cheese, garlic, herbs, salt, and pepper together until completely combined. Pour into warm crust. Arrange vegetable slices on top. Brush the vegetables and edges of the crust with olive oil, then sprinkle with sea salt, pepper, or more fresh herbs.", "name": "The filling", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/savory-vegetable-cheese-tart/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake for 30 minutes or until the vegetables and crust are lightly browned and crisp. After the first 15 minutes of bake time, place a pie crust shield on top of the tart to\u00a0prevent the edges from browning too quickly. You can also tent a piece of aluminum foil over the whole tart if the top is browning too quickly.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/savory-vegetable-cheese-tart/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Slice and serve tart warm or at room temperature. I LOVED IT TOO!!!  I had a Pillsbury pie crust in my fridge that needed to be used so I put it in a glass pie pan as I lack a tart pan in my small kitchen and pre-baked it according to directions.  This was easy to make.  I used eggplant and sweet potato thinly sliced and slightly sauteed for the toppings then added some sliced tomato.  All was good but in future I will use more tomato as I like that flavor the best.    I love the muffin tin or small individual size pies idea someone else posted and I also agree with someone's post that there could be more veggies.  I will definitely make this again!  I had so much left over eggplant, (I only bought one) and sweet potato I roasted the cubed left overs and made a chickpea curry."}, {"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Lily Rygh"}, "datePublished": "2021-07-12", "reviewBody": "So yummy!"}, {"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Abe"}, "datePublished": "2023-11-02", "reviewBody": "Incredible. They're absolutely PACKED with white chocolate morsels and salted macadamia nuts. Chilling the cookie dough is imperative, so set aside at least 2 hours.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "white chocolate macadamia nut cookies", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/09/white-chocolate-macadamia-nut-cookies-1-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/09/white-chocolate-macadamia-nut-cookies-1-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/09/white-chocolate-macadamia-nut-cookies-1-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/09/white-chocolate-macadamia-nut-cookies-1.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/super-chunk-white-chocolate-macadamia-nut-cookies/", "recipeIngredient": ["2 cups + 2 Tablespoons (265g)\u00a0all-purpose flour\u00a0(spooned &amp; leveled)", "1 teaspoon cornstarch", "1 teaspoon baking soda", "1/2 teaspoon salt", "3/4 cup (12 Tbsp; 170g) unsalted butter, melted + slightly cooled", "3/4 cup (150g) packed light or dark brown sugar", "3/4 cup (150g)\u00a0granulated sugar", "1 large\u00a0egg\u00a0+ 1\u00a0egg yolk, at room temperature", "1 and 1/2 teaspoons pure vanilla extract", "1 heaping cup (210g) white chocolate chips*", "1 cup (120g) roughly chopped macadamia nuts*"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Whisk the flour, cornstarch, baking soda, and salt together in a large bowl. Set aside.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/super-chunk-white-chocolate-macadamia-nut-cookies/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Whisk the melted butter, brown sugar, granulated sugar, egg, egg yolk, and vanilla extract together until combined. Pour into dry ingredients and mix everything together with a silicone spatula until completely combined. Fold in the white chocolate chips and macadamia nuts. (You can use a mixer for this step if needed.)", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/super-chunk-white-chocolate-macadamia-nut-cookies/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cover and chill the dough in the refrigerator for at least 2 hours and up to 4 days. If chilling for longer than 2 hours, allow to sit at room temperature for at least 20-30\u00a0minutes before rolling and baking because the dough will be quite hard.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/super-chunk-white-chocolate-macadamia-nut-cookies/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat oven to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C). Line baking sheets with parchment paper or silicone baking mats. This recipe is also in my New York Times best-selling cookbook, Sally's Baking 101.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "white cake", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/01/layered-white-cake-2-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/01/layered-white-cake-2-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/01/layered-white-cake-2-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/01/layered-white-cake-2.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/new-favorite-white-layer-cake/", "recipeIngredient": ["2 and 1/2 cups (295g) cake flour\u00a0(spooned &amp; leveled)", "2 teaspoons baking powder", "1/2 teaspoon baking soda", "1 teaspoon salt", "3/4 cup (12 Tbsp; 170g) unsalted butter, softened to room temperature", "1 and 3/4 cups (350g) granulated sugar", "5 large egg whites, at room temperature", "1/2 cup (120g) full-fat sour cream, at room temperature*", "1 Tablespoon pure vanilla extract (yes, Tbsp!)", "1 cup (240ml) whole milk, at room temperature*", "1 and 1/4 cups (282g) unsalted butter, softened to room temperature", "5 cups (600g) confectioners&#8217; sugar", "1/3 cup (80ml) heavy cream", "2\u00a0teaspoons pure vanilla extract (or use clear imitation vanilla for stark white frosting)", "1/8 teaspoon salt, as needed", "optional: sprinkles, for garnish"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat the oven to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C). Grease two 9-inch round cake pans, line with parchment paper rounds, then grease the parchment paper. Parchment paper helps the cakes seamlessly release from the pans. (If it&#8217;s helpful, see this parchment paper rounds for cakes video &amp; post.)", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/new-favorite-white-layer-cake/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a medium bowl, whisk the cake flour, baking powder, baking soda, and salt together. Set aside.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/new-favorite-white-layer-cake/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a large bowl using a handheld or stand mixer fitted with a paddle attachment, beat the butter and sugar together on medium-high speed until light and creamy, about 3 minutes. Scrape down the sides of the bowl with a silicone spatula as needed. (Here\u2019s a helpful tutorial if you need guidance on\u00a0how to cream butter and sugar.) Add the egg whites and beat on high speed until combined, about 2 minutes. Scrape down the sides and bottom of the bowl as needed. Add the sour cream and vanilla extract, and beat on medium-high speed until combined, about 1 minute.\u00a0 Add the dry ingredients and then, with the mixer running on low speed,\u00a0 slowly pour in the milk and beat just until combined. Do not overmix. You may need to whisk it all by hand to make sure there are no lumps at the bottom of the bowl. The batter will be slightly thick. Pour the batter evenly into the prepared pans.\u00a0", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/new-favorite-white-layer-cake/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake for 24\u201325 minutes or until a toothpick inserted in the center of the cake comes out clean. Cool the cakes in the pans set on a cooling rack for 1 hour. Run a knife around the edges to loosen the sides, remove the cakes from the pan, peel off the parchment, and place on the rack to finish cooling. The cakes must be completely cool before frosting and assembling.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/new-favorite-white-layer-cake/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a large bowl using a handheld mixer or stand mixer fitted with a paddle attachment, beat the butter on medium speed until creamy, about 2 minutes. Sift in the confectioners&#8217; sugar and then add the cream and vanilla extract. Beat on low speed for 30 seconds, then gradually increase to medium-high speed and beat for 2 full minutes. Taste; beat in the salt if the frosting is too sweet. Add more confectioners&#8217; sugar if frosting is too thin, more cream if frosting is too thick, or a pinch more salt if frosting is too sweet.\u00a0", "name": "Make the frosting", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/new-favorite-white-layer-cake/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "(For additional help with this step, see this how to assemble a layer cake video &amp; post.) First, using a large serrated knife, slice a thin layer off the tops of the cakes to create a flat surface. Discard (or crumble over ice cream!). Place one cake layer on your cake stand, cake turntable, or serving plate. Spread 3/4 to 1 cup 3/4\u20131 cup (180\u2013240g) of vanilla buttercream in an even layer on top. Top with the second cake layer, upside down, and spread the top and sides with 1 cup of buttercream (240g) in a very thin layer to make the crumb coat. If desired, run a bench scraper around the cake to help smooth out the frosting on the sides. Refrigerate the cake until the crumb coat has set, about 20 minutes. Finish by spreading the top and sides with the remaining buttercream. For best success, watch the video tutorial and read through the recipe and Notes before starting. I also have a troubleshooting section above.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "pinwheel cookies", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/pinwheel-cookies-homemade-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/pinwheel-cookies-homemade-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/pinwheel-cookies-homemade-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/pinwheel-cookies-homemade.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/pinwheel-cookies/", "recipeIngredient": ["2 and 2/3 cups (333g) all-purpose flour (spooned &amp; leveled)", "3/4 teaspoon baking powder", "1/2 teaspoon salt", "1 cup (16 Tbsp; 226g) unsalted butter, softened to room temperature", "1 cup (200g)\u00a0granulated sugar", "1 large egg + 1 egg yolk, at room temperature", "1 and 1/2 teaspoons pure vanilla extract", "2 Tablespoons\u00a0(10g)\u00a0unsweetened natural or dutch-process cocoa powder", "1 Tablespoon (15ml) milk", "optional: 1/2 teaspoon espresso powder", "6 ounces (170g) white, semi-sweet, or dark chocolate, finely chopped (see Note)", "optional: sprinkles"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Whisk\u00a0the flour, baking powder, and salt together in a medium bowl. Set aside.", "name": "Make the dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/pinwheel-cookies/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a large bowl using a hand mixer or a stand mixer fitted with a paddle attachment, beat the butter and granulated sugar together on medium-high speed until creamed, about 3 minutes. Scrape down the sides and up the bottom of the bowl as needed. (Here\u2019s a helpful tutorial if you need guidance on\u00a0how to cream butter and sugar.) Add the egg, egg yolk, and vanilla extract and beat on high speed until combined, about 1 minute. Scrape down the sides and up the bottom of the bowl and beat again as needed to combine.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/pinwheel-cookies/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Add the flour mixture to the wet ingredients and mix on low speed until combined. Dough will be thick and sticky. Remove from the mixing bowl\u2014no need to rinse out the mixing bowl.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/pinwheel-cookies/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "You should have a little less than 2 lbs. of dough, or somewhere between 800\u2013900g. Divide the dough in half. Note: It&#8217;s ok if the portions aren&#8217;t exactly half. If one half is slightly smaller, use that one for the chocolate dough.", "name": "Divide the dough in half", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/pinwheel-cookies/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Place half of the dough back into the mixing bowl. Add the cocoa powder, milk, and espresso powder (if using). Beat on low speed until dough is combined.", "name": "Make the chocolate dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/pinwheel-cookies/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "The doughs are sticky, so just do your best in this step. Place both doughs on a lightly floured work surface. (Tip: I like to use cocoa powder as my &#8220;flour&#8221; for handling/rolling the chocolate dough.) With lightly floured hands, carefully form each dough into a 1-inch-thick rectangle block, about 4&#215;5 inches in size. Wrap both dough blocks up in plastic wrap, parchment paper, or aluminum foil. Refrigerate for 60\u201390 minutes. The *key* is to only refrigerate until the dough is less sticky, but still pliable enough to bend and shape. Chilling any longer will make it difficult to roll together. If you need to chill it for longer than 90 minutes, make sure you let it sit at room temperature for 15\u201330 minutes before continuing with the next step.", "name": "Shape &amp; chill for 60\u201390 minutes", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/pinwheel-cookies/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Remove vanilla dough from the refrigerator and unwrap. Keep chocolate dough in the refrigerator. Lightly flour a piece of parchment paper. Note that I like to place the parchment paper on top of a silicone baking mat to prevent it from sliding all over the counter, or you can tape it down. (Do not roll the doughs directly on the counter because you may have a hard time lifting/transferring them.) Using a lightly floured rolling pin, begin rolling out the vanilla dough. Flip the dough every now and then between rolls to ensure it&#8217;s not sticking to the parchment. Roll out to an 8&#215;14-inch rectangle, and use your hands to ensure the sides are straight and smooth. The thickness will be between 1/8\u20131/4 inch. Set the dough aside, and it&#8217;s most helpful if you refrigerate the vanilla dough at this time. Pick up the vanilla dough using the parchment paper and place the whole thing in the refrigerator as you roll out the chocolate dough. Lightly dust another piece of parchment paper with flour or cocoa powder. Using a lightly floured (or cocoa powder-ed) rolling pin, roll the chocolate dough out to an 8&#215;14-inch rectangle, or very slightly smaller. Remove vanilla dough from the refrigerator. Carefully peel the chocolate dough off the parchment and do your best to line it up on top of the vanilla dough. Flatten the chocolate dough on top as best you can, gently patting it down to remove any air bubbles between the layers of doughs. Patch any torn chocolate dough pieces back together. And feel free to use a pizza cutter or sharp knife to straighten up any uneven edges.", "name": "Roll out the doughs", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/pinwheel-cookies/#instruction-step-7"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Starting with a long side, tightly roll the 2 doughs together, making sure there are no gaps between them. You can use the parchment paper under the vanilla dough to assist in rolling. Go slowly, and try to roll it as tightly as possible. You can kind of meld the doughs together with your fingers at the beginning to get the roll started. (You can see me do this in the video tutorial below.) If you notice bare or cracked spots of vanilla dough, which usually happens (don&#8217;t worry!), just patch it up with your fingers as you go. Doesn&#8217;t have to look perfect. Once you have your log of dough, cut it in half, so you have two 7-inch-long dough logs.", "name": "Roll into a log", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/pinwheel-cookies/#instruction-step-8"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Wrap each dough log in plastic wrap, parchment paper, or aluminum foil and refrigerate for 2 more hours and up to 4 days.", "name": "Chill for 2 more hours:\u00a0", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/pinwheel-cookies/#instruction-step-9"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat oven to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C).\u00a0Line 2 baking sheets with parchment paper or silicone baking mats. Set aside.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/pinwheel-cookies/#instruction-step-10"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Slice each log into 14 1/2-inch-thick cookies.\u00a0\u00a0", "name": "Slice and bake", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/pinwheel-cookies/#instruction-step-11"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Arrange cookies about 2 inches apart on the prepared baking sheets\u2014expect these cookies to expand quite a bit in the oven. If the dough got a little soft from working with it, chill the cookies on the baking sheet in the refrigerator for 10 minutes before baking. Bake for 14\u201315 minutes or until very lightly browned around the edges.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/pinwheel-cookies/#instruction-step-12"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Remove from the oven and allow cookies to cool on the baking sheet for 5 minutes before transferring to a wire rack to cool completely.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/pinwheel-cookies/#instruction-step-13"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Coarsely chop the chocolate. Melt in a double boiler or the microwave. If using the microwave, stir every 20 seconds until it&#8217;s smooth. Dip half of each cooled cookie into the chocolate. Add sprinkles on top of chocolate, if desired.\u00a0Allow chocolate to completely set at room temperature or in the refrigerator.", "name": "Optional chocolate dipping", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/pinwheel-cookies/#instruction-step-14"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cookies stay fresh covered at room temperature for 1 week. Refrigerate cookies dipped in chocolate after a few days.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/pinwheel-cookies/#instruction-step-15"}], "prepTime": "PT4H15M", "cookTime": "PT15M", "totalTime": "PT4H35M", "recipeYield": ["28", "28 cookies"], "recipeCategory": "Cookies", "cookingMethod": "Baking", "recipeCuisine": "American", "aggregateRating": {"@type": "AggregateRating", "reviewCount": "126", "ratingValue": "4.7"}, "video": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "VideoObject", "name": "How to Make Pinwheel Cookies | Sally's Baking Recipes", "description": "This video shows the process of making pinwheel cookies from scratch. These mesmerizingly beautiful and delightfully soft pinwheel cookies come together by layering and rolling chocolate and vanilla cookie dough together. Chilling the dough is imperative. Or, if you don&#8217;t have a stand mixer, a regular large mixing bowl. Whisk together, cover bowl with a towel, and allow to sit for 5 minutes. The mixture will be frothy and foamy after 5 minutes.", "name": "Make the dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/whole-wheat-rolls/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "On low speed, beat in the softened butter until it is slightly broken up. Then beat in the honey, eggs, and salt. The butter won&#8217;t really be mixing into the mixture, so don&#8217;t be alarmed if it stays in pieces. On low speed, gradually add the flour. Once it is all added, beat on medium speed until a soft dough forms.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/whole-wheat-rolls/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Keep the dough in the mixer and beat for an additional 6-8 full minutes, or knead by hand on a lightly floured surface for 6-8 full minutes. (If you\u2019re new to bread-baking, my How to Knead Dough video tutorial can help here.) If the dough becomes too sticky during the kneading process, sprinkle 1 teaspoon of flour at a time on the dough or on the work surface/in the bowl to make a soft, slightly tacky dough. Do not add more flour than you need because you do not want a dry dough. After kneading, the dough should still feel a little soft. Poke it with your finger\u2014if it slowly bounces back, your dough is ready to rise.", "name": "Knead the dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/whole-wheat-rolls/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Transfer the dough to a lightly floured surface (if you kneaded with your mixer) and knead it with your hands for 1 minute. Form the dough into a ball, coat your mixing bowl with nonstick spray or olive oil, and place the dough back in and turn it over so all sides of the dough are coated with the oil/spray. Cover the dough/bowl loosely with plastic wrap, a paper towel, or aluminum foil and let sit in a warm place until doubled in size, about 1.5 &#8211; 2 hours. Here&#8217;s what I do: turn the oven on to 150\u00b0F (66\u00b0C). Once heated to that temperature, turn the oven off. Stick the covered dough inside the oven and allow it to rise in this warm environment.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/whole-wheat-rolls/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Grease the bottom and sides of a 9&#215;13-inch baking dish. Set aside.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/whole-wheat-rolls/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Punch the dough down to release any air bubbles and turn it out onto a lightly floured work surface. Using floured hands, stretch the dough into a 9&#215;13 rectangle (doesn&#8217;t need to be exact, it can be a little smaller). Use a\u00a0pizza cutter and cut into 15 rolls. See photo above for a visual. Round out the edges of the rolls since they stretched a bit as you cut them. Arrange in prepared pan. Loosely cover the rolls and allow to rise in a warm environment again until puffy and double in size, about 1 hour.", "name": "Shape the rolls", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/whole-wheat-rolls/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat the oven to\u00a0375\u00b0F (191\u00b0C). Bake rolls for about 25 minutes or until they are golden brown. About halfway through the bake time, I like to cover the rolls loosely with aluminum foil so the tops don&#8217;t brown too much. I let it sit out for five minutes before putting it in the tray but the rise on them was minimal and they looked quite... sad. lol. for the remaining batter, I let it sit out at room temp while the first batch baked, and then did an additional temperature shock by preheating the oven to 400 degrees for two minutes and then lowering the temp to 350 for a shorter time. the second batch looks slightly better, but i definitely would make some changes to this recipe/my technique for next time."}, {"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Maisie Matthews"}, "datePublished": "2025-09-01", "reviewBody": "Brilliant although didn't rise as much as I hope. Turn the dough about a quarter turn after every few rolls until you have a circle 12 inches in diameter. If your skillet is 12 inches, roll out the pie dough to about 13 inches so it fits.\u00a0Carefully lay the dough over the filling. Set aside 1 hour to chill the dough in the refrigerator before baking.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "white chocolate cranberry cookies", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/soft-white-chocolate-chip-dried-cranberry-cookies-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/soft-white-chocolate-chip-dried-cranberry-cookies-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/soft-white-chocolate-chip-dried-cranberry-cookies-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/soft-white-chocolate-chip-dried-cranberry-cookies.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/soft-baked-white-chocolate-chip-cranberry-cookies/", "recipeIngredient": ["3/4 cup (12 Tbsp; 170g) unsalted butter, softened to room temperature", "3/4 cup (150g) packed light or dark brown sugar (I use dark)", "1/4 cup (50g) granulated sugar", "1 large egg, at room temperature", "2 teaspoons pure vanilla extract", "2 cups (250g) all-purpose flour (spooned &amp; leveled)", "2 teaspoons cornstarch (cornflour)", "1 teaspoon baking soda", "1/2 teaspoon salt", "3/4 cup (135g) white chocolate chips, plus a few extra for garnish", "1 cup (140g) dried cranberries, plus a few extra for garnish"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a large bowl using a handheld mixer or stand mixer with paddle attachment, beat the butter, brown sugar, and granulated sugar together on medium speed until combined and creamy, about 3 minutes. (Here\u2019s a helpful tutorial if you need guidance on\u00a0how to cream butter and sugar.) Beat in the egg and vanilla. Scrape down the sides and bottom of the bowl and beat again as needed to combine.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/soft-baked-white-chocolate-chip-cranberry-cookies/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a separate bowl, whisk the flour, cornstarch, baking soda and salt together. On low speed, slowly mix into the wet ingredients until combined. The cookie dough will be soft and thick. Add the white chocolate chips and dried cranberries and beat on low speed until combined. Cover dough tightly and chill in the refrigerator for at least 1 hour and up to 3-4 days. Chilling is imperative to prevent the cookies from over-spreading.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/soft-baked-white-chocolate-chip-cranberry-cookies/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Remove cookie dough from the refrigerator. If the cookie dough chilled longer than 3-4 hours, let it sit at room temperature for about 30 minutes. This makes the firm cookie dough easier to scoop and roll.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/soft-baked-white-chocolate-chip-cranberry-cookies/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat oven to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C). Line large baking sheets with parchment paper or silicone baking mats. Set aside.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/soft-baked-white-chocolate-chip-cranberry-cookies/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "As the oven preheats, scoop and roll dough, about 1.5 Tablespoons of dough each, into balls. The dough may be slightly crumbly, but will come together as you work it with your hands. Arrange dough balls 3 inches apart on the prepared baking sheets.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/soft-baked-white-chocolate-chip-cranberry-cookies/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake for 11-12 minutes or until lightly browned around the edges. The centers will still look soft. If cookies didn&#8217;t spread much, lightly bang the the baking sheets on the counter a couple times while the cookies are still warm. They&#8217;ll stretch and deflate.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/soft-baked-white-chocolate-chip-cranberry-cookies/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Allow cookies to cool on the baking sheet for 5 minutes. During this time, press extra white chocolate chips and dried cranberries into the warm tops. This is optional and only for looks. The dough does not have to rise twice. In fact, it doesn't even need to rise at all! All of the rising and baking is done in the slow cooker. And the rolls are unbelievably moist and soft.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "slow cooker cinnamon rolls, cinnamon rolls", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/slow-cooker-cinnamon-rolls-3-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/slow-cooker-cinnamon-rolls-3-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/slow-cooker-cinnamon-rolls-3-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/slow-cooker-cinnamon-rolls-3.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/easy-slow-cooker-cinnamon-rolls/", "recipeIngredient": ["3/4 cup (180ml) whole milk", "1 packet\u00a0Red Star Platinum Yeast\u00a0or any instant yeast\u00a0(1 packet = 2 and 1/4 teaspoons)", "1/4 cup + 1 teaspoon (55g) granulated sugar, divided", "3/4 teaspoon salt", "1/4 cup (4 Tbsp; 56g) unsalted butter, melted and slightly cooled", "1 large egg", "2 and 3/4 cups (344g) all-purpose flour\u00a0(spooned &amp; leveled)", "5 Tablespoons (71g) unsalted butter, very soft", "1 Tablespoon ground cinnamon", "1/3 cup (67g) granulated sugar", "1 and 1/4 cups (150g) confectioners&#8217; sugar", "2 Tablespoons (30ml) pure maple syrup (or use 1 teaspoon vanilla extract)", "2 Tablespoons (30ml)\u00a0milk"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Warm the milk over on the stove over low heat or microwave it until lukewarm. No need to use a thermometer, but to be precise: about\u00a095\u00b0F (35\u00b0C). Pour the warm milk into the bowl of a stand mixer fitted with the dough hook or paddle attachment (OR you can use a handheld mixer). Whisk in the yeast and 1 teaspoon granulated sugar. Cover with a clean towel and let sit until the yeast is foamy, about 5-10 minutes. This is called proofing the yeast. If the yeast does not dissolve and foam, start over with fresh active yeast. On low speed, beat in\u00a0the remaining 1/4 cup sugar, salt, butter, egg, and 2 cups of flour until combined. The dough will be wet. While continuing to beat on low speed, add the remaining flour 1/4 cup at a time until a soft dough forms.\u00a0Dough will be ready when it gently pulls away from the sides of the bowl. I usually use 2 and 3/4 cups flour total. **If you do not have a mixer, you can stir the dough by hand with a wooden spoon in this step.", "name": "Make the dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/easy-slow-cooker-cinnamon-rolls/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "\u00a0Keep the dough in the mixer and beat for an additional 5 full minutes, or knead by hand on a lightly floured surface for 5 full minutes. (If you\u2019re new to bread-baking, my How to Knead Dough video tutorial can help here.) If the dough becomes too sticky during the kneading process, sprinkle 1 teaspoon of flour at a time on the dough or on the work surface/in the bowl to make a soft, slightly tacky dough. Do not add more flour than you need because you do not want a dry dough. After kneading, the dough should still feel a little soft. Poke it with your finger\u2014if it slowly bounces back, your dough is ready to rise. You can also do a \u201cwindowpane test\u201d to see if your dough has been kneaded long enough: tear off a small (roughly golfball-size) piece of dough and gently stretch it out until it\u2019s thin enough for light to pass through it. Hold it up to a window or light. Does light pass through the stretched dough without the dough tearing first? If so, your dough has been kneaded long enough and is ready to rise. If not, keep kneading until it passes the windowpane test.", "name": "Knead the dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/easy-slow-cooker-cinnamon-rolls/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Let the dough rest for about 10 minutes. During this 10 minutes, line a 4 or 5 quart slow cooker with greased parchment paper. (I spray it with non-stick spray, but brushing oil or softened butter all over it works too.) If you have a larger slow cooker, that&#8217;s ok\u2014just space the rolls out more.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/easy-slow-cooker-cinnamon-rolls/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "After 10 minutes, roll the dough out in a 14&#215;8-inch rectangle. Spread the softened butter on top. Mix the cinnamon and sugar together, then sprinkle on top of the butter. Roll the dough up tightly, then cut into 10-12 even pieces and place them inside the lined slow cooker. Place a paper towel right under the lid of the slow cooker\u2014this will help keep condensation off of the cooking rolls. Do not leave that step out and do not use a cloth towel.", "name": "Make the filling:\u00a0", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/easy-slow-cooker-cinnamon-rolls/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Turn your slow cooker on high speed and cook for 2 hours, or until the rolls are fully cooked through. It&#8217;s usually 2 hours, sometimes\u00a02 hours and 15 minutes. Once they&#8217;re done, remove the rolls from the cooker right away by lifting out the parchment paper.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/easy-slow-cooker-cinnamon-rolls/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "\u00a0Right before serving, top\u00a0your cinnamon rolls with glaze. Whisk the confectioners&#8217;\u00a0sugar, maple syrup, and milk together until smooth. Add a little more milk if too thick. Drizzle over the warm rolls.", "name": "Make the icing", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/easy-slow-cooker-cinnamon-rolls/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Rolls are best enjoyed the same day, but stay fresh covered tightly in the refrigerator for 5 days. Rolls (with or without icing) freeze well up to 3 months. Thaw overnight in the refrigerator and heat up however you prefer.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/easy-slow-cooker-cinnamon-rolls/#instruction-step-7"}], "prepTime": "PT30M", "cookTime": "PT2H", "totalTime": "PT2H30M", "recipeYield": ["10", "10-12 cinnamon rolls"], "recipeCategory": "Breakfast", "cookingMethod": "Baking", "recipeCuisine": "American", "aggregateRating": {"@type": "AggregateRating", "reviewCount": "18", "ratingValue": "4.3"}, "review": [{"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "3"}, "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Katie"}, "datePublished": "2020-05-12", "reviewBody": "Was really intrigued and excited by this! They turned out really well and I actually found them easier to separate than the original, as they held their shape and didn't spread together.
