Garnish with fresh whipped cream for a truly epic ending to your meal!", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "amaretto cheesecake", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/12/amaretto-cheesecake-2-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/12/amaretto-cheesecake-2-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/12/amaretto-cheesecake-2-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/12/amaretto-cheesecake-2.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/amaretto-cheesecake/", "recipeIngredient": ["1 and 1/3 cups (160g) graham cracker crumbs (about 10\u201311 full sheet graham crackers)", "1/2 cup (62g) roasted or raw\u00a0almonds*", "1 Tablespoon (12g) granulated sugar", "5 Tablespoons (71g) unsalted butter, melted", "32 ounces (904g) full-fat brick cream cheese, softened to room temperature", "1 cup (200g) granulated sugar", "2 teaspoons cornstarch", "1 cup (240g) full-fat sour cream, at room temperature", "1/3 cup (75g)\u00a0amaretto liqueur", "1/2 teaspoon pure vanilla extract", "1/2 teaspoon almond extract", "3 large eggs, at room temperature", "1 and 1/4 cups mini semi-sweet chocolate chips*", "topping suggestions: toasted almonds, chocolate chips, chocolate ganache,\u00a0whipped cream*"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Adjust the oven rack to the lower-middle position and preheat oven to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C).", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/amaretto-cheesecake/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Using a food processor, pulse the graham cracker crumbs and almonds together until the almonds are crumbs. Pour into a medium bowl and stir in sugar until combined, and then stir in the melted butter. Mixture will be sandy. Try to smash/break up any large chunks. Pour into an ungreased 10-inch springform pan and with medium pressure using your hand, pat the crumbs down into the bottom and partly up the sides to make a compact crust. Do not pack down with heavy force because that makes the crust too hard. Simply pat down until the mixture is no longer crumby/crumbly. Tips: You can use a small flat-bottomed measuring cup to help press down the bottom crust and smooth out the surface, but do not pack down too hard. For more shaping technique tips, see the graham cracker crust recipe page.", "name": "Make the crust", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/amaretto-cheesecake/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Pre-bake the crust for 10 minutes. Remove from the oven and place the hot pan on a large piece of aluminum foil. The foil will wrap around the pan for the water bath or water bath alternative in step 5. Allow crust to slightly cool as you prepare the filling.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/amaretto-cheesecake/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Using a handheld or stand mixer fitted with a paddle or whisk attachment, beat the cream cheese and granulated sugar together on medium-high speed in a large bowl until the mixture is smooth and creamy, about 2 minutes. Add the cornstarch, sour cream, amaretto, vanilla extract, and almond extract then beat until fully combined. On medium speed, add the eggs one at a time, beating after each addition until just blended. After the final egg is incorporated into the batter, stop the mixer. Fold in chocolate chips. Avoid over-mixing the batter.", "name": "Make the filling:\u00a0", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/amaretto-cheesecake/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "\u00a0If needed for extra visuals, see my\u00a0How to Make a Cheesecake Water Bath; the visual guide will assist you in this step. Boil a pot of water. You need 1 inch of water in your roasting pan for the water bath, so make sure you boil enough. I use an entire kettle of hot water. Place the pan inside of a large roasting pan. Pour the cheesecake batter on top of the crust. Use a silicone spatula or spoon to smooth it into an even layer. Carefully pour the hot water inside of the pan and place in the oven. (Or you can place the roasting pan in the oven first, then pour the hot water in. Whichever is easier for you.)", "name": "Prepare the simple water bath (see note for alternative method)", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/amaretto-cheesecake/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "(Note: if you notice the cheesecake browning too quickly on top, tent it with aluminum foil halfway through baking.) Bake cheesecake for 60\u201375 minutes or until the center is almost set. When it&#8217;s done, the center of the cheesecake will slightly jiggle if you gently tap the pan. Turn the oven off and open the oven door slightly. Let the cheesecake sit in the oven as it cools down for 1 hour. (Inside the water bath or, if you used the alternative, with the water bath pan inside the oven.) Remove from the oven and allow to cool completely at room temperature. Then, refrigerate the cheesecake for at least 4 hours or overnight. I recommend overnight.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/amaretto-cheesecake/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Use a knife to loosen the chilled cheesecake from the rim of the springform pan, then remove the rim. Garnish with toppings. I used toasted almonds, mini chocolate chips, and amaretto whipped cream. See recipe note about toasting almonds and for amaretto whipped cream. I used\u00a0Wilton 8B\u00a0piping tip for the pictured whipped cream. Using a clean sharp knife, cut into slices for serving. For neat slices, wipe the knife clean and dip into warm water between each slice.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/amaretto-cheesecake/#instruction-step-7"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cover and store leftover cheesecake in the refrigerator for up to 5 days.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/amaretto-cheesecake/#instruction-step-8"}], "prepTime": "PT45M", "cookTime": "PT1H10M", "totalTime": "PT9H45M", "recipeYield": ["12", "serves 12-16"], "recipeCategory": "Dessert", "cookingMethod": "Baking", "recipeCuisine": "American", "aggregateRating": {"@type": "AggregateRating", "reviewCount": "19", "ratingValue": "4.6"}, "review": [{"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Christine"}, "datePublished": "2023-12-26", "reviewBody": "Another win with one of Sally\u2019s recipes! No cracks, no depression in the middle. The water bath worked superbly. I think the key to the water bath is to use a single piece of heavy duty aluminum foil that is big enough, wide enough. so that there are no seams in it anywhere. The heavy duty foil is strong enough so it doesn't tear. I ran the foil all the way up to the lip of the spring form pan and then put the whole thing in a 12\" round steel frying pan. Once the spring form was in the frying pan I poured the batter in then the boiling water slowly around it about half the way up the sides, as Sally describes in her recipe. If using certified gluten-free oats, they're gluten free as well!", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "berry streusel bars, healthy bars, vegan", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/07/healthy-berry-bars-2-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/07/healthy-berry-bars-2-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/07/healthy-berry-bars-2-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/07/healthy-berry-bars-2.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/healthy-berry-streusel-bars/", "recipeIngredient": ["1 and 1/2 Tablespoons (12g) cornstarch", "1 and 1/2 Tablespoons (23ml) water", "2 cups (about 300g) fresh or frozen mixed berries (do not thaw &amp; see note)", "1/4 cup (60ml) pure maple syrup", "1 Tablespoon (11g) coconut sugar, brown sugar, or granulated sugar", "2 and 1/2 cups (213g) old-fashioned whole rolled oats or quick oats", "1/2 teaspoon ground cinnamon", "1 cup (255g) almond butter", "1/4 cup (60ml) pure maple syrup", "1/4 cup (60g) unsweetened applesauce", "1/4 cup (56g) coconut oil, melted (or use melted butter)", "for topping: 1/2 cup (64g) sliced or chopped almonds and\u00a01 extra Tablespoon oats"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Whisk the cornstarch and water together until all the cornstarch has dissolved. (I just use a fork to mix\u2014very easy.) Place the cornstarch mixture, berries, maple syrup, and coconut sugar in a medium saucepan over medium heat. Using a rubber spatula, stir the mixture as it cooks. Smash some of the berries against the bottom/sides of the pot as you stir, gently breaking them up. Bring to a simmer and allow to simmer for 2 minutes, stirring constantly. After 2 minutes, remove pan from the heat and allow to cool completely. The mixture will thicken as it cools. To speed up the cooling process, feel free to cover and refrigerate it after it slightly cools for at least 30 minutes at room temperature. I recommend making the berry filling in advance so it can cool completely. Berry filling can be cold or room temperature when you assemble the bars\u2014you just don&#8217;t want it hot or warm.", "name": "Berry Filling", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/healthy-berry-streusel-bars/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat oven to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C). The instructions remain exactly the same.", "inLanguage": "en-US"}, "inLanguage": "en-US"}, {"@context": "https://schema.org/", "@type": "Recipe", "name": "Pear Tarte Tatin (Made Simple)", "description": "This is pear tarte tatin made simpler. A classic French dessert, tarte tatin is a rustic fruit tart served upside down. Caramelized with butter and sugar in a skillet, the fruit is then baked beneath a blanket of pastry dough\u2014which becomes a crust once flipped. Depending how you make it, the recipe is often quite technical and complicated. I simplified the process as much as possible without compromising flavor. See step-by-step photos above and carefully read through the recipe before beginning.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "pear tarte tatin", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/pear-tarte-tatin-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/pear-tarte-tatin-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/pear-tarte-tatin-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/pear-tarte-tatin.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/pear-tarte-tatin/", "recipeIngredient": ["1\u00a0and 1/2 cups (188g)\u00a0all-purpose flour\u00a0(spooned &amp; leveled), plus more as needed", "2 Tablespoons\u00a0(25g)\u00a0granulated sugar", "1/4 teaspoon\u00a0salt", "1/2 cup (8 Tbsp; 113g) cold unsalted butter, cubed*", "1/4 cup (60ml) ice-cold water, plus more as needed", "5\u20136 small, semi-firm pears (about 1.5\u20132 lbs.)", "1 Tablespoon freshly squeezed lemon or orange juice", "1/4 teaspoon ground cinnamon", "1/8 teaspoon ground nutmeg\u00a0", "1/8 teaspoon ground ginger", "1/4 cup (4 Tbsp; 56g) unsalted butter", "1/2 cup (100g) packed light or dark brown sugar"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Whisk the flour, sugar, and salt together in a medium bowl. Using a pastry cutter or 2 forks, cut in the butter until the mixture resembles coarse pea-sized crumbs. Add the water and stir until the flour is moistened. Add 1\u20132 more Tablespoons of water if the dough seems dry. Turn the dough out onto a lightly floured work surface and, using your hands, work the dough into a ball. Flatten it into a thick disc. Wrap the dough disc in plastic wrap or parchment paper and refrigerate it for at least 1 hour, and up to 3 days.", "name": "Make the crust", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/pear-tarte-tatin/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Peel, halve lengthwise, and scoop out the seeded core of the pears. Remove the stem, including the bottom part of the stem. Place the pears in a medium bowl, and toss gently with lemon/orange juice, cinnamon, nutmeg, and ginger, until evenly coated. Place the bowl in the refrigerator until you&#8217;re ready to use the pears.", "name": "As the dough chills, prepare the pears", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/pear-tarte-tatin/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Melt the butter in a 10-inch oven-safe skillet over medium heat, or use a heavy-duty medium saucepan. Once the butter has melted, whisk in the brown sugar. At first it will look very separated, like it doesn&#8217;t want to combine, but that&#8217;s ok. Just keep whisking. Cook, whisking occasionally, for 3 minutes. Remove from heat and let cool for a few minutes while you roll out the crust. (If you used a saucepan for the caramel, pour it into an ungreased 9 or 10-inch pie dish.)", "name": "Make the caramel sauce", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/pear-tarte-tatin/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat oven to 400\u00b0F (204\u00b0C).", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/pear-tarte-tatin/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Roll out the chilled dough into a circle about 11\u201312 inches in diameter (it doesn&#8217;t have to be perfect!). Arrange the pears, cut-side up, in the skillet. Drape the pastry crust round over top of the pears. Gently tuck in the edges of the crust around the pears with a spoon. Dock (prick) the crust with a fork, to allow steam to escape.", "name": "Assemble", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/pear-tarte-tatin/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake for 20 minutes, then keeping the tarte tatin in the oven, reduce the temperature to 375\u00b0F (191\u00b0C) and bake for 25 more minutes, or until the crust is golden-brown.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/pear-tarte-tatin/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Allow to cool for 10 minutes on a cooling rack, and then carefully invert the tart onto a large serving plate or platter. I recommend doing this over the sink to catch any possible spills. Use extreme caution as the caramel sauce and fruit are very, very hot.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/pear-tarte-tatin/#instruction-step-7"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Slice and serve warm or at room temperature with vanilla ice cream, if desired. Cover and store leftover pear tarte tatin in the refrigerator for up to 4 days.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/pear-tarte-tatin/#instruction-step-8"}], "prepTime": "PT1H40M", "cookTime": "PT55M", "totalTime": "PT2H45M", "recipeYield": ["8", "serves 8"], "recipeCategory": "Dessert", "cookingMethod": "Baking", "recipeCuisine": "French", "aggregateRating": {"@type": "AggregateRating", "reviewCount": "8", "ratingValue": "4.5"}, "review": [{"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "4"}, "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Connie"}, "datePublished": "2024-11-18", "reviewBody": "I was very excited to try this as this was a technical challenge on the Great British Bake Off. but the crust was a miss. I\u2019ve made an apple tart tatin with puff pastry &amp; it was much better. I used the all butter crust and it was tough and chewy. The pears and caramel we\u2019re absolutely delicious though! The dough has a bright lemon flavor and, after baking, you'll top them with a tangy-sweet lemon cream cheese icing. See recipe Notes for overnight and freezing instructions.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "blueberry lemon sweet rolls", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/06/blueberry-rolls-with-lemon-icing-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/06/blueberry-rolls-with-lemon-icing-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/06/blueberry-rolls-with-lemon-icing-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/06/blueberry-rolls-with-lemon-icing.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/blueberry-sweet-rolls-with-lemon-glaze/", "recipeIngredient": ["2 and 3/4 cups (344g) all-purpose flour (spooned &amp; leveled)", "1/4 cup (50g) granulated sugar", "1/2 teaspoon salt", "1 teaspoon lemon zest", "3/4 cup (180ml) whole milk", "3 Tablespoons (43g) unsalted butter", "2 and 1/4 teaspoons Platinum Yeast from Red Star or any instant yeast (1 standard packet)*", "1 large egg, at room temperature", "1 and 1/4 cups (170\u2013180g) fresh blueberries (do NOT use frozen)", "6 Tablespoons (75g) granulated sugar", "1 teaspoon lemon juice", "4 ounces (113g) full-fat brick cream cheese, softened to room temperature", "1 Tablespoon (14g) unsalted butter, softened to room temperature", "3/4 cup (90g) confectioners&#8217; sugar", "2 Tablespoons (30ml) lemon juice", "optional: lemon zest or sliced lemons for garnish"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Whisk the flour, sugar, salt, and lemon zest together in a large bowl. Set aside.", "name": "Make the dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/blueberry-sweet-rolls-with-lemon-glaze/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Combine the milk and butter together in a heatproof bowl. Microwave or use the stove and heat until the butter has melted and the mixture is warm to the touch (about 110\u00b0F/43\u00b0C, no higher). Whisk in the yeast until it has dissolved. Pour mixture into the dry ingredients, add the egg, and stir with a sturdy silicone spatula or wooden spoon; OR use a stand mixer with a dough hook attachment on medium speed. Mix until a soft dough forms.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/blueberry-sweet-rolls-with-lemon-glaze/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Transfer dough to a lightly floured surface. Using floured hands (or the dough hook attachment if using a stand mixer), knead the dough for 3\u20135 minutes. (If you\u2019re new to bread-baking, my How to Knead Dough video tutorial can help here.) If the dough becomes too sticky during the kneading process, sprinkle 1 teaspoon of flour at a time on the dough or on the work surface/in the bowl to make a soft, slightly tacky dough. Do not add more flour than you need because you do not want a dry dough. After kneading, the dough should still feel a little soft. Poke it with your finger\u2014if it slowly bounces back, your dough is ready to rise.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/blueberry-sweet-rolls-with-lemon-glaze/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Lightly grease a large bowl with nonstick spray or butter. Place the dough in the bowl, turning it to coat all sides. Cover the bowl tightly and allow the dough to rise in a relatively warm environment until nearly double in size, about 1.5 hours. (If desired, use my warm oven trick for rising. See my answer to Where Should Dough Rise?\u00a0in my\u00a0Baking with Yeast Guide.)", "name": "1st rise", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/blueberry-sweet-rolls-with-lemon-glaze/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Combine blueberries, sugar, and lemon juice together in a small saucepan with tall sides over medium heat. Stir constantly with a wooden spoon or silicone spatula, pressing the blueberries against the sides of the pan (stand back in case they splatter!). Once the blueberries are mostly smashed and the sugar has dissolved, stop stirring and allow to come to a boil. Boil, stirring occasionally, until the mixture is slightly reduced, about 10 minutes. (If you have a candy or instant-read thermometer, the mixture should reach about 215\u2013220\u00b0F.) You should have about 1/2 cup (around 160g). Remove from heat and allow to cool completely. The filling will thicken as it cools. You can transfer it to a shallow heat-safe dish and place it in the refrigerator to cool down quicker. Set aside.", "name": "While the dough is rising, make the blueberry filling", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/blueberry-sweet-rolls-with-lemon-glaze/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Grease a 9- or 10-inch round cake pan, pie dish, or square baking pan or line with parchment paper.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/blueberry-sweet-rolls-with-lemon-glaze/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "When the dough is ready, punch it down to release the air. Flour a work surface, your hands, and a rolling pin. Roll the dough out to a 14&#215;9-inch (36x20cm) rectangle. *Note: Should it run over the sides of the dough, the blueberry filling can stain a work surface. If needed, transfer the rolled-out dough to a piece of parchment paper or silicone baking mat.* Gently spread the blueberry filling mixture on top. Using floured hands, tightly roll up the dough to form a 14-inch-long log.", "name": "Shape &amp; fill the dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/blueberry-sweet-rolls-with-lemon-glaze/#instruction-step-7"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cut into 9\u201312 even rolls and arrange in the prepared pan.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/blueberry-sweet-rolls-with-lemon-glaze/#instruction-step-8"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cover the pan with aluminum foil, plastic wrap, or a clean kitchen towel. Allow the rolls to rise in a relatively warm environment for about 1 hour, or until doubled in size and puffy. (For a tiny reduction in rise time, see my answer to Where Should Dough Rise?\u00a0in my\u00a0Baking With Yeast Guide.)", "name": "2nd rise", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/blueberry-sweet-rolls-with-lemon-glaze/#instruction-step-9"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "After the rolls have nearly doubled in size, preheat the oven to 375\u00b0F (190\u00b0C). Bake for 24\u201325 minutes, or until lightly browned. If you notice the tops are getting too brown too quickly, loosely tent the pan with aluminum foil and continue baking. If you want to be precise about their doneness, the rolls&#8217; internal temperature taken with an instant-read thermometer should be around 195\u2013200\u00b0F (91\u201393\u00b0C) when done. Remove pan from the oven and place pan on a cooling rack as you make the icing.", "name": "Bake the rolls", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/blueberry-sweet-rolls-with-lemon-glaze/#instruction-step-10"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a medium bowl using a handheld or stand mixer fitted with a paddle or whisk attachment, beat the cream cheese on high speed until smooth and creamy. Add the butter and beat until smooth and combined, then beat in the confectioners\u2019 sugar and lemon juice until combined. Using a knife or icing spatula, spread the icing over the warm rolls and serve immediately. If desired, garnish frosted rolls with a slice of lemon or a light sprinkling of lemon zest.", "name": "Make the icing", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/blueberry-sweet-rolls-with-lemon-glaze/#instruction-step-11"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cover leftover frosted rolls tightly and store in the refrigerator for up to 5 days. Add egg, egg yolk, and vanilla extract, then beat on medium-high speed until combined. Scrape down the sides and up the bottom of the bowl as needed. Beat in the dry ingredients on low speed, then beat in the chocolate chips until combined. The dough will be thick.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/giant-chocolate-chip-cookies/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Divide dough into 6 portions. Each will be a heaping 1/2 cup and weigh a little over 6 ounces. Shape each into mound, slightly flattening down the top. If you absolutely cannot use it, you can try replacing it with one 8-ounce block of full-fat cream cheese, though the chocolate will have more of a cream cheese flavor. Or you can make <a href=\"https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-ganache/\">chocolate ganache</a>. Wait for it to cool and thicken until spoonable consistency.", "inLanguage": "en-US"}, "inLanguage": "en-US"}, {"@context": "https://schema.org/", "@type": "Recipe", "name": "Peanut Butter Fudge Puddles (Cookie Cups)", "description": "These delightful 2-bite peanut butter cookie cups are known as peanut butter fudge puddles. They're baked in a mini muffin pan, then filled with a rich chocolate cream. The secret ingredient is mascarpone cheese, which keeps the fudge-like chocolate filling super soft and creamy. Note that these bake at 325\u00b0F (163\u00b0C) and not 350\u00b0F.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "peanut butter fudge puddles", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/peanut-butter-fudge-puddle-cookie-cups-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/peanut-butter-fudge-puddle-cookie-cups-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/peanut-butter-fudge-puddle-cookie-cups-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/peanut-butter-fudge-puddle-cookie-cups.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/peanut-butter-fudge-puddles/", "recipeIngredient": ["1/2 cup (8 Tbsp; 113g) unsalted butter, softened to room temperature", "1/2 cup (100g) packed light or dark brown sugar", "1/2 cup (100g) granulated sugar", "1 large egg, at room temperature", "2/3 cup (156g) creamy peanut butter", "1 teaspoon pure vanilla extract", "1 and 1/4 cups (156g) all-purpose flour (spooned &amp; leveled)", "1/2 teaspoon baking soda", "1/2 teaspoon salt", "8 ounces (226g) semi-sweet chocolate, chopped (see Note)", "1 teaspoon vegetable oil or coconut oil", "8 ounces (226g) mascarpone cheese, at room temperature", "optional: 1/2 cup (120g) Heath toffee bits or chopped peanuts, for topping"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a large bowl using a hand mixer or a stand mixer fitted with paddle attachment, beat the butter, brown sugar, and granulated sugar on medium high speed until light and creamy, about 3 minutes. (Here\u2019s a helpful tutorial if you need guidance on\u00a0how to cream butter and sugar.) Add the egg and beat until combined, about 1 minute. Scrape down the sides and bottom of the bowl with a silicone spatula as needed. Add the peanut butter and vanilla extract and beat until combined.", "name": "Make the cookie cups", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/peanut-butter-fudge-puddles/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Add the flour, baking soda, and salt to the wet ingredients and beat on low speed until the dry ingredients are incorporated, and then increase to medium speed and beat until well combined. The dough will be very creamy and soft. Cover and chill the cookie dough in the refrigerator for at least 1 hour, and up to 3 days.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/peanut-butter-fudge-puddles/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Grease 2 mini muffin pans (or bake in batches if you have only 1 pan) with nonstick spray, or line with mini cupcake liners. I prefer these without liners; the dough is easier to &#8220;thumbprint&#8221; without liners. Set aside.\u00a0", "name": "Preheat oven to 325\u00b0F (163\u00b0C)", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/peanut-butter-fudge-puddles/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Scoop and roll cookie dough, about 1 Tablespoon/20g of dough each. Place the dough balls in the prepared pan. With your thumb, press down in the center of each dough ball, to make an indent, and press the dough partway up the sides of the muffin cup. (If you only have 1 mini muffin pan, refrigerate the 2nd batch of dough balls until ready to bake.)", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/peanut-butter-fudge-puddles/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake for 14\u201315 minutes or until the edges appear lightly browned. Do not under-bake these. The cookie cups will puff up in the oven; that&#8217;s ok and expected.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/peanut-butter-fudge-puddles/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Remove from the oven and place the mini muffin pan on a cooling rack. Let the cookie cups cool in the pan for just 5\u201310 minutes. During this time, use the back of a rounded teaspoon to lightly press into the center of each cookie cup to make the indent deeper again. After 5\u201310 minutes, carefully remove cookie cups from the pan. Use a butter knife to help, if needed. Place cookie cups on a cooling rack to cool completely.\u00a0", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/peanut-butter-fudge-puddles/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Melt the chopped chocolate and oil together in a double boiler or use the microwave. For the microwave, place the chocolate and oil in a large heat-proof bowl. Melt in 20-second increments, stirring after each increment until completely melted and smooth. Let slightly cool for 3 minutes. With a silicone spatula or a spoon, gently fold the mascarpone into the melted chocolate until combined.", "name": "Make the fudge filling", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/peanut-butter-fudge-puddles/#instruction-step-7"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Spoon a heaping teaspoon of the filling into each cooled cookie cup. Sprinkle with 1 cup of confectioners&#8217; sugar. Once the cake comes out of the oven, immediately invert it onto the parchment/towel. Peel off the parchment paper that was on the bottom of the cake as it baked. Starting with the narrow end, begin rolling the cake up with the parchment/towel. Do this slowly and gently. The cake will be warm. Allow the cake to cool completely rolled up in the parchment/towel. Give it a minute to slightly cool down, then whisk in the sugar and oil. Finally, whisk in the egg. Pour these wet ingredients into the flour mixture. Fold everything together with a silicone spatula or wooden spoon until combined\u2014or use a mixer on medium speed. (It&#8217;s a bit too heavy for a whisk.) As it softens, line a 9-inch 2.5 quart bowl (I recommend the one in this set) with plastic wrap with enough overhang to easily remove the ice cream as a whole once it\u2019s frozen.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/brownie-baked-alaska/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Scoop softened ice cream into another large bowl and using a handheld or stand mixer fitted with a paddle attachment, beat until creamy. Spread ice cream into prepared lined bowl. Cover with plastic wrap and freeze for 8 hours and up to 3 days. I freeze it overnight. The longer it&#8217;s frozen, the sturdier the cake and neater the slices.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/brownie-baked-alaska/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat oven to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C). (If it&#8217;s helpful, see this parchment paper rounds for cakes video &amp; post.)", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/brownie-baked-alaska/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Pour brownie batter into prepared cake pan and bake for 32-38 minutes or until a toothpick inserted in the center comes out mostly clean without any wet batter. (This chewy fudgy frosted brownies recipe is thick and could take a little longer in your oven.) Allow to cool completely in the pan. Once cool, run a knife around the brownie edges, then invert the pan to fully release the brownie as a whole.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/brownie-baked-alaska/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Remove bowl of ice cream from the freezer. (Make the meringue while you wait.)", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/brownie-baked-alaska/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Place egg whites, sugar, and cream of tartar in a heatproof bowl. Set bowl over a saucepan filled with two inches of simmering water. Do not let it touch the water. (You can use a double boiler if you have one.) Whisk constantly until sugar is dissolved, about 4 minutes. Transfer the mixing bowl to an electric mixer fitted with a whisk attachment. Add the vanilla. (FYI I forgot to add it in the video!) Beat on high speed for 5-6 minutes until stiff glossy peaks form.", "name": "Make the meringue", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/brownie-baked-alaska/#instruction-step-7"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "If using the oven in step 10, preheat oven to 450\u00b0F (232\u00b0C) now.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/brownie-baked-alaska/#instruction-step-8"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Remove ice cream/brownie from the freezer. If using the oven, invert onto a baking sheet lined with aluminum foil.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/brownie-baked-alaska/#instruction-step-9"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Spread meringue all over the ice cream, completely enclosing it. It's dangerously good! No candy thermometer, no stove, just a few simple steps to make this decadent fudge.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "peanut butter fudge", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/10/The-BEST-Peanut-Butter-Fudge-4-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/10/The-BEST-Peanut-Butter-Fudge-4-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/10/The-BEST-Peanut-Butter-Fudge-4-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/10/The-BEST-Peanut-Butter-Fudge-4.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/peanut-butter-fudge/", "recipeIngredient": ["1 cup (250g) creamy peanut butter*", "1 cup (2 sticks or 230g) unsalted butter", "1 teaspoon pure vanilla extract", "4 cups (460g) sifted confectioners&#8217; sugar*", "optional: 1/4 teaspoon salt", "optional: 3/4 cup add-ins, such as chocolate chips, peanuts, or Reese&#8217;s Peanut Butter Cups"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Line an 8-inch or 9-inch square baking pan with aluminum foil, leaving an overhang on the sides to lift the finished fudge out.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/peanut-butter-fudge/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Melt the peanut butter and butter together in a large bowl. I prefer to slice the butter to make melting easier. Stop the microwave and stir the mixture every minute until completely melted and smooth. Remove from the microwave and stir in the vanilla using a large silicone spatula or wooden spoon. Add the salt if you prefer a salty/sweet fudge. Add the sifted confectioners&#8217; sugar and stir until completely combined. The mixture is very, very thick and resembles cookie dough. Add the granulated sugar and brown sugar and beat on medium high speed until fluffy and light in color. Beat in the vanilla on high speed. Scrape down the sides and bottom of the bowl as needed.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/butterscotch-toffee-chocolate-fudge-cookies/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "On low speed, slowly mix the dry ingredients into\u00a0the wet ingredients until combined. The cookie dough will be thick. Switch to high speed and beat in the milk, then the butterscotch and toffee. The cookie dough will be sticky. Cover dough tightly with aluminum foil or plastic wrap and chill for at least 3 hours and up to 3 days. Chilling is mandatory for this cookie dough. My oven has hot spots and yours may too, so be sure to rotate the pan once during bake time. The baked cookies will look extremely soft in the centers when you remove them from the oven. Allow to cool for 5 minutes on the cookie sheet. During this time, you can press a few more butterscotch morsels into the top of the warm cookies\u2014this is just for looks. Set aside. Using a handheld or stand mixer fitted with a paddle or whisk attachment beat the butter, brown sugar, and granulated sugar together until creamed, about 2 minutes. Add the eggs, sour cream, and vanilla and beat on medium speed until combined. Scrape down the sides and bottom of the bowl as needed. The mixture will look curdled; that&#8217;s ok\u2014it will come together when you add the dry ingredients.", "name": "For the cake", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chai-cinnamon-swirl-bundt-cake/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Pour the dry ingredients into the wet ingredients, add the milk, and beat on medium speed it all until the batter is completely combined. Set aside.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/confetti-cupcakes/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Whisk the cake flour, baking powder, baking soda, and salt together. Set aside.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/confetti-cupcakes/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Using a handheld or stand mixer fitted with a paddle attachment, beat the butter and sugar together on high speed until smooth and creamy, about 2 minutes. Scrape down the sides and up the bottom of the bowl with a rubber spatula as needed. Add the egg whites and vanilla extract. Beat on medium-high speed until combined, then beat in the sour cream. Scrape down the sides and up the bottom of the bowl as needed. With the mixer on low speed, add the dry ingredients until just incorporated. With the mixer still running on low, slowly pour in the milk until combined. Do not over-mix. Gently and slowly whisk in the sprinkles. The batter will be slightly thick.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/confetti-cupcakes/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Pour/spoon the batter into the liners. Cover and allow to rest for 5 minutes.\u00a0*If you don\u2019t have a stand mixer, simply use a large mixing bowl and mix the dough with a wooden spoon or silicone spatula in the next step.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-ham-cheese-pockets/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Add the olive oil, salt, and flour. Beat on low speed for 2 minutes until combined.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-ham-cheese-pockets/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Keep the dough in the mixer and beat for an additional 5 full minutes, or knead by hand on a lightly floured surface for 5 full minutes. (If you\u2019re new to bread-baking, my How to Knead Dough video tutorial can help here.) If the dough becomes too sticky during the kneading process, sprinkle 1 teaspoon of flour at a time on the dough or on the work surface/in the bowl to make a soft, slightly tacky dough. Do not add more flour than you need because you do not want a dry dough. After kneading, the dough should still feel a little soft. Poke it with your finger\u2014if it slowly bounces back, your dough is ready to rise. You can also do a \u201cwindowpane test\u201d to see if your dough has been kneaded long enough: tear off a small (roughly golfball-size) piece of dough and gently stretch it out until it\u2019s thin enough for light to pass through it. Hold it up to a window or light. Does light pass through the stretched dough without the dough tearing first? If so, your dough has been kneaded long enough and is ready to rise. If not, keep kneading until it passes the windowpane test.", "name": "Knead the dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-ham-cheese-pockets/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Lightly grease a large bowl with oil or nonstick spray\u2014just use the same bowl you used for the dough. Place the dough in the bowl, turning it to coat all sides in the oil. Cover the bowl with aluminum foil, plastic wrap, or a clean kitchen towel. Allow the dough to rise at room temperature for 60-90 minutes or until double in size. (Tip: For the warm environment on a particularly cold day, heat your oven to 150\u00b0F (66\u00b0C). Turn the oven off, place the dough inside, and keep the door slightly ajar. This will be a warm environment for your dough to rise. After about 30 minutes, close the oven door to trap the air inside with the rising dough. When it&#8217;s doubled in size, remove from the oven.)", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-ham-cheese-pockets/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat oven to 400\u00b0F (204\u00b0C). Line 2 large baking sheets with parchment paper or silicone baking mats.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-ham-cheese-pockets/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Once risen, punch the dough down to release the air. Turn the dough out onto a lightly floured surface. Using a sharp knife, slice dough in half. Then slice each half into quarters. You&#8217;ll have 8 pieces of dough, as shown in the photo above. Flatten each piece with your fingers or use a rolling pin. You want each piece of flattened dough to be about 6 inches long and 4 inches wide. They don&#8217;t have to be perfect rectangles, as you can see in my photos! Transfer flattened dough to the baking sheets. Place the cheese (I fold the slice in half) and ham (2 slices for each) on top of the dough on one side, then fold the other side over top. Pinch the edges to seal as best you can. Use a fork to crimp the edges.\u00a0Brush the tops and sides of each pocket with egg wash, then slice 2-3 slits in the tops for air vents (use a super sharp knife to do that).", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-ham-cheese-pockets/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake the pockets for 20-25\u00a0minutes, or until the tops are golden brown. Pour dry ingredients into the wet ingredients, then beat on low speed until combined. The cookie dough will be slightly thick. On low speed, beat in the chocolate chips. Cover dough tightly with aluminum foil or plastic wrap and chill for at least 1 hour and up to 2 days. Chilling is mandatory for this cookie dough.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/smores-chocolate-chip-cookies/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Remove cookie dough from the refrigerator and allow to sit at room temperature for 10 minutes. (I like to use this medium cookie scoop.)", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/smores-chocolate-chip-cookies/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake for 10-11 minutes, until barely golden brown around the edges. Return to the oven for only 1-2 minutes or until the broil setting lightly toasts the marshmallow. Using the back of a spoon, press the marshmallow down if it didn&#8217;t melt down on its own. (Sometimes it holds its taller shape, but gently pressing down flattens it out.)", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/smores-chocolate-chip-cookies/#instruction-step-8"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "You can melt the chocolate in a double boiler or the microwave. I'm taking a double batch to a party this afternoon.  First couple times I used mini marshmallows because that's what I had (4 per cookie),  and this time I used regular marshmallows cut in half per the recipe.   I actually prefer the minis now that I've compared, because whereas the half medium stands taller in the middle of the cookie,  the minis aren't as tall and they're spaced a little apart so they cover more of the cookie surface.  Provides more toasted surface and less gooey marshmallow middle, which I prefer.  I also found that even though some of the marshmallows got toasted more than I wanted, it wasn't noticeable in the finished product.   And on a few where the marshmallows got way too toasted, I plucked them off, replaced and broiled again without over baking the cookies  - couldn't tell the difference.  Such a great recipe!!  Thank you, Sally, from my family and friends,  and this happy baker!"}, {"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Marcia"}, "datePublished": "2023-07-04", "reviewBody": "Took these to a picnic. Instead of broiling them, since I had them on parchment, I put the marshmallows on when the cookies had about three minutes left to bake. Then when they were soft and the cookies were ready, I used a baking torch to toast the marshmallows. Add the egg and beat on high until combined, about 1 minute. Scrape down the sides and bottom of the bowl as needed. Add the vanilla and molasses and beat on high until combined. Set aside.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/loaded-oatmeal-cookies/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a separate bowl, whisk the oats, flour, cinnamon, baking soda, and salt together. See video above for a closer look at the texture. Dough will be sticky. If it&#8217;s too sticky, add a little more flour. If it seems too dry, add 1-2 more Tablespoons heavy cream. Press into an 8-inch disc and, with a sharp knife or bench scraper, cut into 8 wedges. For smaller scones, press dough into two 5-inch discs and cut each into 8 wedges. To make 10-12 drop scones: Keep mixing dough in the bowl until it comes together. Drop scones, about 1/4 cup of dough each, 3 inches apart on a lined baking sheet. Moving forward I will just continue with the Triple Chocolate scone recipe as written.\r\nIf Sally has any suggestions for a Red Velvet Scone, I would love the input.  Her scone recipes are always spot on and a favorite in my family.  I make them very often.  Thank you."}, {"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Crystal"}, "datePublished": "2025-12-09", "reviewBody": "This is the best scone recipe I have tried! For the best results, use either water bath method described in the recipe and notes below.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "cheesecake, key lime pie, lime", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/key-lime-pie-cheesecake-2-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/key-lime-pie-cheesecake-2-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/key-lime-pie-cheesecake-2-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/key-lime-pie-cheesecake-2.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/key-lime-cheesecake/", "recipeIngredient": ["1 and 1/2 cups (180g)\u00a0graham cracker crumbs (about\u00a012\u00a0full sheet graham crackers)", "5 Tablespoons (71g) unsalted butter, melted", "1/4 cup\u00a0(50g)\u00a0granulated sugar", "32 ounces (904g) full-fat brick PHILADELPHIA Cream Cheese, softened to room temperature", "1 cup + 2 Tablespoons (225g) granulated sugar", "1/2 cup (120ml) key lime juice*", "1/3 cup (80g) sour cream or plain yogurt, at room temperature", "1 teaspoon pure vanilla extract", "2 teaspoons key lime zest*", "3 large eggs, at room temperature", "homemade whipped cream", "fresh berries", "key lime or regular lime slices"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Adjust the oven rack to the center position, with a lower oven rack in place for the water bath described in step 5, and preheat oven to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C).", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/key-lime-cheesecake/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "If your graham crackers aren&#8217;t crumbs yet, use a food processor to pulse them into fine crumbs. Pour crumbs into a medium bowl and stir in sugar and melted butter until combined. Mixture will be sandy. Press firmly into the bottom and slightly up the sides of a 9-inch springform pan. No need to grease the pan first. I use the bottom of a measuring cup to pack the crust down tightly. Pre-bake for 10 minutes. Remove from the oven and allow crust to slightly cool as you prepare the filling.", "name": "Make the crust", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/key-lime-cheesecake/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Using a handheld or stand mixer fitted with a paddle attachment, beat the cream cheese and granulated sugar together on medium-high speed in a large bowl until the mixture is smooth and creamy, about 2 minutes. Add the lime juice, sour cream, vanilla extract, and lime zest then beat on medium-high speed until fully combined. On medium speed, add the eggs one at a time, beating after each addition until just blended. After the final egg is incorporated into the batter, stop mixing. To help prevent the cheesecake from deflating and cracking as it cools, avoid over-mixing the batter as best you can.", "name": "Make the filling:\u00a0", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/key-lime-cheesecake/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Pour cheesecake batter into warm crust. Use a rubber spatula or spoon to smooth it into an even layer.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/key-lime-cheesecake/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Boil a kettle or pot of water. You need 1 inch of water in your roasting pan for the water bath, so make sure you boil enough. Place a large metal baking or roasting pan (I usually use a 9&#215;13-inch baking pan\u2014do not use glass) on the bottom rack of the preheated oven. Pour boiling water into pan, about 1 inch deep. Immediately place the cheesecake on the center rack. Close oven to trap the steam inside. This unique water bath adds steam to the oven without having the cheesecake sit inside the water itself, which is the traditional water bath method explained in the recipe Notes. \u00a0See\u00a0How to Make a Cheesecake Water Bath\u00a0for more information.", "name": "Prepare the simple water bath (see recipe note for traditional water bath method)", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/key-lime-cheesecake/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "(Note: if you notice the cheesecake browning too quickly on top, tent it with aluminum foil halfway through baking.) Bake cheesecake for 55\u201370 minutes or until the center is almost set. When it&#8217;s done, the center of the cheesecake will slightly wobble if you gently tap the pan. Turn the oven off and open the oven door slightly. Let the cheesecake sit in the oven as it cools down for 1 hour. Remove from the oven, then cool cheesecake completely at room temperature. Then refrigerate the cheesecake for at least 4 hours or overnight.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/key-lime-cheesecake/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Use a knife to loosen the chilled cheesecake from the rim of the springform pan, then remove the rim. Add optional toppings if desired. I used a piping tip for the pictured whipped cream. Using a clean sharp knife, cut into slices for serving. For neat slices, wipe the knife clean and dip into warm water between each slice.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/key-lime-cheesecake/#instruction-step-7"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cover and store leftover cheesecake in the refrigerator for up to 5 days.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/key-lime-cheesecake/#instruction-step-8"}], "prepTime": "PT45M", "cookTime": "PT1H", "totalTime": "PT7H45M", "recipeYield": ["16", "serves 16"], "recipeCategory": "Dessert", "cookingMethod": "Baking", "recipeCuisine": "American", "aggregateRating": {"@type": "AggregateRating", "reviewCount": "35", "ratingValue": "4.7"}, "video": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "VideoObject", "name": "Key Lime Cheesecake | Sally's Baking Recipes", "description": "Combining the refreshing flavor of key lime pie and the irresistible creaminess of classic cheesecake, this key lime cheesecake is two mouthwatering desserts in one. 113g) unsalted butter", "1 cup (200g) packed light or dark brown sugar", "\u00a03 large egg yolks", "1 can (12 ounces; 354ml) evaporated milk", "1 teaspoon pure vanilla extract", "2 cups sweetened shredded coconut", "1 cup (125g) chopped pecans", "use this chocolate buttercream for a naked-style cake", "use this chocolate buttercream for frosting the top and sides", "optional for garnish: extra toasted pecans and sweetened shredded coconut"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat oven to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C). (If it&#8217;s helpful, see this parchment paper rounds for cakes video &amp; post.)", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/german-chocolate-cake/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Whisk the flour, cocoa powder, sugar, baking soda, baking powder, salt, and espresso powder (if using)\u00a0together in a large bowl. Set aside. Using a handheld or stand mixer fitted with a whisk attachment (or you can use a whisk) mix the oil, eggs, sour cream, buttermilk, and vanilla together until combined. Pour the wet ingredients into the dry ingredients, add the hot water or coffee, and whisk or beat it all until the batter is completely combined.", "name": "Make the cake:\u00a0", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/german-chocolate-cake/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Divide batter evenly between 3 pans. Combine butter, brown sugar, egg yolks, and evaporated milk in a medium saucepan over medium heat. Whisk occasionally as the mixture comes to a low boil. Once boiling, whisk constantly until the mixture thickens, about 5 minutes.\u00a0Remove from heat and stir in vanilla, toasted pecans, and coconut. Allow to cool completely before layering in cake. It will thicken even more as it cools.", "name": "As the cakes cool, prepare the coconut pecan filling", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/german-chocolate-cake/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "First, level\u00a0the cakes if needed: using a large serrated knife,\u00a0slice\u00a0a thin layer off the tops of the cakes\u00a0to create a flat surface. Discard (or crumble over ice cream!).\u00a0Place 1 cake layer on your cake stand, cake turntable, or serving plate. Evenly cover the top with 1/2 of the coconut pecan filling (half is about 1 and 1/4 cups). Top with 2nd layer and evenly cover the top with remaining coconut pecan filling. Top with the third cake layer. Spread the chocolate buttercream into a thick layer on top. Garnish with extra toasted pecans and coconut, if desired. Both batches came out great the day I baked them. I covered both batches with aluminum foil and left at room temperature and by the next day they sugar on top seamed to have absorbed and they lost their crunchy top. I baked them at 425 for 5 minutes and then 25 minutes at 350 and the toothpick was clean when I tested them. Any tips/ suggestions for why that happened and how to prevent it next time?"}, {"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Emily P"}, "datePublished": "2025-06-11", "reviewBody": "Hi Lexi,\r\n\r\nWanted to follow up on this. Set aside.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/pistachio-cake/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Using a handheld or stand mixer fitted with a paddle or whisk attachment, beat the butter and sugar together on high speed until smooth and creamy, about 3 minutes. Scrape down the sides and bottom of the bowl with a rubber spatula as needed. Beat in the egg whites on high speed until combined, about 2 minutes. Beat in the sour cream, vanilla extract, and almond extract. Scrape down the sides and bottom of the bowl as needed. Add the dry ingredients, then start the mixer on low speed. With the mixer running, slowly pour in the milk (and the green food coloring, if using) and mix just until combined. You may need to whisk it all by hand to make sure there are no lumps at the bottom of the bowl. The batter will be slightly thick.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/pistachio-cake/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Divide batter evenly among the prepared cake pans. Allow cakes to cool completely in the pans set on a wire rack. The cakes must be completely cool before frosting and assembling.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/pistachio-cake/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a large bowl using a handheld or stand mixer fitted with a whisk or paddle attachment, beat the cream cheese and butter together on medium-high speed until smooth, about 2 minutes. Add the confectioners\u2019 sugar, vanilla extract, and a pinch of salt. Beat on low speed for 30 seconds, then increase to high speed and beat for 3 minutes until completely combined and creamy. Add more confectioners\u2019 sugar if frosting is too thin, a little milk if frosting is too thick, or an extra pinch of salt if frosting is too sweet. Frosting should be soft, but not runny.", "name": "Make the frosting:\u00a0", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/pistachio-cake/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "First, using a large serrated knife or cake leveler, layer off the tops of the cakes to create a flat surface. Avoid soft, mealy, and mushy apples. For depth of flavor, it's best to bake with a mix of tart and sweet apples. Use tart Granny Smith, Braeburn, Jonathan, or Pacific Rose. And use sweet\u00a0Jazz, Honeycrisp, Pink Lady, or Fuji. I found that the apple filling dried out a bit after freezing and thawing, and the cake-like topping is a bit wet. If you want to try it, however, freeze baked and cooled cobbler for up to 3 months. Thaw in the refrigerator and see reheating instructions below.", "inLanguage": "en-US"}, "inLanguage": "en-US"}, {"@type": "Question", "@id": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/apple-cobbler/#faq-question-1725311046423", "position": 4, "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/apple-cobbler/#faq-question-1725311046423", "name": "Can I halve this apple cobbler recipe?", "answerCount": 1, "acceptedAnswer": {"@type": "Answer", "text": "Yes. Sprinkle cinnamon-sugar evenly over the top. Use a butter knife to gently swirl the topping as best you can (the apples get in the way a bit, and that&#8217;s fine).", "name": "Make the topping", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/apple-cobbler/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake on the center rack for 48-55 minutes or until the topping is golden and the apple filling is bubbling around the edges. If you find the top of the cobbler is browning too quickly in the oven, loosely cover it with aluminum foil (I usually do this about halfway through baking). If the dough seems too soft and sticky for rolling, add 1 more Tablespoon of flour.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/football-cookies/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Divide the dough into 2 equal parts. Place each portion onto a piece of lightly floured parchment paper or a lightly floured silicone baking mat. With a lightly floured rolling pin, roll the dough out to about 1/4-inch thickness. Use more flour if the dough seems too sticky. The rolled-out dough can be any shape, as long as it is evenly 1/4-inch thick.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/football-cookies/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Lightly dust one of the rolled-out doughs with flour. Line 2-3 large baking sheets with parchment paper or silicone baking mats. Carefully remove the top dough piece from the refrigerator. If it&#8217;s sticking to the bottom, run your hand under it to help remove it\u2014see me do this in the video below. Using a football cookie cutter, cut the dough into shapes. Re-roll the remaining dough and continue cutting until all is used. Repeat with 2nd piece of dough. (Note: It doesn&#8217;t seem like a lot of dough, but you get a lot of cookies from the dough scraps you re-roll.)", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/football-cookies/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Arrange cookies on baking sheets 3 inches apart. Allow cookies to cool on the baking sheet for 5 minutes then transfer to a wire rack to cool completely before decorating.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/football-cookies/#instruction-step-7"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Prepare Royal Icing. Spoon 1/2 cup of the prepared icing into a separate bowl. This icing will remain white. (You won&#8217;t use the white icing for a couple hours after the base icing sets, so place a damp paper towel directly on the surface of it. This prevents it from hardening.) Tint the rest of the icing brown. I used 3 drops to get this shade of brown. Spoon or pour the brown icing into a piping bag (disposable or reusable) fitted with\u00a0Wilton piping tip #5 or piping tip #4. Decorate cookies with brown icing by piping a border around the edges and then filling it. Let the icing-covered cookies mostly set uncovered for about 2-3 hours before adding the white laces.", "name": "Decorate:\u00a0", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/football-cookies/#instruction-step-8"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Spoon or pour the white icing into a piping bag (disposable or reusable) fitted with piping tip #2\u00a0or\u00a0piping tip #3. Beat in the chopped pecans. The cookie dough may look like it won&#8217;t come together, but keep beating\u2014I promise, it will! The cookie dough will be thick.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/pecan-shortbread/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Turn the dough out onto a floured work surface and, with floured hands, divide or cut into two. Shape each half into an 8-inch log, about 2.5 inches in diameter. The measurements don&#8217;t have to be exact. Tightly wrap the logs in plastic wrap and chill in the refrigerator for at least 3-4 hours and up to 5 days. Chilling is mandatory for this cookie dough. I prefer to chill mine for 4 hours or even overnight\u2014the colder the dough, the thicker the cookies.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/pecan-shortbread/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat oven to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C). It's love at first bite!", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "heart donuts", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/party-donuts-sallys-baking-addiction-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/party-donuts-sallys-baking-addiction-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/party-donuts-sallys-baking-addiction-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/party-donuts-sallys-baking-addiction.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/pink-party-donuts/", "recipeIngredient": ["1 cup (125g) all-purpose flour\u00a0(spooned &amp; leveled)", "1 teaspoon baking powder", "1/4 teaspoon baking soda", "1/2 teaspoon salt", "1/2\u00a0teaspoon\u00a0ground cinnamon", "1/4 teaspoon ground nutmeg", "1 large egg, at room temperature", "1/3 cup (65g) packed light brown sugar", "1/2 cup (120ml) buttermilk, at room temperature*", "2 Tablespoons (28g) unsalted butter, melted", "1 and 1/2 teaspoons pure vanilla extract", "2 cups (240g) confectioners&#8217;\u00a0sugar", "3 Tablespoons (43g) unsalted butter, melted and slightly cooled", "3-4 Tablespoons (45-60ml) heavy cream", "1 teaspoon pure\u00a0vanilla extract", "pinch salt", "1-2 drops red food coloring", "for garnish: rainbow sprinkles*"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat oven to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C). Spray the donut pan (heart-shaped donut pan or regular donut pan) with non-stick spray. Set aside.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/pink-party-donuts/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Whisk the flour, baking powder, baking soda, salt, cinnamon, and nutmeg together in a medium bowl. Set aside. Whisk the egg, brown sugar, and buttermilk\u00a0together until smooth. Add the melted butter and vanilla, whisking until fully combined.\u00a0Pour the wet ingredients into the dry ingredients and mix until just combined. Do not overmix. The batter will be very thick.", "name": "Make\u00a0the donuts:\u00a0", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/pink-party-donuts/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Spoon the batter into the donut cavities\u2014I highly recommend using a large zipped-top bag for ease. Cut a corner off the bottom of the bag and pipe the batter into each donut cup, filling only 1/2 to 2/3 full. If baking hearts, do not fill up too much or the donuts won&#8217;t have a hole in the center (they&#8217;ll puff up too much).", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/pink-party-donuts/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake for 8-10 minutes or until the edges are lightly browned. Allow to cool in the pan for about two minutes then place each on a wire rack set on top of a baking sheet or parchment paper (to catch any sprinkles or glaze in step 5). Bake the remaining donut batter\u00a0(there is usually enough batter for 2-3 more donuts) and once baked, transfer to the wire rack. Allow donuts to cool down until you can handle them.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/pink-party-donuts/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "\u00a0In a medium bowl, whisk the glaze ingredients together until completely smooth. Add more cream to thin or more confectioners&#8217; sugar to thicken, if desired. I always add a little salt to offset the sweetness. Dip each donut into the glaze, then place back on the rack. Top with sprinkles. Donuts are best served immediately. Leftovers keep well covered tightly in the refrigerator for up to 3 days. If glazed lightly, the glaze will somewhat set after a few hours.", "name": "Make the glaze", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/pink-party-donuts/#instruction-step-5"}], "prepTime": "PT30M", "cookTime": "PT10M", "totalTime": "PT45M", "recipeYield": ["9", "9 donuts"], "recipeCategory": "Breakfast", "cookingMethod": "Baking", "recipeCuisine": "American", "aggregateRating": {"@type": "AggregateRating", "reviewCount": "12", "ratingValue": "4.7"}, "review": [{"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Mabel"}, "datePublished": "2021-10-29", "reviewBody": "Hi Sally,\r\n\r\nI tried out the glaze and it was delicious! This recipe is also in my New York Times best-selling cookbook, Sally's Baking 101.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "brown butter pumpkin oatmeal cookies", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/09/brown-butter-pumpkin-oatmeal-cookies-recipe-3-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/09/brown-butter-pumpkin-oatmeal-cookies-recipe-3-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/09/brown-butter-pumpkin-oatmeal-cookies-recipe-3-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/09/brown-butter-pumpkin-oatmeal-cookies-recipe-3.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/brown-butter-pumpkin-oatmeal-cookies/", "recipeIngredient": ["1 and 1/4 cups (285g) canned pumpkin puree*", "1 cup (16 Tbsp; 226g) unsalted butter, cut into 16 pieces", "2 cups (170g) old-fashioned whole rolled oats", "1 and 2/3 cups (208g) all-purpose flour\u00a0(spooned &amp; leveled)", "1 teaspoon baking soda", "1/2 teaspoon salt", "1 and 1/2 teaspoons ground cinnamon", "2 teaspoons store-bought or homemade pumpkin pie spice*", "1 cup (200g) granulated sugar", "2/3 cup (133g) packed light or dark brown sugar", "1 egg yolk, at room temperature", "2 teaspoons pure vanilla extract", "1/4 cup (4 Tbsp; 56g) unsalted butter, cut into 4 pieces", "1 and 1/2 cups (180g) confectioners&#8217; sugar", "3 Tablespoons (45ml) milk", "1/4 teaspoon pure vanilla extract", "optional for garnish: sprinkle of pumpkin pie spice"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Blot the pumpkin: Line a medium bowl with a double layer of paper towels. Place the pumpkin puree in the bowl. Using another paper towel, press down to blot excess moisture from the pumpkin. You may need to repeat a couple of times with new paper towels. After blotting, you will have about 1 cup (225g) of pumpkin. Set aside.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/brown-butter-pumpkin-oatmeal-cookies/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Brown the 16 Tablespoons of butter for the cookies together with the 4 Tablespoons for the glaze. Place all 20 pieces of butter in a light-colored skillet over medium heat. (Light-colored helps you determine when the butter begins browning.) Stir or whisk the butter constantly as it melts. Once melted, the butter will begin to foam. Keep stirring. After 5\u20138 minutes, the butter will begin browning\u2014you&#8217;ll notice lightly browned specks begin to form at the bottom of the pan and it will have a nutty aroma. As soon as the butter has browned, immediately remove from heat and pour it into a large heat-safe glass bowl or liquid measuring cup. Scrape up the browned solids at the bottom of the skillet and add them as well. Divide and set aside 2 Tbsp (28g) of the brown butter to use for the glaze in step 8. The rest of the brown butter will go in the cookie dough in step 5. Allow to slightly cool while you continue.", "name": "Brown the butter", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/brown-butter-pumpkin-oatmeal-cookies/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat the oven to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C). Line large baking sheets with parchment paper or silicone baking mats. Whisk in the egg yolk and vanilla extract until combined, then whisk in the blotted pumpkin. Slowly stir the dry ingredients into the wet ingredients until combined. The cookie dough will be soft and sticky.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/brown-butter-pumpkin-oatmeal-cookies/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Scoop the cookie dough, about 2 Tablespoons (45g) of dough each, and arrange them 3 inches apart on the prepared baking sheets.\u00a0", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/brown-butter-pumpkin-oatmeal-cookies/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake for 14\u201315 minutes or until the edges of the cookies are lightly browned and set. Cool the cookies on the baking sheet for 10 minutes before transferring to a cooling rack to cool completely.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/brown-butter-pumpkin-oatmeal-cookies/#instruction-step-7"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Give the brown butter you reserved for the glaze a quick stir. If it&#8217;s no longer thin and liquid, warm it on the stove or in the microwave. Whisk in the confectioners&#8217; sugar, milk, and vanilla extract until smooth. Lightly dip the top of each cookie into the glaze. Sprinkle a pinch of pumpkin pie spice on top of each glazed cookie, if desired. Return the cookies to the cooling rack and let sit until the glaze has set. Greek yogurt or sour cream keeps them extra moist, creamed butter creates a wonderfully soft texture, and fresh blackberries add a burst of fresh flavor. Drizzle each with sweet, tart lemon icing for a finishing touch.\u00a0", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "blackberry lemon poppy seed muffins", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/07/blackberry-lemon-poppy-seed-muffins-2-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/07/blackberry-lemon-poppy-seed-muffins-2-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/07/blackberry-lemon-poppy-seed-muffins-2-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/07/blackberry-lemon-poppy-seed-muffins-2.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/blackberry-lemon-poppy-seed-muffins/", "recipeIngredient": ["1 and 3/4 cups (219g) all-purpose flour\u00a0(spooned &amp; leveled)", "1 and 1/2 Tablespoons poppy seeds", "1 teaspoon baking soda", "1 teaspoon baking powder", "1/2 teaspoon salt", "1/2 cup (8 Tbsp; 113g) unsalted butter, softened to room temperature", "1/2 cup (100g) granulated sugar", "1/4 cup (50g) packed light or dark brown sugar", "2 large eggs, at room temperature", "1/2 cup (120g) sour cream or plain yogurt, at room temperature", "1 and 1/2 Tablespoons fresh lemon zest", "2 and 1/2 Tablespoons fresh lemon juice", "1 and 1/2 teaspoons pure vanilla extract", "1/4 cup (60ml) milk (any kind), at room temperature", "1 and 1/2 cups (250g) fresh or frozen blackberries (do not thaw if using frozen)", "1 cup (120g) confectioners&#8217; sugar, sifted", "1 and 1/2 Tablespoons (22ml) lemon juice", "1 Tablespoon (15ml) milk (any kind)"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat oven to\u00a0425\u00b0F (218\u00b0C).\u00a0Spray a 12-count muffin pan with nonstick spray or line with cupcake liners. Set aside.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/blackberry-lemon-poppy-seed-muffins/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "\u00a0In a large bowl, toss the flour, poppy seeds, baking soda, baking powder, and salt together. Set aside.", "name": "Make the muffins", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/blackberry-lemon-poppy-seed-muffins/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a large bowl using a handheld or stand mixer fitted with a paddle attachment, beat the butter, sugar, and brown sugar together on high speed until smooth and creamy, about 2 minutes. Scrape down the sides and bottom of the bowl as needed. Add the eggs, sour cream, vanilla extract, lemon zest, and lemon juice. Beat on medium speed for 1 minute, then turn up to high speed and beat until combined. Scrape down the sides and bottom of the bowl as needed. Mixture may look a little chunky and curded; that&#8217;s ok.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/blackberry-lemon-poppy-seed-muffins/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "With the mixer running on low speed, add the dry ingredients and milk into the wet ingredients and beat until no flour pockets remain. Gently fold into the blackberries; they may bleed a little color and that&#8217;s ok.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/blackberry-lemon-poppy-seed-muffins/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Spoon the batter evenly into each cup or liner, filling each all the way to the top. Bake the muffins for 5 minutes at 425\u00b0F (218\u00b0C), then, keeping the muffins in the oven, reduce the oven temperature to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C). Bake for an additional 15\u201318 minutes or until a toothpick inserted in the center comes out clean. The total time these muffins take in the oven is about 22\u201323 minutes, give or take. Allow the muffins to cool for 5 minutes in the muffin pan, then transfer to a wire rack to continue cooling.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/blackberry-lemon-poppy-seed-muffins/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Whisk all of the icing ingredients together and drizzle over warm or cooled muffins.", "name": "Make the icing", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/blackberry-lemon-poppy-seed-muffins/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cover and store leftover muffins for up to 3 days at room temperature or up to 1 week in the refrigerator.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/blackberry-lemon-poppy-seed-muffins/#instruction-step-7"}], "prepTime": "PT15M", "cookTime": "PT22M", "totalTime": "PT40M", "recipeYield": ["12", "12 muffins"], "recipeCategory": "Muffins", "cookingMethod": "Baking", "recipeCuisine": "American", "aggregateRating": {"@type": "AggregateRating", "reviewCount": "45", "ratingValue": "4.8"}, "review": [{"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "4"}, "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Jane Doe"}, "datePublished": "2024-02-14", "reviewBody": "Delicious muffins, but do not rise up tall as I had hoped. I followed the instructions to a T, and heres my thoughts:\r\n\r\n- The comments about it sticking to the cupcake liners are 100% true, and it's pretty bad. I loose most of my muffin to the liner and have to spend a few minutes pulling it off with my nails first. It comes off in streaks, leaving behind some paper scraps. \r\n- The comments about the icing are also very true -- it's incredibly sweet. Honestly, I find the sweetness level complimentary to the muffin, but the texture is *awful*. Using maple syrup makes it a sticky disaster, and I end up having to wash my hands after wrestling the liner off and after eating it. If you don't like sticky hands, 100% switch out the icing for a cinnamon roll glaze or something similar\r\n- And last but not least -- they're honestly quite bland. Like, they're fluffy and the crumb cake portion has a great texture, but the muffin itself is very plain. \r\n\r\nHonestly, I think these are fine as is. They're not stand-out, but they're not awful. With my complaints in mind I would personally make these changes if I were to make them again:\r\n- Double the spices. Absolutely needed to make it less bland\r\n- Switch the icing for a cinnamon roll glaze, or anything remotely similar, just don't use maple syrup. \r\n- I think part of why they stick to the liners is an over-abundance of moisture, so I would either squeeze some of the moisture out of the pumpkin puree first (not all, but some), or add more flour. \r\n\r\nNot the best, but not the worst."}, {"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sonia"}, "datePublished": "2025-11-09", "reviewBody": "Delicious muffin!
