Dunk in espresso-speckled white chocolate and top with a sprinkle of spice for a creamy gingerbread latte experience... in a cookie!", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "gingerbread latte cookies", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/gingerbread-latte-cookies-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/gingerbread-latte-cookies-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/gingerbread-latte-cookies-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/gingerbread-latte-cookies.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/gingerbread-latte-cookies/", "recipeIngredient": ["2 cups\u00a0(170g) old-fashioned whole rolled\u00a0oats", "1 and 2/3 cups (210g) all-purpose flour (spooned &amp; leveled)", "2 teaspoons espresso powder", "1 teaspoon baking soda", "1/4 teaspoon salt", "1 teaspoon ground ginger", "1 teaspoon ground cinnamon", "1/4 teaspoon ground nutmeg", "1/8 teaspoon ground cloves", "3/4 cup (12 Tbsp; 170g)\u00a0unsalted butter, softened to room temperature", "1 cup\u00a0(200g) packed light or dark\u00a0brown sugar", "1/4 cup (50g) granulated sugar", "1 large egg,\u00a0at room temperature", "1/4 cup (60ml/75g) unsulphured or dark molasses (do not use blackstrap; I prefer Grandma&#8217;s brand)", "8 ounces (226g) white chocolate, chopped", "1 teaspoon vegetable oil or coconut oil (optional; helps to thin the chocolate)", "1/2 teaspoon espresso powder", "pinch each of cinnamon and nutmeg, for sprinkling on top"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "\u00a0Pulse the oats in a\u00a0food processor 10\u201312 times until you have a variety of texture\u2014chopped oats with some oat flour. See photo above for a visual.", "name": "Make the cookies", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/gingerbread-latte-cookies/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Whisk the pulsed oats, flour, espresso powder, baking soda, salt, ginger, cinnamon, nutmeg, and cloves together in a medium bowl. Set aside.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/gingerbread-latte-cookies/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a large bowl using a hand mixer or a stand mixer fitted with a paddle attachment, beat the butter, brown sugar, and granulated sugar together on medium-high speed until creamed, about 3 minutes. (Here\u2019s a helpful tutorial if you need guidance on\u00a0how to cream butter and sugar.) Add the egg and molasses and beat on high speed until combined, about 1 minute. Scrape down the sides of the bowl and beat again as needed to combine.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/gingerbread-latte-cookies/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Add the dry ingredients to the wet ingredients and mix on low speed until combined. Dough will be very thick and sticky. Cover and chill the dough for 30\u201345 minutes (and up to 3 days) in the refrigerator. If chilling for longer than a few hours, allow to sit at room temperature for at least 30 minutes before scooping because the dough will be quite hard.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/gingerbread-latte-cookies/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat oven to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C). Bake for 12\u201313 minutes or until lightly browned on the sides. The centers will look very soft.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/gingerbread-latte-cookies/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Remove from the oven and allow cookies to cool on the baking sheet for 10 minutes, then transfer to a cooling rack to cool completely before dipping.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/gingerbread-latte-cookies/#instruction-step-7"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Melt the chopped white chocolate, oil, and espresso powder in a double boiler or use the microwave. For the microwave, place it all in a medium heat-proof bowl or liquid measuring cup. Melt in 20-second increments, stirring after each increment until completely melted and smooth. Dip each completely cooled cookie halfway into the white chocolate and place onto a parchment- or silicone baking mat-lined baking sheet or cooling rack. In a small bowl, mix together cinnamon and nutmeg. Using your fingers, lightly sprinkle a tiny pinch of the spice mix on top of the white chocolate-covered part of the cookie. Repeat with the remaining cookies. Place the baking sheet in the refrigerator to set the white chocolate, about 30 minutes.", "name": "Make the topping", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/gingerbread-latte-cookies/#instruction-step-8"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cookies stay fresh covered at room temperature for 3 days, or in the refrigerator for up to 1 week.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/gingerbread-latte-cookies/#instruction-step-9"}], "prepTime": "PT45M", "cookTime": "PT13M", "totalTime": "PT1H30M", "recipeYield": ["30", "30 cookies"], "recipeCategory": "Cookies", "cookingMethod": "Baking", "recipeCuisine": "American", "aggregateRating": {"@type": "AggregateRating", "reviewCount": "35", "ratingValue": "4.6"}, "review": [{"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "4"}, "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Stacey"}, "datePublished": "2024-12-21", "reviewBody": "Tasty! This recipe is also in my cookbook, Sally's Baking 101.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "caramel, salted caramel", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/11/salted-caramel_-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/11/salted-caramel_-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/11/salted-caramel_-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/11/salted-caramel_-scaled.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-salted-caramel-recipe/", "recipeIngredient": ["1 cup (200g) granulated sugar (make sure it&#8217;s labeled &#8220;pure cane&#8221;)*", "6 Tablespoons (85g) unsalted butter, at room temperature and cut into 6 pieces", "1/2 cup (120g/ml) heavy cream, at room temperature", "1 teaspoon salt"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a medium heavy-duty stainless steel saucepan (do not use nonstick) over medium heat, cook the sugar, stirring constantly with a wooden spoon or heat-safe silicone spatula. Sugar will form clumps and eventually melt into a thick brown, amber-colored liquid as you continue to stir. On my stove, this takes about 6 minutes. Stir constantly, especially around the bottom edges, and be careful not to let it burn.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-salted-caramel-recipe/#instruction-step-1", "image": {"@type": "ImageObject", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/03/cooking-salted-caramel.jpg", "height": "897", "width": "1200"}}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Once the sugar is completely melted, reduce the heat to low and stir in the butter. Be careful in this step because the caramel will bubble rapidly when the butter is added. (If you&#8217;re nervous for splatter, wear kitchen gloves.) Cook and stir constantly until the butter is melted and well combined. If you notice the butter separating or if the sugar clumps up, remove the pan from heat and vigorously whisk to combine it again. Keep whisking until it comes back together, even if it takes 3\u20134 minutes. It will eventually\u2014just keep whisking. Return to heat when it&#8217;s combined again.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-salted-caramel-recipe/#instruction-step-2", "image": {"@type": "ImageObject", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/03/cooking-salted-caramel-2.jpg", "height": "893", "width": "1200"}}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Very slowly and carefully pour in the heavy cream, stirring constantly. Since the heavy cream is colder than the hot caramel, the mixture will rapidly bubble and steam when added. When all of the heavy cream has been added, stop stirring, increase the heat to medium, and let it boil for 1 minute. It will rise in the pan as it boils. If you&#8217;d like to be precise and use a candy thermometer, the temperature should reach 220\u00b0F (104\u00b0C).", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-salted-caramel-recipe/#instruction-step-3", "image": {"@type": "ImageObject", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/03/cooking-salted-caramel-3.jpg", "height": "895", "width": "1200"}}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Remove from heat and stir in the salt. The caramel will be a thin liquid at this point. Allow to slightly cool and thicken before using. Caramel thickens considerably as it cools.\n\u00a0", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-salted-caramel-recipe/#instruction-step-4", "image": {"@type": "ImageObject", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/03/smooth-caramel-sauce-on-stove.jpg", "height": "899", "width": "1200"}}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cover tightly and store in the refrigerator for up to 1 month. Caramel solidifies in the refrigerator. Sally\u2019s work has been featured on TODAY, Good Morning America, Taste of Home, People, and more.", "sameAs": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"]}, {"@context": "https://schema.org/", "@type": "Recipe", "name": "Honey Roasted Peanut Butter Granola", "description": "If you like peanut butter and honey, this easy homemade granola is for you.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "honey roasted peanut butter granola, peanut butter granola", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/Honey-Roasted-Peanut-Butter-Trail-Mix-Granola-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/Honey-Roasted-Peanut-Butter-Trail-Mix-Granola-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/Honey-Roasted-Peanut-Butter-Trail-Mix-Granola-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/Honey-Roasted-Peanut-Butter-Trail-Mix-Granola.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/honey-roasted-peanut-butter-granola/", "recipeIngredient": ["1/4 cup (56g) coconut oil*", "1/3 cup (113g) honey", "1/2 cup (125g) honey roasted peanut butter*", "1 teaspoon pure vanilla extract", "3 cups (255g) old-fashioned whole rolled oats*", "1 cup (140g) honey roasted peanuts", "1/2 teaspoon ground cinnamon", "optional: 1/2 cup (90g) peanut butter chips", "optional: 1/2 cup (100g) mini or regular size M&amp;Ms"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat oven to 300\u00b0F (149\u00b0C) degrees. Line one large baking sheet with parchment paper or a silicone baking mat.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/honey-roasted-peanut-butter-granola/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a large heat-proof bowl, microwave the coconut oil and honey together for about 30 seconds. Alternatively, you may melt these ingredients together in a small pan on the stovetop. Remove from the microwave and using a fork or silicone spatula, stir until they are melted together and smooth. You may need to microwave it for 10 more seconds or so. Stir in the peanut butter and vanilla until smooth. Add the oats, peanuts, and cinnamon. Toss the mixture to coat everything. Make sure all of the oats are moistened.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/honey-roasted-peanut-butter-granola/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Spread onto the prepared baking sheet (it usually always fits onto just one\u2014if too crowded, use two baking sheets and bake at the same time on different racks) and bake for 35 minutes, stirring every 10 minutes or so. Remove from the oven and allow the granola to cool for 10 minutes, then sprinkle the peanut butter chips and M&amp;Ms on top. Stir everything together gently on the baking sheet. Set aside.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/whole-wheat-banana-bread/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "You can use an electric mixer or mix everything by hand. I like to use an electric mixer because I use it to mash the bananas. Using a handheld or stand mixer fitted with a paddle or whisk attachment on medium-high speed, beat the mashed bananas, applesauce, and eggs together until combined. (Or whisk by hand.) Add the honey, brown sugar, milk, and vanilla extract. Beat on medium-high speed (or whisk) until combined. Set aside.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/whole-wheat-banana-bread/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Whisk the flour, baking soda, cinnamon, and salt together. Fold in the walnuts.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/whole-wheat-banana-bread/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Pour the batter into the prepared loaf pan. Bake for 60-65 minutes, making sure to loosely cover the bread with aluminum foil halfway through to prevent the top from getting too brown. The bread is done when a toothpick inserted in the center comes out clean with only a few small moist crumbs. This may be before or after 60-65 minutes depending on your oven, so begin checking every 5 minutes at the 55 minute mark or so.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/whole-wheat-banana-bread/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Remove from the oven and allow the bread to cool completely in the pan set on a wire rack before slicing and serving.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/whole-wheat-banana-bread/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cover and store banana bread at room temperature for 2 days or in the refrigerator for up to 1 week. Set aside.", "name": "Make the cake", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/raspberry-swirl-pound-cake/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "With a handheld or stand mixer fitted with a paddle or whisk attachment, beat the butter and sugar together on high speed until creamy, about 1 minute. Scrape down the sides and up the bottom of the bowl as needed. With the mixer running on low speed, add the eggs one at a time, then add the sour cream, vanilla and almond extracts. Beat on medium-high speed until combined.\u00a0Scrape down the sides and up the bottom of the bowl as needed.\u00a0With the mixer running on low speed, slowly add the dry ingredients. Beat everything just until incorporated. Do not overmix.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/raspberry-swirl-pound-cake/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Spoon 1/2 cup of batter into a smaller bowl. Stir in raspberry jam.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/raspberry-swirl-pound-cake/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Spoon most (about 2/3) of the plain batter into the\u00a0prepared loaf pan, followed by all of the raspberry batter. Then spread the remaining plain batter on top as best you can. Using a knife, swirl the layers together. Bake for 55 minutes to 1 hour, 10 minutes. (I like to loosely cover the loaf with aluminum foil halfway through to prevent heavy browning on top.) Pound cakes are dense and, therefore, take awhile in the oven. Baking times vary so keep an eye on yours. The cake is done when a toothpick inserted in the center comes out *mostly* clean with zero raw batter. Remove the cake from the oven and set on a wire rack. They're almost double the size of your typical and covered with cream cheese frosting!", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "giant cinnamon rolls", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/08/big-cinnabon-style-cinnamon-rolls-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/08/big-cinnabon-style-cinnamon-rolls-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/08/big-cinnabon-style-cinnamon-rolls-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/08/big-cinnabon-style-cinnamon-rolls.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/big-giant-cinnamon-rolls/", "recipeIngredient": ["1 cup (240ml) buttermilk*, warmed to about 100\u00b0F (38\u00b0C)", "2/3 cup (135g) granulated sugar, divided", "1 and 1/2 tablespoons (14g) active dry\u00a0yeast\u00a0(2 standard size packets)", "1/2 cup (8 Tbsp; 113g) unsalted butter, softened to room temperature and cut into 4 pieces", "2 large eggs, at room temperature", "1/2 teaspoon salt", "4 and 1/2 cups (563g) all-purpose flour or bread flour (spooned &amp; leveled), plus more as needed", "2 teaspoons canola, vegetable, or olive oil for bowl (or use nonstick spray)", "6 Tablespoons (85g) unsalted butter, softened to room temperature", "1/2 cup (100g) granulated sugar", "1 and 1/2 Tablespoons ground cinnamon", "4 ounces (113g) full-fat brick cream cheese, softened to room temperature", "1 cup (120g) confectioners&#8217; sugar", "1 Tablespoon (15ml) heavy cream or milk", "1/2 teaspoon pure vanilla extract"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Whisk the warm buttermilk, 2 Tablespoons sugar, and the yeast together in the bowl of your stand mixer fitted with a dough hook or paddle attachment. Cover and allow mixture to sit for about 5 minutes or until foamy on top. *If you do not own a mixer, you can do this in a large mixing bowl and in the next step, mix the dough together with a large wooden spoon/silicone spatula. It will take a bit of arm muscle. A hand mixer works, but the sticky dough repeatedly gets stuck in the beaters. Mixing by hand with a wooden spoon or silicone spatula is a better choice.*", "name": "Prepare the dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/big-giant-cinnamon-rolls/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "On medium speed, beat in the remaining sugar (which should be 1/2 cup/100g) and the softened butter until it is slightly broken up. Add the eggs and salt and beat on medium speed until combined. The butter won&#8217;t really be mixing into the mixture, so don&#8217;t be alarmed if it stays in pieces. Switch the mixer down to low speed and with it running, add 1 cup of flour at a time, making sure it&#8217;s fully incorporated before adding the next. After 4 cups have been added, add the last 1/2 cup and beat until the dough comes together and pulls away from the sides of the bowl, about 3 minutes. Dough will be soft.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/big-giant-cinnamon-rolls/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Keep the dough in the mixer and beat for an additional 5 full minutes, or knead by hand on a lightly floured surface for 5 full minutes. (If you\u2019re new to bread-baking, my How to Knead Dough video tutorial can help here.) If the dough becomes too sticky during the kneading process, sprinkle 1 teaspoon of flour at a time on the dough or on the work surface/in the bowl to make a soft, slightly tacky dough. Do not add more flour than you need because you do not want a dry dough. After kneading, the dough should still feel a little soft. Poke it with your finger\u2014if it slowly bounces back, your dough is ready to rise. You can also do a \u201cwindowpane test\u201d to see if your dough has been kneaded long enough: tear off a small (roughly golfball-size) piece of dough and gently stretch it out until it\u2019s thin enough for light to pass through it. Hold it up to a window or light. Does light pass through the stretched dough without the dough tearing first? If so, your dough has been kneaded long enough and is ready to rise. If not, keep kneading until it passes the windowpane test.", "name": "Knead the dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/big-giant-cinnamon-rolls/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Lightly grease a large bowl with oil or use nonstick spray. Place the dough in the bowl, turning it to coat all sides in the oil. Cover the bowl with aluminum foil, plastic wrap, or a clean kitchen towel. Allow the dough to rise in a relatively warm environment for 2 hours or until double in size. (I always let it rise on the counter and it takes about 2 hours. For a tiny reduction in rise time, see my answer to Where Should Dough Rise? in my Baking with Yeast Guide.)", "name": "1st Rise", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/big-giant-cinnamon-rolls/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Grease the bottom and sides of a metal or glass 9&#215;13-inch baking dish or line with parchment paper.\u00a0", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/big-giant-cinnamon-rolls/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Punch down the dough to release the air. Turn the dough out onto a lightly floured work surface and, using a rolling pin, roll into a 10&#215;16-inch rectangle. Make sure the dough is smooth and evenly thick. If the dough keeps shrinking as you roll it out, stop what you\u2019re doing, cover it lightly, and let it rest for 10 minutes to relax the gluten. When you return to the dough, it should stretch out much easier.", "name": "Roll out the dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/big-giant-cinnamon-rolls/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Spread the softened butter all over the dough. In a small bowl, toss the cinnamon and sugar together until combined and then sprinkle evenly over the dough. Tightly roll up the dough to form a 16 inch long log. If some filling spills out, that&#8217;s ok just sprinkle it on top of the rolls. Cut into 8 large rolls (about 2 inches in width each). Arrange them in the prepared baking pan.\u00a0", "name": "For the filling", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/big-giant-cinnamon-rolls/#instruction-step-7"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cover the rolls tightly and allow to rise until puffy, about 2 hours. About halfway through baking time, tent a piece of aluminum foil over the pan to prevent the tops from browning too quickly. Remove pan from the oven and allow to cool on a wire rack for about 10 minutes as you make the icing.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/big-giant-cinnamon-rolls/#instruction-step-10"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a medium bowl using a handheld or stand mixer fitted with a paddle or whisk attachment, beat the cream cheese on medium speed until smooth and creamy. sugar", "1 Tablespoon (15ml) heavy cream or milk", "1/2 teaspoon pure vanilla extract"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "To help guarantee success, I recommend reading through the recipe before beginning. I also detail this recipe in the separate pastry dough post. Do not use an electric mixer for this dough. It&#8217;s best if the dough is folded together with a wooden spoon or silicone spatula since it is so sticky. There is very minimal mixing required.", "name": "Preliminary note", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/blueberries-n-cream-danish-braid/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Whisk the warm water, yeast, and 1 Tablespoon (6g) of sugar together in a large bowl. Cover and allow to rest until foamy on top, about 5 minutes. If the surface doesn&#8217;t have bubbles on top or look foamy after 15 minutes (it should if the yeast isn&#8217;t expired), start over with a fresh packet of yeast. Whisk in remaining sugar, the milk, egg, and salt. Once these wet ingredients are mixed together, lightly cover and set the bowl aside as you work on the next step.", "name": "Make the Pastry Dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/blueberries-n-cream-danish-braid/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cut the cold butter into 1/4 inch slices and add to a food processor or blender. Top with 2 and 1/2 cups flour. Pulse the mixture 12-15 times, until butter is crumbled into pea-size bits. See photo below for a visual. Using a food processor or blender is best for this dough. Keeping that in mind, if you don&#8217;t have one, you can use a pastry cutter to work in the butter.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/blueberries-n-cream-danish-braid/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Pour the flour mixture into the wet yeast mixture. Very gently fold everything together using a silicone spatula or wooden spoon. Fold *just until* the dry ingredients are moistened. The butter must remain in pieces and crumbles, which creates a flaky pastry. Turn the sticky dough out onto a large piece of plastic wrap, parchment paper, aluminum foil, or into any container you can tightly cover.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/blueberries-n-cream-danish-braid/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Wrap the dough/cover up tightly and refrigerate for at least 4 hours and up to 48 hours.", "name": "1st Refrigeration", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/blueberries-n-cream-danish-braid/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Take the dough out of the refrigerator to begin the \u201crolling and folding\u201d process. If the dough sat for more than 4 hours, it may have slightly puffed up and that&#8217;s ok. (It will deflate as you shape it, which is also ok.) Very generously flour a work surface. The dough is very sticky, so make sure you have more flour nearby as you roll and fold. Using the palm of your hands, gently flatten the dough into a small square. Using a rolling pin, roll out into a 15&#215;8-inch rectangle. When needed, flour the work surface and dough as you are rolling. Fold the dough into thirds as if it were a business letter. (See photos and video tutorial.) Turn it clockwise and roll it out into a 15 inch long rectangle again. Then, fold into thirds again. Turn it clockwise. You\u2019ll repeat rolling and folding 1 more time for a total of 3 times.", "name": "Roll &amp; Fold", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/blueberries-n-cream-danish-braid/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Wrap up/seal tightly and refrigerate for at least 1 hour and up to 24 hours. You can also freeze the dough at this point. See freezing instructions.", "name": "2nd Refrigeration", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/blueberries-n-cream-danish-braid/#instruction-step-7"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Line two large baking sheets with parchment paper or silicone baking mats. Rimmed baking sheets are best because butter may leak from the dough as it bakes. If you don&#8217;t have rimmed baking sheets, when it&#8217;s time to preheat the oven, place another baking sheet on the oven rack below to catch any butter that may drip.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/blueberries-n-cream-danish-braid/#instruction-step-8"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a medium bowl using a handheld or stand mixer fitted with a paddle attachment, beat the cream cheese and egg yolk together on medium speed until smooth. Add the sugar, lemon juice, and vanilla, then beat until smooth. Cover and refrigerate until ready to use.", "name": "Make the cheese filling", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/blueberries-n-cream-danish-braid/#instruction-step-9"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Take the dough out of the refrigerator and cut it in half. Wrap 1 half up and keep refrigerated as you work with the first half. (You can freeze half of the dough at this point, use the freezing instructions below.)", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/blueberries-n-cream-danish-braid/#instruction-step-10"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "On a floured work surface, roll dough out into a 12&#215;8-inch rectangle. You can roll out the dough on a lightly floured piece of parchment paper or lightly floured silicone baking mat instead because you will transfer the shaped dough to a lined baking sheet next.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/blueberries-n-cream-danish-braid/#instruction-step-11"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Using a sharp knife, cut off two corners of the dough (on one 8-inch side) and then two small triangles 3 inches apart from each other on the other end (the other 8-inch side). See visual below.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/blueberries-n-cream-danish-braid/#instruction-step-12"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Spread 1/2 of the cream cheese filling down the length of the center of the strip, which should be about 3 inches wide. Dot with half of the blueberries (1/3 cup). Using a sharp knife, pastry wheel, or pizza cutter, cut 10 slanting strips (3/4 &#8211; 1 inch wide each) along both sides. Fold strips over filling, alternating each side to resemble a twist or a braid. Fold the bottom end up to seal the filling inside. Repeat with the second half of the dough and the rest of the filling. The braids may seem very narrow, but they puff up and out as they bake.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/blueberries-n-cream-danish-braid/#instruction-step-13"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Whisk the egg wash ingredients together. Brush all over the dough. If you want a little crunch from almonds, sprinkle them evenly on top of the braids after brushing the dough with egg wash.", "name": "Egg Wash", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/blueberries-n-cream-danish-braid/#instruction-step-14"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "I strongly recommend refrigerating the shaped braids before baking for at least 15 minutes and up to 1 hour before baking. The braids tend to leak more butter and/or lose more shape if they haven&#8217;t chilled.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/blueberries-n-cream-danish-braid/#instruction-step-15"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat oven to 400\u00b0F (204\u00b0C).", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/blueberries-n-cream-danish-braid/#instruction-step-16"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake each braid for 18-22 minutes or until golden brown. Some butter may leak from the dough, that&#8217;s completely normal and expected. Feel free to remove the baking sheets from the oven halfway through baking and brush the dough with any of the leaking butter, then place back in the oven to finish baking. (That&#8217;s what I do!)", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/blueberries-n-cream-danish-braid/#instruction-step-17"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Remove baked braids from the oven and cool for at least 5 minutes before icing, cutting, and serving.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/blueberries-n-cream-danish-braid/#instruction-step-18"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Whisk the icing ingredients together. If you want a thicker icing, whisk in more confectioners\u2019 sugar. If you want a thinner icing, whisk in more milk or cream. Drizzle over warm pastries and serve.", "name": "Vanilla Icing", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/blueberries-n-cream-danish-braid/#instruction-step-19"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cover leftover iced or un-iced pastries and store at room temperature for 1 day or in the refrigerator for up to 5 days. Or you can freeze them for up to 3 months. Thaw before serving. Crumb-coated cake and ganache must chill before assembling and decorating the cake. See recipe Notes for further information about some ingredients. This recipe is also in my New York Times best-selling cookbook, Sally's Baking 101.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "dark chocolate peanut butter cake", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/07/chocolate-and-peanut-butter-cake-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/07/chocolate-and-peanut-butter-cake-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/07/chocolate-and-peanut-butter-cake-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/07/chocolate-and-peanut-butter-cake.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-peanut-butter-cake/", "recipeIngredient": ["1 and 3/4 cups (219g) all-purpose flour\u00a0(spooned &amp; leveled)", "3/4 cup (64g) unsweetened natural cocoa powder*", "1 and 3/4 cups (350g) granulated sugar", "2 teaspoons baking soda", "1 teaspoon baking powder", "1 teaspoon salt", "2 teaspoons instant espresso powder (optional)*", "1/2 cup (113g/120ml) canola or vegetable oil", "2 large eggs, at room temperature", "3/4 cup (180g) full-fat sour cream, at room temperature", "1/2 cup (120g/ml) buttermilk, at room temperature*", "2 teaspoons pure vanilla extract", "1/2 cup (120g/ml) hot water or black coffee*", "1 cup (170g) mini semi-sweet chocolate chips, tossed in 1 Tablespoon flour", "3/4 cup (12 Tbsp; 170g) unsalted\u00a0butter, softened to room temperature", "1 and 3/4 cups (440g) creamy peanut butter*", "1 and 3/4 cups (210g) confectioners&#8217; sugar", "1 teaspoon pure vanilla extract", "pinch of salt", "3 Tablespoons (45g/ml) heavy cream, at room temperature", "8 ounces (226g) quality semi-sweet chocolate, finely chopped*", "1 cup (240g/ml) heavy cream", "optional garnish: chopped or mini peanut butter cups"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat oven to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C). Grease three 9-inch cake pans, line with parchment paper rounds, then grease the parchment paper. Parchment paper helps the cakes seamlessly release from the pans. (If it&#8217;s helpful, see this parchment paper rounds for cakes\u00a0video &amp; post.)", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-peanut-butter-cake/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Whisk the flour, cocoa powder, sugar, baking soda, baking powder, salt, and espresso powder (if using) together in a large bowl. Set aside. Using a handheld or stand mixer fitted with a whisk attachment (or you can use a whisk), mix the oil, eggs, and sour cream together on medium-high speed until combined. Add the buttermilk and vanilla and beat until combined. Pour the wet ingredients into the dry ingredients, add the hot water/coffee, and whisk or beat on low speed until the batter is completely combined. Fold in the flour-coated chocolate chips. Batter is thin and you may see some air bubbles on the surface\u2014that&#8217;s normal. You should have about 6\u20136.5 cups of batter, or around 1400g.\u00a0Divide batter evenly between 3 pans.", "name": "Make the cake:\u00a0", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-peanut-butter-cake/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake for 24\u201326 minutes or until a toothpick inserted in the center comes out clean. Cool the cakes in the pans set on a cooling rack for 1 hour. Run a knife around the edges to help loosen the sides, remove the cakes from the pans, peel off the parchment, and place on the rack to finish cooling. The cakes may slightly sink in the middle as they cool\u2014that&#8217;s expected.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-peanut-butter-cake/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "With a handheld or stand mixer fitted with a paddle attachment, beat the butter on medium high speed until creamy and smooth, about 2 minutes. With a spatula, scrape down the sides and bottom of the bowl as needed. Add the peanut butter and beat until completely combined, about 1\u20132 minutes. Scrape down the sides and bottom of the bowl as needed to help combine. Mixture will be thin. Add confectioners&#8217; sugar, vanilla extract, and salt and then pour in the heavy cream with the mixer running on low speed. After all of the cream has been added, turn the mixer up to medium-high speed and beat for 1\u20132 minutes, or until fully combined and creamy. Add up to 1/4 cup more confectioners&#8217; sugar if frosting seems quite thin. You should end up with about 3.5\u20134 cups (850g) of peanut butter frosting. This amount makes enough for the filling, crumb coat, and for a little piping on top.", "name": "As the cakes cool, make the peanut butter frosting", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-peanut-butter-cake/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "(For extra help with this step, see this video &amp; post on how to assemble a layer cake.) Place 1 cake layer on your cake stand, cake turntable, or serving plate. Using a large icing spatula or small offset spatula, evenly cover the top with about 1 cup (240g) peanut butter frosting. Repeat with 2nd and 3rd cake layers, spreading about 1 cup of peanut butter frosting in between each layer. Spread a thin layer of frosting on the top and around the sides as a crumb coat. Run a bench scraper around the cake to smooth out the sides. Chill uncovered in the refrigerator for at least 30 minutes and up to 3 hours to set the crumb coat.", "name": "Assemble cake + apply crumb coat", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-peanut-butter-cake/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Place finely chopped chocolate in a medium heat-proof bowl. Heat the cream in a small saucepan over medium heat until it begins to gently simmer. (Do not let it come to a rapid boil\u2014that\u2019s too hot!) Pour over chocolate, then let it sit for 2\u20133 minutes to gently soften the chocolate. With a metal spoon or small rubber spatula, very slowly stir until chocolate has melted and mixture is smooth. Ganache is thin. The finer you chopped the chocolate, the quicker it will melt with the cream. If it\u2019s not melting, do not microwave it. If needed, see Troubleshooting Chocolate Ganache. Once the ganache is smooth, refrigerate for at least 30 minutes or up to 1 hour to thicken before spreading on the crumb-coated cake.", "name": "As your crumb coat sets, make the chocolate ganache", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-peanut-butter-cake/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Pour/spoon thickened ganache on chilled cake. Smooth the top with an icing spatula and the sides with a bench scraper. If desired, pipe remaining peanut butter frosting around the edge of the cake. I used\u00a0Wilton 1M piping tip on the pictured cake. Garnish with peanut butter cups, if desired. Serve cake immediately or chill, uncovered, for up to 4\u20136 hours before serving. Cake can be served at room temperature or chilled.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-peanut-butter-cake/#instruction-step-7"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cover leftover cake tightly and store in the refrigerator for up to 5 days. 56g) unsalted butter, cold and cubed*", "4 ounces\u00a0(113g) full-fat brick cream cheese, cold and cubed*", "1 cup (240ml) cold buttermilk*", "2 Tablespoons (30ml) buttermilk, divided", "1 heaping Tablespoon everything bagel seasoning (recipe above)"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat oven to 425\u00b0F (218\u00b0C).", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/everything-biscuits/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Mix all of the everything bagel seasoning ingredients together.", "name": "Make the seasoning", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/everything-biscuits/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Place the flour, 2 Tablespoons everything bagel seasoning, baking powder, baking soda, granulated sugar, garlic powder, and salt together in a large bowl or in a large food processor. Whisk or pulse until combined. Add the cubed butter and cream cheese and cut into the dry ingredients with a pastry cutter or by pulsing several times in the processor. Cut/pulse until coarse crumbs form. See photo above for a visual. If you used a food processor, pour the mixture into a large bowl.", "name": "Make the biscuits", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/everything-biscuits/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Make a well in the center of the mixture. The dough will be shaggy and crumbly with some wet spots. See photo above for a visual.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/everything-biscuits/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Pour the dough and any dough crumbles onto a floured work surface and gently bring together with generously floured hands. The dough will become sticky as you bring it together. Have extra flour nearby and use it often to flour your hands and work surface in this step. Using floured hands or a floured rolling pin, flatten into a 3/4 inch thick rectangle as best you can. Fold one side into the center, then the other side. Turn the dough horizontally. Gently flatten into a 3/4 inch thick rectangle again. Repeat the folding again. Turn the dough horizontally one more time. Gently flatten into a 3/4 inch thick rectangle. Repeat the folding one last time. Flatten into the final 3/4 inch thick rectangle.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/everything-biscuits/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cut into 3-inch circles with a biscuit cutter. (Tip: Do not twist the biscuit cutter when pressing down into the dough\u2014this seals off the edges of the biscuit which prevents them from fully rising.) Re-roll scraps until all the dough is used. You should have about 8 biscuits. Arrange in a 10-inch cast iron skillet (see note) or close together on a parchment paper-lined baking sheet. Make sure the biscuits are touching.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/everything-biscuits/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Brush the tops with 1 Tablespoon buttermilk. You can add various extracts, in addition to the vanilla extract. If doing so, I recommend reducing the vanilla extract to 1 teaspoon. Extracts you can add include 1/2 teaspoon peppermint extract, 1/2 teaspoon maple extract, 1/2 teaspoon coconut extract, 1/2 teaspoon orange extract, or 1/4 teaspoon almond extract. Taste the buttercream, and, if desired, beat in an extra splash of extract. Instead of adding extracts, you can keep the vanilla extract as 2 teaspoons, and beat in 1/4 teaspoon of ground cinnamon. You could also try this <a href=\"https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/lemon-buttercream-frosting/\">Lemon Buttercream</a>, <a href=\"https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/favorite-chocolate-buttercream/\">Chocolate Buttercream</a>, <a href=\"https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chai-spice-buttercream/\">Chai Spice Buttercream</a>, or <a href=\"https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/white-chocolate-buttercream-frosting/\">White Chocolate Buttercream</a>.", "inLanguage": "en-US"}, "inLanguage": "en-US"}, {"@type": "Question", "@id": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/vanilla-buttercream/#faq-question-1749829949891", "position": 2, "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/vanilla-buttercream/#faq-question-1749829949891", "name": "Is this buttercream sweet?", "answerCount": 1, "acceptedAnswer": {"@type": "Answer", "text": "Yes, this is American-style buttercream and it's sweet. You can freeze the buttercream for up to 3 months, and those detailed instructions are in the recipe card below. You can also make it up to 3 days ahead and refrigerate it. To color it, beat in a drop of gel food coloring.\u00a0(<a href=\"https://amzn.to/4la8Bxb\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noreferrer noopener sponsored nofollow\">Here is my favorite brand</a>.)<em>\u00a0</em>I recommend gel food coloring instead of liquid food coloring because liquid can throw off the consistency. The most important steps are whipping the heavy cream into stiff peaks before folding into the filling and refrigerating the cheesecake long enough so it can set.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "no bake, cheesecake, pumpkin cheesecake", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/no-bake-pumpkin-cheesecake-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/no-bake-pumpkin-cheesecake-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/no-bake-pumpkin-cheesecake-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/no-bake-pumpkin-cheesecake.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/no-bake-pumpkin-cheesecake/", "recipeIngredient": ["2 cups (200g) gingersnap cookie crumbs*", "1/4 teaspoon\u00a0each: ground\u00a0ginger\u00a0and ground\u00a0cinnamon", "6 Tablespoons (85g) unsalted butter, melted", "1/4 cup (50g)\u00a0granulated sugar or brown sugar (packed)", "1 cup (240ml) cold heavy cream or heavy whipping cream", "16 ounces (452g) full-fat brick\u00a0cream cheese, softened to room temperature", "1 cup (226g)\u00a0pumpkin puree*", "3/4 cup (90g) confectioners&#8217; sugar", "1/4 cup (50g) packed light or dark brown sugar", "1 teaspoon pure vanilla extract", "2 teaspoons store-bought or homemade pumpkin pie spice*", "1/2 teaspoon ground cinnamon", "1/8 teaspoon salt", "Whipped Cream and/or Salted Caramel"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Stir the gingersnap crust ingredients together. Pour into a 9-inch or 10-inch springform pan and pack in very tightly. The tighter it&#8217;s packed, the less likely it will fall apart when cutting the cheesecake. I recommend using the bottom of a measuring cup to pack it into the bottom and up the sides. You can watch me do this in the video above. Freeze for 10-20 minutes as you prepare the filling.", "name": "Make the crust", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/no-bake-pumpkin-cheesecake/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Using a hand mixer or a stand mixer fitted with a whisk attachment, whip the cold heavy cream into stiff peaks on medium-high speed, about 4 minutes. Set aside.", "name": "Make the filling", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/no-bake-pumpkin-cheesecake/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Using a hand mixer or a stand mixer fitted with a whisk or paddle attachment, beat the cream cheese on medium speed until perfectly smooth and creamy. Scrape down the sides and up the bottom of the bowl with a silicone spatula as needed. Add the pumpkin, confectioners&#8217; sugar, and brown sugar and beat on medium-high speed until combined. Scrape down the sides and up the bottom of the bowl as needed to help combine. Add the vanilla extract, pumpkin pie spice, cinnamon, and salt and beat until combined, creamy, and smooth. Make sure there are no large lumps of cream cheese. If there are lumps, keep beating until smooth.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/no-bake-pumpkin-cheesecake/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Using your mixer on low speed or a silicone spatula, fold the whipped cream into the cheesecake filling until combined. This takes several turns of your silicone spatula. Combine slowly as you don&#8217;t want to deflate all the air in the whipped cream.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/no-bake-pumpkin-cheesecake/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Remove crust from the freezer and spread filling into crust. For best results, at least 12 hours is best. I chill mine overnight. The longer refrigerated, the nicer the no-bake cheesecake will set up. I don&#8217;t recommend using the freezer to set this cheesecake filling.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/no-bake-pumpkin-cheesecake/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Use a knife to loosen the chilled cheesecake from the rim of the springform pan, then remove the rim. It seems to be a heavy cream issue, not a recipe issue.  I make my whipped cream first, and then transfer it to a bowl in the fridge to stay firm while I make the cream cheese pumpkin mix.  Then I fold in just enough whipped cream to get that nice whipped look, and save the rest for topping.  \r\n\r\nI move the filled crust into the freezer for 15 minutes before transferring it to the fridge, and once set, pipe the extra cream on top.  \r\n\r\nIf you use store bought whipped cream out of a tub, it falls flat and changes the consistency to a mousse, so don\u2019t do that.  I took one for the team for funsies and ate the mousse with graham crackers.  Still a win."}, {"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "4"}, "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Rachel Cannon"}, "datePublished": "2025-11-23", "reviewBody": "Really tasty and easy to make, but mine didn't set up after 20 hours in the fridge. Beat on medium-high speed for 2 minutes until combined. My #1 tip: Give the assembled brownies plenty of time to freeze so they slice into neat squares or rectangles.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "ice cream, ice cream sandwich, brownies", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/homemade-brownie-ice-cream-sandwiches-2-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/homemade-brownie-ice-cream-sandwiches-2-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/homemade-brownie-ice-cream-sandwiches-2-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/homemade-brownie-ice-cream-sandwiches-2.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/brownie-ice-cream-sandwiches/", "recipeIngredient": ["1 cup (226g) unsalted butter", "2 cups (400g)\u00a0granulated sugar", "3\u00a0large\u00a0eggs, at room temperature", "1 Tablespoon pure vanilla extract", "1 cup\u00a0(82g)\u00a0unsweetened natural\u00a0or\u00a0dutch-process cocoa powder*", "1 cup\u00a0(125g)\u00a0all-purpose flour\u00a0(spooned &amp; leveled)", "1 teaspoon\u00a0salt", "3/4 teaspoon baking powder", "2 quart container (1/2 gallon)\u00a0vanilla ice cream (slightly softened\u2014you can use any flavor and you&#8217;ll have a little leftover)"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "For best success, I recommend reviewing the recipe notes and video tutorial above before beginning.", "name": "Preliminary note", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/brownie-ice-cream-sandwiches/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat the oven to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C) and line a 9-inch square baking pan with parchment paper, leaving enough overhang on the sides to lift the warm brownies out. Set aside. (If you have 2 identical 9-inch square baking pans, you can line both and bake the batches of brownie batter at the same time.) I don&#8217;t recommend other size baking pans. See my recipe note.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/brownie-ice-cream-sandwiches/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a microwave-safe bowl or a saucepan on the stove, melt the butter. After melting, whisk in the sugar until completely combined, then whisk in the eggs and vanilla. The batter will be a little dull looking.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/brownie-ice-cream-sandwiches/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Add the cocoa powder, flour, salt, and baking powder. Fold it all together with a rubber spatula or wooden spoon. It will come together, I promise! Batter will be very thick. You will have about 4 cups of batter.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/brownie-ice-cream-sandwiches/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Spoon and spread half of the batter (about 2 cups) into prepared pan. (Lightly cover remaining batter and keep at room temperature.) The batter is thick and heavy, so do your best to spread it evenly in the lined baking pan. I find the back of a spoon is most helpful. Place a small sheet of parchment paper directly on top of the brownie batter, smoothing it down as pictured in the photos and video tutorial above. The top parchment paper helps the brownies stay flat and prevents the brownies from puffing up too much.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/brownie-ice-cream-sandwiches/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake for 15-16 minutes. I find any longer over-cooks the brownies, making the ice cream sandwiches difficult to cut and eat. Remove brownies from the oven and cool for 5 minutes in the pan. Carefully, using the overhanging parchment paper on the sides, lift the warm and soft square sheet of brownies out of the pan as a whole. Remove top piece of parchment. (You can reuse it for the top of the 2nd sheet of brownies in the next step, if desired.) Set aside.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/brownie-ice-cream-sandwiches/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Line the warm pan with another sheet of parchment paper, leaving enough overhang on the sides to lift the warm brownies out. Give the remaining brownie batter a stir. It will be very thick at this point. Add a teaspoon of water to thin out if necessary. (No more.) Spoon and spread the remaining brownie batter in the pan. Place a small sheet of parchment paper directly on top of the brownie batter, just as you did before.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/brownie-ice-cream-sandwiches/#instruction-step-7"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake for 15-16 minutes. Remove brownies from the oven and cool for 15 minutes in the pan. During this cooling time, I remove the ice cream from the freezer so it has a chance to soften.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/brownie-ice-cream-sandwiches/#instruction-step-8"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Scoop the softened ice cream onto the warm brownie layer in the pan. You&#8217;ll use almost all of the 1/2 gallon of ice cream. Using the back of a spoon or your ice cream scoop, gently spread it into an even and thick layer.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/brownie-ice-cream-sandwiches/#instruction-step-9"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Carefully pick up the 1st square sheet of brownies and place on top of the ice cream layer. Gently press it down into the ice cream to help it stick. Cover the entire pan with aluminum foil or plastic wrap and freeze for at least 12 hours and up to 1 week. I find 12-18 hours is the perfect amount of time. Any less and the ice cream will still be pretty soft. The longer after 18 hours, the harder the sandwiches are to cut.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/brownie-ice-cream-sandwiches/#instruction-step-10"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Remove the pan of ice cream brownies from the freezer. Microwave in four fifteen second increments, stirring after each, for a total of 60 seconds. Stir until almost completely melted. Set aside.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-hazelnut-crunch-truffles/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Pour\u00a0cream into a\u00a0small saucepan over medium heat. Whisking occasionally, heat until it just begins to boil. Remove from the heat, then slowly pour over the chocolate. Gently begin stirring with a wooden spoon in one direction. Do not forcefully stir, always be gentle! Once the chocolate and cream are smooth, stir in the Nutella and butter until combined and smooth, then stir in 1/2 cup of the hazelnuts. Cover with plastic wrap pressed on the top of the mixture then allow to sit at room temperature for 15-30\u00a0minutes. Then place in the refrigerator until it reaches &#8220;scoopable&#8221; consistency, about 4\u00a0hours.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-hazelnut-crunch-truffles/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Line a lage baking sheet with parchment paper or a silicone baking mat. Set aside.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-hazelnut-crunch-truffles/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Remove mixture from the refrigerator. Measure 1 teaspoon, roll mixture in your hands into a ball as best as you can, then place on the baking sheet. The mixture will be a little sticky. Coat your palms with a little cocoa powder, which I find helps you handle the mixture. Repeat rolling\u00a0the rest of the mixture. (A rolling tip:\u00a0If you can&#8217;t roll into perfect balls, do the best you can and place on the baking sheet. The air will help &#8220;dry out&#8221; the truffles. After 15 minutes, you&#8217;ll be able to roll them into neater balls.)", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-hazelnut-crunch-truffles/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "You can melt the remaining 8 ounces of\u00a0chocolate in a double boiler or the microwave. (Alternatively, you can temper the chocolate.) If using the microwave: place the chocolate in a medium heat-proof bowl. I like to use a liquid measuring cup. Its depth\u00a0makes it easier for dipping. Melt in 15 second increments in the microwave, stirring after each increment until completely melted and smooth.", "name": "Coat in chocolate", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-hazelnut-crunch-truffles/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Dip each truffle completely into the chocolate using the spiral dipping tool or a fork. When lifting the ball out of the chocolate, remember to tap the dipping tool gently on the side of the bowl to allow excess chocolate to drip off. Place balls back onto the baking sheet after you dip each one. Drizzle with any leftover chocolate. Sprinkle with remaining hazelnuts. Refrigerate for 30 minutes or until chocolate has completely set before serving.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-hazelnut-crunch-truffles/#instruction-step-6"}], "prepTime": "PT1H", "cookTime": "", "totalTime": "PT5H30M", "recipeYield": ["40", "40-45 truffles"], "recipeCategory": "Candy", "cookingMethod": "No Bake", "recipeCuisine": "American", "aggregateRating": {"@type": "AggregateRating", "reviewCount": "5", "ratingValue": "4.8"}, "review": [{"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "4"}, "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Ali"}, "datePublished": "2020-05-16", "reviewBody": "I made what I call a truffle cookie bar. Thank you for sharing.\n\nSrikanth from India\nChocolate Mantra"}, {"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Laurara"}, "datePublished": "2021-02-15", "reviewBody": "Oh, yes!  This is the stuff!  I have been looking for a hazelnut truffle recipe, and this one is great.  It never occurred to me to have pieces of nuts inside- what a delicious revelation! I made this to fill bonbons, in hard chocolate shell hearts (complete with edible gold leaf!).  I made a few modifications- I made it vegan!  My daughter is vegan, and I wanted her to be able to have one (yes, one). \r\n\r\nI used Silk Protein Nut Milk in place of cream, because it is thick and rich.  I used salted Earth Balance in place of butter, But- I used half the suggested amount, and substituted 1 T of toasted hazelnut oil, which is delicious.  I got raw, organic hazelnuts from nuts.com, roasted them at 350 F for 12 minutes.  When they cooled a bit, I put them between two ceramic bowls and shook hard to sluff off the skins.  I did this a couple times.  Then I put them in a thick freezer bag and crushed them first with a rolling pin, then with the flat end of a meat tenderizer.  They are so fragrant this way! Oh, and I also used Nutiva Hazelnut Spread in place of Nutella which I got from Thrive Market, because it is vegan and it does not contain icky palm oil.  They make it in 'regular' and dark.  I used the regular one, because I did not want the chocolate flavor to overpower the hazelnut flavor.  \r\n\r\nThank you Sally for the inspiration!!"}, {"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Anna"}, "datePublished": "2021-03-06", "reviewBody": "Amazing and incredibly easy to follow. Make pie dough the night before because it needs to chill in the refrigerator for at least 2 hours before rolling out and blind baking (next step).", "name": "Prepare pie crust", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/brownie-pie/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "If you need a visual for the crust steps, there are helpful step-by-step photos below this recipe. On a floured work surface, roll out one of the disks of chilled dough (use the 2nd pie crust for another recipe). Turn the dough about a quarter turn after every few rolls until you have a circle 12 inches in diameter. Carefully place the dough into a 9-inch pie dish. Tuck it in with your fingers, making sure it is completely smooth. To make a lovely thick edge, I do not trim excess dough around the edges. Instead, fold the excess dough back over the edge and use your hands to mold the edge into a rim around the pie. Crimp the edges with a fork or use your fingers to flute the edges. (In the pictured pie, I fluted the edges and then crimped them with a fork. Review my how to crimp and flute pie crust tutorial if you need extra help with this step.) If dough is too warm, fluting/crimping will be difficult so you can always chill it in the refrigerator for 5-10 minutes first. After fluting/crimping the edges, chill the pie dough in the refrigerator for at least 30 minutes and up to 5 days. Cover the pie crust with plastic wrap if chilling for longer than 30 minutes. Chilling the shaped dough helps prevent the crust from shrinking.", "name": "Roll out the chilled pie dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/brownie-pie/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "While the crust is chilling, preheat oven to 375\u00b0F (190\u00b0C).", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/brownie-pie/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Line the chilled pie crust with parchment paper. Fill with pie weights or dried beans. Make sure the weights are evenly distributed around the pie dish. Bake until the edges of the crust are starting to brown, about 15-16 minutes. Remove pie from the oven and carefully lift the parchment paper (with the weights) out of the pie. Prick holes all around the bottom crust with a fork. Return pie crust to the oven and bake for 8 minutes to help set the bottom. Remove from the oven. Brush egg wash/egg white all over the bottom and sides of the warm pie crust. Set pie crust aside. (Crust can still be warm when you add the filling. You can pre-bake the crust/add egg wash up to 3 days ahead of time. Cover cooled crust tightly and refrigerate until ready to fill.)", "name": "Partially blind bake", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/brownie-pie/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Reduce oven temperature to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C).", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/brownie-pie/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Slice the butter into Tablespoon-size pieces and melt in the microwave in a large heat-proof bowl or in a small saucepan on the stove. (Transfer melted butter to a large bowl if using the stove.) Whisk the oil and granulated sugar into the melted butter. Let it sit for 3-5 minutes to slightly cool. Whisk in 2 whole eggs, 1 egg yolk, and vanilla extract until combined. Add the cocoa powder, flour, and salt and whisk until combined. Batter will be thick. Fold in the walnuts and chocolate chips. Batter will continue to thicken the longer it sits, so immediately spoon and spread evenly into crust.", "name": "Make the brownie batter immediately before spreading into crust", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/brownie-pie/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake for 40-45 minutes or until a toothpick inserted in the center comes out with just a few moist crumbs. During bake time, if you find the edges of the pie crust are browning too quickly, apply a\u00a0pie crust shield\u00a0or a ring of aluminum foil to protect it. **Err on the side of under-baking because the brownie filling will set as it cools.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/brownie-pie/#instruction-step-7"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Remove pie from the oven. Cool for 20 minutes before slicing and serving. Brownie pie will still be warm and that&#8217;s ok. Tastes best served warm!", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/brownie-pie/#instruction-step-8"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cover and store leftover pie at room temperature for up to 2 days or in the refrigerator for up to 4-5 days.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/brownie-pie/#instruction-step-10"}], "prepTime": "PT3H", "cookTime": "PT1H5M", "totalTime": "PT4H25M", "recipeYield": ["9", "one 9-inch pie"], "recipeCategory": "Dessert", "cookingMethod": "Baking", "recipeCuisine": "American", "aggregateRating": {"@type": "AggregateRating", "reviewCount": "6", "ratingValue": "4.7"}, "review": [{"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "4"}, "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Christina"}, "datePublished": "2025-11-12", "reviewBody": "I made this pie and it looked great! Sally\u2019s work has been featured on TODAY, Good Morning America, Taste of Home, People, and more.", "sameAs": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"]}, {"@context": "https://schema.org/", "@type": "Recipe", "name": "Snickers Caramel Tart", "description": "This Snickers caramel tart combines caramel, salty peanuts, chocolate, and peanut butter for one irresistible sweet and salty dessert!", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "snickers tart, homemade tart, chocolate tart", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/03/snickers-caramel-tart-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/03/snickers-caramel-tart-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/03/snickers-caramel-tart-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/03/snickers-caramel-tart.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/snickers-caramel-tart/", "recipeIngredient": ["1 and 3/4 cups (220g) salted roasted peanuts, divided*", "1 cup (125g) all-purpose flour (spooned &amp; leveled)", "2 Tablespoons (25g) light brown\u00a0sugar", "1/4 teaspoon salt", "1/2 cup (8 Tbsp; 113g) unsalted butter, cold and cubed", "3 Tablespoons (45ml) ice water", "1 cup (290g) homemade salted caramel* (the full recipe)", "6 ounces milk or semi-sweet chocolate, coarsely chopped", "2 Tablespoons (31g) creamy peanut butter", "optional: chopped Snickers bar, crushed peanuts, extra caramel for topping"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "I encourage you to check out the step-by-step photos\u00a0for the crust below this recipe before beginning.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/snickers-caramel-tart/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat the oven to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C). Using a food processor, pulse 3/4 cup peanuts, the flour, brown sugar, and salt together until it reaches the consistency of coarse meal. Add the cubes of cold butter and pulse until the mixture turns into\u00a0pea-sized crumbs.\u00a0Transfer mixture to a large bowl. Slowly stir in 3 Tablespoons of ice water. You only want to add enough water to bring the dough somewhat together. Using floured fingers or the bottom of a flat and lightly floured measuring cup, press the dough evenly into a\u00a09-inch tart pan. You want it extremely tight in the pan.\u00a0You&#8217;ll need to use\u00a0pie weights\u00a0for the next step, so line the crust with aluminum foil or parchment paper and add pie weights. If you do not have pie weights, prick the crust a few times with a fork so no air bubbles form.", "name": "For the crust", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/snickers-caramel-tart/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake (with pie weights) for 18-20 minutes.\u00a0Remove from the oven and\u00a0allow to slightly cool as you prepare the filling.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/snickers-caramel-tart/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "\u00a0Mix the salted caramel and 1 cup of peanuts together. If the salted caramel was made ahead of time, slightly warm it so that it can easily be poured. Pour caramel nut filling into crust.", "name": "For the filling", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/snickers-caramel-tart/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Using a double boiler or microwave, melt the chocolate and peanut butter together until smooth. If using the microwave, stop and stir every 15 seconds until melted. Spread over caramel nut filling. Garnish with optional toppings, if desired.", "name": "For the topping", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/snickers-caramel-tart/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Chill in the refrigerator, uncovered, for 2-3 hours or until set. Sally\u2019s work has been featured on TODAY, Good Morning America, Taste of Home, People, and more.", "sameAs": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"]}, {"@context": "https://schema.org/", "@type": "Recipe", "name": "S'more Chocolate Crinkle Cookies", "description": "A soft and brownie-like chocolate crinkle cookie, rolled into graham cracker crumbs and topped with melty marshmallows.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "S'more Chocolate Crinkle Cookies", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/08/Smore-Crinkle-Cookies-5-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/08/Smore-Crinkle-Cookies-5-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/08/Smore-Crinkle-Cookies-5-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/08/Smore-Crinkle-Cookies-5.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/smore-chocolate-crinkle-cookies/", "recipeIngredient": ["1/2 cup (8 Tbsp; 113g) unsalted butter, softened to room temperature", "1/2 cup (100g) granulated sugar", "1/2 cup (100g) packed light or dark brown sugar", "1 large egg", "1 teaspoon pure vanilla extract", "1 cup (125g) all-purpose flour (spooned &amp; leveled)", "2/3 cup (55g) unsweetened cocoa powder", "1 teaspoon baking soda", "1/8 teaspoon salt", "1 Tablespoon (15ml) milk", "1/2 cup (50g) miniature marshmallows, cut in half", "3/4 cup (75g) graham cracker crumbs (about 5 graham crackers)"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a large bowl using a handheld or stand mixer fitted with a paddle attachment, beat the butter, granulated sugar, and brown sugar together on medium high speed until fluffy and light in color, about 2-3 minutes. Add the egg and vanilla extract, and then beat on high speed until combined. Scrape down the sides and bottom of the bowl as needed.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/smore-chocolate-crinkle-cookies/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a separate bowl, whisk the flour, cocoa powder, baking soda and salt together until combined. With the mixer running on low speed, slowly pour into the wet ingredients. Beat on low until combined. The cookie dough will be quite thick. Switch to high speed and beat in the milk. The cookie dough will be sticky and tacky. Cover dough tightly and chill in the refrigerator for at least 3 hours and up to 3 days. Chilling is mandatory for this sticky cookie dough.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/smore-chocolate-crinkle-cookies/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Remove cookie dough from the refrigerator and allow to sit at room temperature for 10 minutes. If the cookie dough chilled longer than 3 hours, let it sit at room temperature for about 20 minutes. This makes the chilled cookie dough easier to scoop and roll.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/smore-chocolate-crinkle-cookies/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat oven to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C). Line large baking sheets with parchment paper or silicone baking mats. (Always recommended\u00a0for cookies.)\u00a0Set aside.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/smore-chocolate-crinkle-cookies/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Scoop and roll dough, a heaping 1.5 Tablespoons of dough each, into balls (I use this medium cookie scoop). Roll each into graham cracker crumbs. Arrange 2-3 inches apart on the baking sheets. The cookie dough is certainly sticky, so wipe your hands clean after every few balls of dough you shape.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/smore-chocolate-crinkle-cookies/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake for 10 minutes. Remove from the oven and press 3-4 pieces of marshmallow on top of each cookie. Return to the oven for another 1-2 minutes. Remove from the oven and allow to cool on the cookie sheet for at least 5 minutes before transferring to a wire rack to cool completely. The cookies will slightly deflate as they cool.\u00a0", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/smore-chocolate-crinkle-cookies/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cover leftover cookies tightly and store at room temperature for up to 1 week.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/smore-chocolate-crinkle-cookies/#instruction-step-7"}], "prepTime": "PT3H20M", "cookTime": "PT11M", "totalTime": "PT3H35M", "recipeYield": ["20", "20-22 cookies"], "recipeCategory": "Cookies", "cookingMethod": "Baking", "recipeCuisine": "American", "aggregateRating": {"@type": "AggregateRating", "reviewCount": "1", "ratingValue": "5"}, "review": [{"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Malia"}, "datePublished": "2020-03-18", "reviewBody": "Super tasty! (Here\u2019s a helpful tutorial if you need guidance on\u00a0how to cream butter and sugar.) Add the egg, vanilla, and almond extract (if using) and beat on high speed until combined, about 1 minute. Place each portion onto a piece of lightly floured parchment paper or a lightly floured silicone baking mat. With a lightly floured rolling pin, roll the dough out to about 1/4-inch thickness. Use more flour if the dough seems too sticky. The rolled-out dough can be any shape, as long as it is evenly 1/4-inch thick.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/valentines-day-heart-sugar-cookies/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Lightly dust one of the rolled-out doughs with flour. Line 2\u20133 large baking sheets with silicone baking mats or parchment paper. Carefully remove the top dough piece from the refrigerator. If it&#8217;s sticking to the bottom, run your hand under it to help remove it. Using a heart cookie cutter (pictured cookies use the 3.5-inch size), cut the dough into hearts. Re-roll the remaining dough and continue cutting until all is used. Repeat with 2nd piece of dough. (Note: It may not seem like a lot of dough, but you get a lot of cookies from the dough scraps you re-roll.)", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/valentines-day-heart-sugar-cookies/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Arrange cookies on baking sheets 3 inches apart. Bake for 11\u201312 minutes or until lightly browned around the edges. If your oven has hot spots, rotate the baking sheets halfway through bake time. Allow cookies to cool on the baking sheets for 5 minutes, then transfer to a wire rack to cool completely before decorating.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/valentines-day-heart-sugar-cookies/#instruction-step-7"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "I have a video for how to make royal icing below. Use that as your guide for this step. Combine sifted confectioners&#8217; sugar, meringue powder, and 9 Tablespoons of water in a large bowl. Using a hand mixer or a stand mixer fitted with a whisk attachment, beat icing ingredients together on high speed for 1.5\u20132 minutes. When lifting the whisk up off the icing, the icing should drizzle down and smooth out within 5\u201310 seconds. If it&#8217;s too thick, beat in more water 1 Tablespoon at a time. I usually need 10 Tablespoons, but on particularly dry days, I may use up to 12\u201314 Tablespoons. Keep in mind that the longer you beat the royal icing, the thicker it becomes. If your royal icing is too thin, just keep beating it to introduce more air OR you can add more sifted confectioners&#8217; sugar. Yields about 3 cups of icing.", "name": "Make the icing", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/valentines-day-heart-sugar-cookies/#instruction-step-8"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Separate icing into 6 different bowls. (Or fewer bowls, depending how many colors you want.) Stir in 1 tiny drop of the following colors into each bowl, 1 color per bowl: pink, violet, green, yellow, and orange. The 6th bowl is for the writing. For that, stir in 2\u20133 drops of red. You won&#8217;t use the red icing for a couple hours after the base icing sets, so place a damp paper towel directly on the surface of it. This prevents it from hardening.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/valentines-day-heart-sugar-cookies/#instruction-step-9"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Spoon or pour the pastel icings into piping bags (disposable or reusable) fitted with round piping tip #4. The batter is thick.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/orange-lemon-poppy-seed-muffins/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Spoon the thick batter into the muffin tins, filling them all the way to the top. It didn't take long but seemed to mix everything without overworking it.\r\n\r\nAlso because I'm a bit clumsy, I break the eggs into a glass before adding them to the wet ingredients so I don't end up chasing pieces of eggshell round the bowl.\r\n\r\nThe muffins are delicious.
