Make pie dough the night before because it needs to chill in the refrigerator for at least 2 hours before rolling out and blind baking (next step).", "name": "Prepare pie crust", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/quiche-recipe/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "On a floured work surface, roll out one of the disks of chilled dough (use the 2nd pie crust for another recipe). Turn the dough about a quarter turn after every few rolls until you have a circle 12 inches in diameter. Carefully place the dough into a 9-inch pie dish. Tuck it in with your fingers, making sure it is completely smooth. To make a lovely edge, I do not trim excess dough around the edges. Instead, fold the excess dough back over the edge and use your hands to mold the edge into a rim around the pie. Crimp the edges with a fork or use your fingers to flute the edges. Chill the pie crust in the refrigerator for at least 30 minutes and up to 5 days. Cover the pie crust with plastic wrap if chilling for longer than 30 minutes.", "name": "Roll out the chilled pie dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/quiche-recipe/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "While the crust is chilling, preheat oven to 375\u00b0F (190\u00b0C).", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/quiche-recipe/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Line the chilled pie crust with parchment paper. Fill with pie weights or dried beans. Make sure the weights are evenly distributed around the pie dish. Bake until the edges of the crust are starting to brown, about 15-16 minutes. Remove pie from the oven and carefully lift the parchment paper (with the weights) out of the pie. Prick holes all around the bottom crust with a fork. Return the pie crust to the oven. Bake until the bottom crust is just beginning to brown, about 7-8 minutes. Remove from the oven and set aside. (Crust can still be warm when you pour in the filling. You can partially pre-bake the crust up to 3 days ahead of time. Cover cooled crust tightly and refrigerate until ready to fill.)", "name": "Partially blind bake", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/quiche-recipe/#instruction-step-7"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Reduce oven temperature to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C).", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/quiche-recipe/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a large bowl with a handheld or stand mixer fitted with a whisk attachment, beat the eggs, whole milk, heavy cream, salt, and pepper together on high speed until completely combined, about 1 minute. Don&#8217;t over-bake. Use a pie crust shield to prevent the pie crust edges from over-browning. Allow to cool for 15 minutes. Top with optional toppings before slicing and serving, if desired. Or you can cool the quiche completely before serving\u2014it&#8217;s fantastic at room temperature!", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/quiche-recipe/#instruction-step-7"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "This quiche makes great leftovers! Set aside.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/cookies-n-cream-cookies/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a large bowl using a hand mixer or a stand mixer fitted with a paddle attachment, beat the cream cheese on medium-high speed until completely smooth and creamy. Add the butter and beat until combined (see photo for a visual), scraping down the sides and up the bottom of the bowl as needed. Add granulated sugar and brown sugar and beat on medium-high speed until smooth and creamy, about 2 minutes. Add the egg and vanilla and beat on high speed until combined, about 1 minute. Scrape down the sides and up the bottom of the bowl and beat again as needed to combine.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/cookies-n-cream-cookies/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Add the dry ingredients to the wet ingredients and mix on low speed until combined. With the mixer running on low speed, beat in the white chocolate chips. Add the Oreos and beat on low speed or gently fold in with a silicone spatula or wooden spoon (dough is heavy) until combined. Cover and chill the dough for at least 2 hours in the refrigerator (and up to 4 days). If chilling for longer than a few hours, allow to sit at room temperature for at least 30 minutes before rolling and baking because the dough will be quite hard.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/cookies-n-cream-cookies/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat oven to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C). Set aside.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/triple-chocolate-crunch-granola/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Pour oats into a large bowl, set aside. In a smaller bowl, mix melted coconut oil, cocoa powder, and dark brown sugar until combined. Add honey and salt and mix until a liquid-y paste forms. Pour over oats and mix until all oats are moistened. Add more honey if needed.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/triple-chocolate-crunch-granola/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake for 30 minutes, stirring + flipping every 10 minutes. Remove from oven and sprinkle with chocolate chips while the granola is still warm. Stir. The chocolate chips will melt, creating larger clusters of granola. Once cooled, add in chocolate covered raisins and any additional add-ins you prefer. Store covered at room temperature for up to three weeks.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/triple-chocolate-crunch-granola/#instruction-step-3"}], "prepTime": "PT15M", "cookTime": "PT30M", "totalTime": "PT1H", "recipeYield": ["4", "4 cups"], "recipeCategory": "Snacks", "cookingMethod": "Baking", "recipeCuisine": "American", "aggregateRating": {"@type": "AggregateRating", "reviewCount": "4", "ratingValue": "5"}, "review": [{"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Elizabeth"}, "datePublished": "2022-06-21", "reviewBody": "This is seriously the best chocolate granola I've ever eaten - and this is coming from a chocolate lover and avid granola eater. It's crunchy and has that delicious chocolate taste - mmm. \r\nI made one change to the recipe; instead of using all honey for the 1/3 cup of liquid sweetener, I used about half honey and half maple syrup, with about 3/4 tsp vanilla as well. In my opinion, chocolate isn't real chocolate without a splash of vanilla! \r\nAlso, 1/2 cup of chocolate chips isn't needed. I only used about 1/4 cup, but my family actually complained that it was \"too rich and too chocolate-y\". (I must disagree, but omitting the chocolate took the popular vote.) It's perfectly fine without it. \r\nI recommend turning the oven to convection bake and checking it after 10 minutes, 10 minutes, 5 minutes, 5 minutes. It may not appear crunchy enough at the end but it crisps up excellently. \r\nAll in all, I love this granola and absolutely recommend it!"}, {"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Lil D"}, "datePublished": "2024-02-29", "reviewBody": "So delicious and crunchy, just the right amount of saltiness! Or melt in a medium microwave safe bowl in 20 second increments, stirring after each, in the microwave. Reduce to medium-high speed and beat in the sugar until combined. Beat in the egg and vanilla extract until combined. Finally, fold in the white chocolate chips with a silicone spatula or wooden spoon. Set aside.", "name": "Make the cheesecake batter:\u00a0", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/mocha-cheesecake-brownies/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Spread about half of the brownie batter into the prepared baking pan. The batter is thick, so do your best to spread it to every corner making 1 even layer. Top with all of the cheesecake batter. Spread this in a thick, even layer. Layer on the rest of the thick brownie batter, spreading as best you can. If some cheesecake swirls out on top or if you can&#8217;t quite cover the corners with brownie batter, that&#8217;s ok! Sprinkle the optional chocolate chips on top.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/mocha-cheesecake-brownies/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake for 35\u201338 minutes or until the brownies begin to pull away from the edges of the pan. A toothpick inserted in the center should come out with only a few moist crumbs when the brownies are done. Set aside.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-peppermint-thumbprints/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a large bowl using a handheld or stand mixer fitted with a paddle attachment, beat the butter, brown sugar, and 1/3 cup (67g) granulated sugar together on medium-high speed until smooth and creamy, about 2 minutes. Add the egg, vanilla extract, and peppermint extract and beat on high speed until combined, about 1 minute. Scrape down the sides and up the bottom of the bowl and beat again as needed to combine. Pour the dry ingredients into the wet ingredients, add the milk, and mix on low until combined. The cookie dough will be thick.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-peppermint-thumbprints/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Roll balls of dough, a little less than 1 Tablespoon each (about 1 inch balls), and roll each into remaining 1/3 cup (67g) granulated sugar. Place dough balls onto a large lined baking sheet. Using your thumb or the end of a spatula (see post above), make an indent into each cookie. If you find that the balls are cracking when you make an indent, use your hands to push back together. (Some cracks are bound to happen as the cookies expand in the oven\u2014see my photos. No worries there!)", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-peppermint-thumbprints/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Chill the shaped cookies for at least 2 hours in the refrigerator or 1 hour in the freezer (or up to 4 days in the refrigerator). Cover them if chilling for longer than 3 hours.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-peppermint-thumbprints/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat oven to 350\u00b0F (180\u00b0C). Line a baking sheet with parchment paper or a silicone baking mat. Remove chilled and shaped cookies from the refrigerator. Divide between both baking sheets, spacing the cookies about 2-3 inches apart. This recipe yields about 30 cookies, so you&#8217;ll have a 3rd batch with only a few cookies on the sheet.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-peppermint-thumbprints/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake for 12-14 minutes or until the edges are set. The cookies will still look and feel a little soft. Remove from the oven. The indents will have lost some shape or have puffed up, so use the end of a spatula to make an indent again into the warm cookies.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-peppermint-thumbprints/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Allow cookies to cool on the baking sheets for 5 minutes, then transfer to a wire rack to cool completely before filling with ganache.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-peppermint-thumbprints/#instruction-step-7"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Place chocolate into a heat-proof bowl. Heat the cream in a small saucepan until it begins to gently simmer. (Do not let it come to a rapid boil\u2014that\u2019s too hot!) Pour over chocolate and let it sit for 2-3 minutes to gently soften the chocolate. Slowly stir until completely combined and chocolate has melted. Stir in the peppermint extract. Taste and add another drop if desired. (It&#8217;s potent so don&#8217;t go overboard!) Allow to cool for at least 10 minutes before spooning into cookies.", "name": "For the ganache", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-peppermint-thumbprints/#instruction-step-8"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Spoon 1/2 &#8211; 1 teaspoon of ganache into each indentation. I fit about 3/4 teaspoon into each. Sprinkle ganache with crushed candy canes. Ganache will thicken inside the cookies and set on the tops after a few hours, but will still be creamy when you bite into the cookies.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-peppermint-thumbprints/#instruction-step-9"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cookies stay fresh covered at room temperature for up to 3 days or in the refrigerator for up to 1 week.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-peppermint-thumbprints/#instruction-step-10"}], "prepTime": "PT30M", "cookTime": "PT14M", "totalTime": "PT3H", "recipeYield": ["30", "30-32 cookies"], "recipeCategory": "Desserts", "cookingMethod": "Baking", "recipeCuisine": "American", "aggregateRating": {"@type": "AggregateRating", "reviewCount": "42", "ratingValue": "4.8"}, "review": [{"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Mary Boyd"}, "datePublished": "2023-12-01", "reviewBody": "The family loved the cookies especially my son in law. They were both filled and then frozen after baking. Sadly we lost our mom 4 days into the new yr. Since I knew family and friends would be at her house I grabbed both sets of cookies and by the time I got to my mom's house they had already warmed up. I was able to take something without having to worry about making anything on one of the hardest days of my life. Mom was a big fan of both cookies as well. She also loved Sally's strawberry on strawberry cake. Mom passed without warning but I'm thankful that I was able to make the strawberry on strawberry cake for her 4 months prior. I would often tell her about Sally's website. She was so happy that I got back into baking from scratch. Other than our birthday cakes (mom made them) as a teenager I was the baker in the family. I'll just put it this way. Every recipe I ever made from Sally my mom loved. Thanks for sharing your talent with us. Because of you I was able to treat my mom to some desserts I never made as a teen. Sorry for going off track. I was just hoping to share how well these and the other cookies hold up after freezing. You'd never know they were. I then did 1/2 tsp of cherry jam in a few of them. \r\n\r\nI agree with other comments that have tried jelly to maybe put it in after a few mins of cooking because it really melted in when doing it from the start (maybe if the dough was frozen it wouldnt?) Easy enough for any beginner baker to handle!", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "cookies & cream, Oreo, pie, cookies and cream, cookies and creme, cookies & creme", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/10/cookies-and-cream-pie-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/10/cookies-and-cream-pie-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/10/cookies-and-cream-pie-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/10/cookies-and-cream-pie.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/cookies-cream-pie/", "recipeIngredient": ["22 regular Oreo cookies (not Double-Stuf)", "5 Tablespoons (71g)\u00a0unsalted butter, melted", "1 cup\u00a0(240ml) cold\u00a0heavy cream\u00a0or\u00a0heavy whipping cream", "8 ounces (226g) full-fat brick cream cheese, softened to room temperature", "3/4 cup (90g) confectioners&#8217; sugar", "1 teaspoon pure vanilla extract", "12 whole Oreos, chopped (about 1.5 cups, or 135g)", "optional for topping: homemade whipped cream"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C).", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/cookies-cream-pie/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a food processor or blender, pulse 22 Oreos (including the cream filling) into a fine crumb. You should have about 2 cups (packed) crumbs, or 250g. Pour crumbs into a large bowl. Add the melted butter and stir to combine. The mixture will be thick and quite wet. Try to smash/break up any large chunks. Pour the mixture into an un-greased 9-inch pie dish. With medium pressure using your hand, pat the crumbs down into the bottom and up the sides to make a compact, thick crust. See Oreo crust page for more success tips if needed. Bake for 10 minutes. Allow to cool as you prepare the filling.", "name": "Bake the crust", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/cookies-cream-pie/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Using a hand mixer or a stand mixer fitted with a whisk attachment, whip the cold heavy cream into stiff peaks on medium-high speed, about 4 minutes. Set aside. Using a hand mixer or a stand mixer fitted with a whisk or paddle attachment, beat the cream cheese on medium speed until perfectly smooth and creamy. Scrape down the sides and up the bottom of the bowl with a silicone spatula as needed. Add the confectioners&#8217; sugar and vanilla extract and beat on medium-high speed until combined. Make sure there are no large lumps of cream cheese. If there are lumps, keep beating until smooth.", "name": "Make the filling:\u00a0", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/cookies-cream-pie/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Using your mixer on low speed or a silicone spatula, fold the whipped cream and chopped Oreos into the cream cheese mixture until combined. This takes several turns of your silicone spatula. Combine slowly as you don&#8217;t want to deflate all the air in the whipped cream.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/cookies-cream-pie/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Spread filling into cooled crust. Use an offset spatula to smooth down the top.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/cookies-cream-pie/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cover tightly with plastic wrap or aluminum foil and refrigerate for at least 6 hours and up to 2 days. The longer refrigerated, the better the pie will set up. You could also freeze the pie for at least 4 hours and up to 3 months. The crust is a little difficult to eat frozen, though.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/cookies-cream-pie/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Feel free to garnish the pie with whipped cream. I used Ateco 849 piping tip for the whipped cream in the pictured pie. Using a clean sharp knife, cut into slices for serving. Sally\u2019s work has been featured on TODAY, Good Morning America, Taste of Home, People, and more.", "sameAs": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"]}, {"@context": "https://schema.org/", "@type": "Recipe", "name": "Sunshine Citrus Cake", "description": "This sunshine citrus cake cures the cold weather blues with bright flavor, a light and springy cake crumb, and creamy whipped frosting. Be sure to set aside enough time to prepare the lemon curd in advance.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "citrus cake", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/02/6-inch-citrus-cake-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/02/6-inch-citrus-cake-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/02/6-inch-citrus-cake-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/02/6-inch-citrus-cake.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/6-inch-citrus-cake/", "recipeIngredient": ["2\u00a0large\u00a0egg yolks", "1 large egg", "2/3 cup\u00a0(134g)\u00a0granulated sugar", "1 Tablespoon\u00a0lemon zest\u00a0(about\u00a01\u00a0lemon)", "1/3 cup\u00a0(80ml) fresh\u00a0lemon juice\u00a0(about\u00a02\u20133\u00a0lemons)", "1/8 teaspoon\u00a0salt", "6 Tablespoons\u00a0(85g)\u00a0unsalted butter, softened to room temperature", "1 and 3/4 cups (219g)\u00a0all-purpose flour\u00a0(spooned &amp; leveled)", "2 teaspoons\u00a0baking powder", "1/2 teaspoon\u00a0salt", "1/2 cup (8 Tbsp; 113g)\u00a0unsalted butter, softened to room temperature", "1 cup\u00a0(200g)\u00a0granulated sugar", "1\u00a0and 1/2 Tablespoons\u00a0citrus zest (combination of lemon, orange, and lime or other, see note)", "2\u00a0large\u00a0eggs, at room temperature", "1\u00a0and 1/2 teaspoons\u00a0pure vanilla extract", "1/2 cup\u00a0(120ml)\u00a0whole milk, at room temperature", "1/3 cup\u00a0(80ml)\u00a0freshly squeezed citrus juice (combination of lemon, orange, and lime or other, see note)", "6 ounces\u00a0(170g) full-fat brick\u00a0cream cheese, softened to room temperature", "3/4 cup (90g) confectioners&#8217; sugar", "1\u00a0and 1/2 teaspoons\u00a0pure vanilla extract", "1 and 1/2 cups (360ml) cold heavy cream\u00a0or\u00a0heavy whipping cream\u00a0(very cold!)", "optional: sliced citrus fruits or citrus twists to garnish"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Fill the bottom pot of your\u00a0double boiler with 1-2 inches of water. (Or use the DIY double boiler method listed in the notes.) Place on high heat. Once the water begins to boil, reduce to low heat to keep the water at a simmer. Place egg yolks, egg, granulated sugar, lemon zest, lemon juice, and salt into the top pot of your double boiler. Using a silicone whisk (avoid metal because it leaves an aftertaste), whisk until completely blended and then continue to whisk as the curd cooks. Whisk and cook until the mixture becomes thick and is the consistency of hollandaise sauce or a really thick soup, about 10 minutes or when an instant read thermometer reaches 160\u00b0F (71\u00b0C). If curd isn\u2019t thickening, turn up the heat and constantly whisk. Remove pan from heat. Cut the butter into 6 separate pieces and then whisk into the curd until butter has melted and combined. Pour curd into a jar or bowl and place a piece of plastic wrap directly on top so it is touching the top of the curd. This prevents a skin from forming on top. The curd will continue to thicken as it cools. Place in refrigerator to speed up cooling. Once cool, the plastic wrap can be removed. Refrigerate the curd for up to about 10 days or for longer storage, you can freeze the cooled curd for up to 3-6 months. Thaw in the refrigerator overnight before enjoying. Makes 1 heaping cup.", "name": "Make the lemon curd:\u00a0", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/6-inch-citrus-cake/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat oven to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C). Grease three 6-inch round cake pans, line with parchment paper rounds, then grease the parchment paper. Parchment paper helps the cakes seamlessly release from the pans. (If it&#8217;s helpful, see this parchment paper rounds for cakes\u00a0video &amp; post.)", "name": "Make the cake", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/6-inch-citrus-cake/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Whisk the flour, baking powder, and salt together in a medium bowl. Set aside. Using a handheld or stand mixer fitted with a paddle or whisk attachment, beat the butter and sugar together on medium-high speed until combined, about 3 minutes. (Here\u2019s a helpful tutorial if you need guidance on\u00a0how to cream butter and sugar.) Scrape down the sides and up the bottom of the bowl with a silicone spatula and then add the citrus zest. Beat on medium-high speed until combined and creamy, about 2 minutes. Add the eggs and vanilla extract. Beat on medium-high speed until combined. Scrape down the sides and up the bottom of the bowl and beat again as needed to combine. Add half of the flour mixture (just eyeball it), half of the milk, and half of the citrus juice. Beat on low speed until mostly combined, and then add the remaining flour mixture, milk, and citrus juice. Beat on low speed until combined. Do not over-mix. You may need to whisk it all by hand to make sure there are no large lumps at the bottom of the bowl. The batter will be slightly thick with some small lumps. You will have between 3.5 &#8211; 4 cups of batter.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/6-inch-citrus-cake/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Divide and pour batter evenly into cake pans. If batter appears to have bubbles, give the pans a light tap on the counter to pop them. Bake cakes for 18-21 minutes or until baked through. To test for doneness, insert a toothpick into the center of the cake. If it comes out clean, it\u2019s done.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/6-inch-citrus-cake/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Allow cakes to cool completely in the pans set on a wire rack for 30 minutes. Remove cakes from the pans and set them on a wire rack to cool completely. The cakes must be completely cool before frosting and assembling.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/6-inch-citrus-cake/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a large bowl using a hand-held mixer or stand mixer fitted with a whisk or paddle attachment, beat the cream cheese on medium-high speed until creamy, about 1 minute. Scrape down the sides and up the bottom of the bowl and beat again as needed until creamy. Add the confectioners\u2019 sugar and vanilla extract, and then beat on medium speed until combined and completely smooth (absolutely no lumps), at least 2 full minutes. Scrape down the sides and up the bottom of the bowl and beat again as needed to smooth out. Switch to a whisk attachment (if you haven\u2019t already been using it). Turn the mixer to low speed and with the mixer running, carefully pour in the cream in a slow and steady stream. After all of the cream has been added, turn the mixer up to high speed and whip until thick and stiff peaks form, about 1-2 minutes. Do not walk away during this time and do not be concerned if your frosting takes longer to whip. You\u2019re looking for a thick, airy consistency with stiff peaks. If your frosting appears soupy now or at any point you are working with it, it needs more whipping to introduce more air. If your frosting appears chunky or curdled, it\u2019s over-whipped. To fix, stir 1 Tablespoon of heavy cream into the frosting by hand to smooth out again. You will have about 3.5 cups of frosting.", "name": "Make the whipped frosting:\u00a0", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/6-inch-citrus-cake/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Spoon 1 cup of frosting (about 240ml) into a separate bowl. Stir in 3 heaping Tablespoons of cooled lemon curd. This will be your filling for the cake. Enjoy remaining lemon curd drizzled on the cake slices or as a topping on other baked goods.", "name": "Make lemon curd frosting filling", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/6-inch-citrus-cake/#instruction-step-7"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "First, make sure you have enough room for the cake inside your refrigerator because it must chill at the end of this step and briefly in the next step as well. If the cake layers aren&#8217;t flat on top, carefully and slowly level them off using a large serrated knife. Discard (or crumble over ice cream!). Place 1 cake layer on your cake stand, cake turntable, or serving plate. Evenly cover the top with 1/2 of the lemon curd frosting. Top with 2nd cake layer and evenly cover the top with remaining lemon curd frosting (if you have extras, just use it on the exterior of the cake). Top with the third cake layer. Spread a very thin layer of regular whipped frosting on top and all around the sides of the cake to create a crumb coat. A bench scraper\u00a0and\u00a0small icing spatula are handy for this. Refrigerate uncovered for 30 minutes.", "name": "Assemble &amp; crumb coat the cake", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/6-inch-citrus-cake/#instruction-step-8"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Add remaining frosting on chilled crumb-coated cake using\u00a0a small icing spatula or a larger flat icing spatula. Use a bench scraper, if desired, to smooth out the sides. Refrigerate the decorated cake uncovered for at least 30 minutes to help set the frosting. After that, if you used a cake turntable, you can carefully transfer the cake to a cake stand or serving plate using a couple flat spatulas.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/6-inch-citrus-cake/#instruction-step-9"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "After 30 minutes in the refrigerator, the decorated cake is fine to slice and serve or sit out at room temperature for a few hours.\u00a0Cover leftover cake\u00a0tightly and store in the refrigerator for 5 days.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/6-inch-citrus-cake/#instruction-step-10"}], "prepTime": "PT1H", "cookTime": "PT20M", "totalTime": "PT5H20M", "recipeYield": ["8", "serves 8"], "recipeCategory": "Dessert", "cookingMethod": "Baking", "recipeCuisine": "American", "aggregateRating": {"@type": "AggregateRating", "reviewCount": "242", "ratingValue": "4.7"}, "video": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "VideoObject", "name": "Sunshine Citrus Cake | Sally's Baking Addiction", "description": "This video shows the process of making a homemade citrus layer cake. Slowly stir everything together using a silicone spatula or wooden spoon. If there are any lumps, gently use your whisk to rid them. The batter will be slightly thick.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/peanut-butter-chocolate-lava-cakes/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Spoon chocolate batter evenly into each prepared ramekin. The cakes should release easily from the ramekin. Top with ice cream and melted peanut butter and/or chocolate syrup for serving, if desired. Don't skip the glaze because it adds flavor; it also sets after a couple hours so the cookies are convenient to stack, store, and/or transport. Set aside enough time to chill the cookie dough in step 4.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "coconut lime cookies", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/05/coconut-and-lime-cookies-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/05/coconut-and-lime-cookies-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/05/coconut-and-lime-cookies-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/05/coconut-and-lime-cookies.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/coconut-lime-cookies/", "recipeIngredient": ["1 and 1/4 cups (100g) sweetened shredded coconut*", "2\u00a0and 1/2 cups (313g)\u00a0all-purpose flour\u00a0(spooned &amp; leveled)", "1 teaspoon cornstarch*", "1 teaspoon baking soda", "1/2 teaspoon salt", "3/4 cup (12 Tbsp; 170g)\u00a0unsalted butter, softened to room temperature", "1 and 1/2 cups (300g) granulated sugar, divided", "1 large egg, at room temperature", "1/4 cup (60ml) fresh or bottled lime juice (regular or key lime), at room temperature*", "2 teaspoons lime zest (regular or key lime)*", "1 teaspoon coconut extract", "1 cup (120g)\u00a0confectioners\u2019 sugar\u00a0(or more, as needed)", "2 Tablespoons (23ml)\u00a0fresh lime juice"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Pulse the coconut shreds in a food processor or chop them up with a sharp knife so they are finer. Smaller pieces make a more desirable texture in the baked cookies. Set aside for step 3.", "name": "Optional but recommended", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/coconut-lime-cookies/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Whisk the flour, cornstarch, baking soda, and salt together in a medium bowl. Set aside.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/coconut-lime-cookies/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a large bowl using a hand mixer or a stand mixer fitted with a paddle attachment, beat the butter and 1 cup (200g) granulated sugar together on medium-high speed until creamed, about 3 minutes. (Here\u2019s a helpful tutorial if you need guidance on\u00a0how to cream butter and sugar.) Add the egg, lime juice, lime zest, and coconut extract and beat on high speed until combined, about 1 minute. Mixture will appear curdled and that&#8217;s ok. Scrape down the sides and up the bottom of the bowl. Turn the mixer down to medium speed and beat in the coconut. Add the dry ingredients and beat on low speed until combined. Dough is thick, creamy, and sticky.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/coconut-lime-cookies/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cover and chill the cookie dough in the refrigerator for at least 1.5 hours (and up to 4 days). If chilling for longer than a few hours, allow to sit at room temperature for 15 minutes before rolling and baking because the dough will be quite firm.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/coconut-lime-cookies/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat oven to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C). Line baking sheets with parchment paper or silicone baking mats. Set aside.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/coconut-lime-cookies/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Pour remaining sugar into a large bowl. (Here\u2019s a helpful tutorial if you need guidance on how to cream butter and sugar.) Scrape down the sides and bottom of the bowl with a silicone spatula as needed. So I use salted butter (which adds 1/8 tsp per stick of butter) and also double what the recipe calls for. (1 tsp)"}, {"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "CC"}, "datePublished": "2025-11-04", "reviewBody": "These were so delicious! Sally\u2019s work has been featured on TODAY, Good Morning America, Taste of Home, People, and more.", "sameAs": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"]}, {"@context": "https://schema.org/", "@type": "Recipe", "name": "Cinnamon Swirl Cheesecake", "description": "Two favorite indulgences come together to make one epic dessert in this cinnamon-roll inspired cheesecake. Swirl crumbles of buttery cinnamon-brown sugar filling into layers of rich, creamy cheesecake, and bake atop a thick graham cracker crust. Top with brown sugar whipped cream and a sprinkle of cinnamon for the perfect finishing touch.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally McKenney", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "cinnamon swirl cheesecake", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/04/cinnamon-swirl-cheeescake-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/04/cinnamon-swirl-cheeescake-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/04/cinnamon-swirl-cheeescake-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/04/cinnamon-swirl-cheeescake.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/cinnamon-swirl-cheesecake/", "recipeIngredient": ["1 and 1/2 cups (180g) graham cracker crumbs (about 12 full-sheet graham crackers)", "1/4 cup (50g) granulated sugar", "5 Tablespoons (71g) unsalted butter, melted", "32 ounces (904g) full-fat brick cream cheese, softened to room temperature", "1 cup (200g) granulated sugar\u00a0", "3/4 cup (180g) full-fat sour cream, at room temperature", "1 and 1/2 teaspoons vanilla extract or vanilla bean paste", "3 large eggs, at room temperature", "3/4 cup (150g) packed light or dark brown sugar", "1/2 cup (60g) all-purpose flour", "1 Tablespoon ground cinnamon", "5 Tablespoons (71g) unsalted butter, melted", "1 and 1/2 cups heavy cream, cold", "2 Tablespoons light or dark brown sugar", "1 teaspoon pure vanilla extract", "optional: ground cinnamon, for garnish"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Adjust the oven rack to the lower-middle position, and preheat oven to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C).", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/cinnamon-swirl-cheesecake/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "If you\u2019re starting out with full graham crackers, use a\u00a0food processor or blender to grind them into fine crumbs. Pour into a medium bowl and stir in sugar until combined, and then stir in the melted butter. Mixture will be sandy. Try to smash/break up any large chunks.\u00a0Pour into an ungreased 9-inch or 10-inch springform pan. With medium pressure using your hand, pat the crumbs down into the bottom and partly up the sides to make a compact crust. Do not pack down with heavy force because that makes the crust too hard. Simply pat down until the mixture is no longer crumbly; you can use the flat bottom of a small measuring cup to help smooth it all out if needed. Pre-bake for 10 minutes. Remove from the oven and place the hot pan on a large piece of heavy-duty aluminum foil (use a double layer for extra protection, if desired). You will wrap the foil around the pan in step 5. Allow crust to slightly cool as you prepare the filling.", "name": "Make the crust", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/cinnamon-swirl-cheesecake/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Using a handheld or stand mixer fitted with a paddle attachment, beat the cream cheese and sugar together on medium-high speed in a large bowl until the mixture is smooth and creamy, about 2 minutes. Add the sour cream and vanilla and then beat until fully combined. Scrape down the sides of the bowl as needed. Add the eggs one at a time, beating on medium speed after each addition until just incorporated. After the final egg is incorporated into the batter, stop mixing. To help prevent the cheesecake from deflating and cracking, avoid over-mixing the batter as best you can.", "name": "Make the cheesecake", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/cinnamon-swirl-cheesecake/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a medium bowl, using a fork, mix together the brown sugar, flour, and cinnamon until combined. Add the melted butter and mix until everything comes together. The mixture will be sandy and crumbly.", "name": "Make the cinnamon swirl filling:\u00a0", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/cinnamon-swirl-cheesecake/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Wrap the aluminum foil around the springform pan.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/cinnamon-swirl-cheesecake/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Pour about a third of the cheesecake batter into the crust (you can eyeball it; this doesn&#8217;t need to be exact). Use a spatula or spoon to smooth it into an even layer. Sprinkle about half of the cinnamon swirl mixture over the top. Pour another third of the cheesecake batter over top of the cinnamon swirl layer, then sprinkle on most of the remaining cinnamon swirl mixture, reserving a couple Tablespoons for the topping. Finally, pour the remaining cheesecake batter over top and smooth it into an even layer. Sprinkle with remaining cinnamon mixture. With a knife, gently swirl the layers of batter and cinnamon filling together. I like to swirl it in a spiral, like a cinnamon roll (though you really can&#8217;t tell when it&#8217;s done baking, so swirl in any way you like!).", "name": "Assemble the cheesecake", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/cinnamon-swirl-cheesecake/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "If needed for extra visuals, see\u00a0How to Make a Cheesecake Water Bath; the visual guide will assist you in this step. Boil a kettle of water. You need 1 inch of water in your roasting pan for the water bath, so make sure you boil enough. I use an entire kettle of hot water. Place the wrapped pan inside of a large roasting pan. Carefully pour the hot water inside of the pan and place in the oven. (Or you can place the roasting pan in the oven first, then pour the hot water in. Whichever is easier for you.)", "name": "Prepare the water bath (see recipe Notes for alternate water bath method)", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/cinnamon-swirl-cheesecake/#instruction-step-7"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake cheesecake for 65\u201385 minutes or until the edges are set. Don&#8217;t get nervous if your cheesecake takes longer than this. When it&#8217;s done, the center of the cheesecake will slightly wobble if you gently shake the pan.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/cinnamon-swirl-cheesecake/#instruction-step-8"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Turn the oven off and open the oven door slightly. Let the cheesecake sit in the oven, door slightly ajar, as it cools down for 1 hour. Remove from the oven, then cool cheesecake completely at room temperature. Then, refrigerate the cheesecake for at least 4 hours or overnight.", "name": "Cool &amp; chill the cheesecake", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/cinnamon-swirl-cheesecake/#instruction-step-9"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Using a\u00a0handheld\u00a0or\u00a0stand mixer fitted with a whisk attachment, whip the heavy cream, brown sugar, and vanilla on medium-high speed until medium peaks form, about 3\u20134 minutes. Medium peaks are between soft/loose peaks and stiff peaks, and are the perfect consistency for topping and piping on desserts.\u00a0", "name": "Make the whipped cream topping", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/cinnamon-swirl-cheesecake/#instruction-step-10"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Use a knife to loosen the chilled cheesecake from the rim of the springform pan, then remove the rim. Spread a layer of whipped cream over top of the cheesecake (I use an offset spatula) and, if desired, you can transfer some to a piping bag and pipe a design on top. I used Wilton 1M piping tip for the pictured whipped cream border. Lightly dust cinnamon on top, if using. Using a sharp knife, cut into slices for serving. For neat slices, wipe the knife clean and dip into warm water between each slice.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/cinnamon-swirl-cheesecake/#instruction-step-11"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cover and store leftover cheesecake in the refrigerator for up to 5 days.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/cinnamon-swirl-cheesecake/#instruction-step-12"}], "prepTime": "PT50M", "cookTime": "PT1H15M", "totalTime": "PT8H", "recipeYield": ["12", "serves 12-16"], "recipeCategory": "Dessert", "cookingMethod": "Baking", "recipeCuisine": "American", "aggregateRating": {"@type": "AggregateRating", "reviewCount": "417", "ratingValue": "4.9"}, "review": [{"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sheri M Venturelli"}, "datePublished": "2025-11-25", "reviewBody": "The cinnamon swirl cheesecake is literally the best thing I have ever tasted (and I don't like cheesecake LOL). AMAZING. A lot easier to make than I thought it would be. But I didn't like that a little bit of water still leaked through the foil (I used heavy duty foil, two layers). So now I have a springform pan with a silicone wrap that should keep everything watertight. Everybody loved this cheesecake. I'm making more for Christmas!"}], "datePublished": "2025-05-01", "@id": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/cinnamon-swirl-cheesecake/#recipe", "isPartOf": {"@id": Watch the video tutorial below and review the recipe instructions and recipe notes prior to beginning. If you\u2019re new to working with yeast, reference my Baking with Yeast Guide\u00a0for answers to common yeast FAQs.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "bread, loaf", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/homemade-artisan-bread-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/homemade-artisan-bread-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/homemade-artisan-bread-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/homemade-artisan-bread.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-artisan-bread/", "recipeIngredient": ["3 and 1/4 cups (about 430g) bread flour (spooned &amp; leveled), plus more for hands and pan", "2 teaspoons (about 6g) instant yeast", "2 teaspoons (about 9g) coarse salt (see note)", "1 and 1/2 cups (360ml) water, close to room temperature at about 70\u00b0F (21\u00b0C)", "optional: cornmeal for dusting pan"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a large ungreased mixing bowl, whisk the flour, yeast, and salt together. Pour in the water and gently mix together with a silicone spatula or wooden spoon. The dough will seem dry and shaggy, but keep working it until all the flour is moistened. If needed, use your hands (as I do in the video tutorial below) to work the dough ingredients together. The dough will be sticky. Shape into a ball in the bowl as best you can.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-artisan-bread/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Keeping the dough in the bowl, cover the dough tightly with plastic wrap or aluminum foil and set on the counter at room temperature (honestly any normal room temperature is fine!). Allow to rise for 2-3 hours. The dough will just about double in size, stick to the sides of the bowl, and have a lot of air bubbles.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-artisan-bread/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "You can continue with step 4 immediately, but for absolute best flavor and texture, I strongly recommend letting this risen dough rest in the refrigerator for at least 12 hours and up to 3 days. Place covered dough in the refrigerator for 12 hours &#8211; 3 days. I usually let it rest in the refrigerator for about 18 hours. The dough will puff up during this time, but may begin to deflate after 2 days. That&#8217;s fine and normal\u2014nothing to worry about.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-artisan-bread/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Lightly dust a large nonstick baking sheet (with or without rims and make sure it&#8217;s nonstick) with flour and/or cornmeal. Turn the cold dough out onto a floured work surface. Using a sharp knife or bench scraper, cut dough in half. Some air bubbles will deflate as you work with it. Place dough halves on prepared baking sheet. Using floured hands, shape into 2 long loaves about 9&#215;3 inches each (doesn&#8217;t have to be exact) about 3 inches apart. Loosely cover and allow to rest for 45 minutes. You will bake the dough on this prepared baking sheet.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-artisan-bread/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "During this 45 minutes, preheat the oven to 475\u00b0F (246\u00b0C).", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-artisan-bread/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "When ready to bake, using a very sharp knife or bread lame (some even use kitchen shears), score the bread loaves with 3 slashes, about 1/2 inch deep. (&#8220;Score&#8221; = shallow cut.) If the shaped loaves flattened out during the 45 minutes, use floured hands to narrow them out along the sides again.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-artisan-bread/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Optional for a slightly crispier crust: After the oven is preheated and bread is scored, place a shallow metal or cast iron baking pan or skillet (I usually use a metal 9&#215;13-inch baking pan) on the bottom oven rack. Carefully and quickly pour 3-4 cups of boiling water into it. Place the scored dough/baking pan on a higher rack and quickly shut the oven, trapping the steam inside. The steam helps create a crispier crust.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-artisan-bread/#instruction-step-7"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Place the shaped and scored dough (on the flour/cornmeal dusted pan) in the preheated oven on the center rack. Bake for 20-25 minutes or until the crust is golden brown. Gently tap the loaves\u2014if they sound hollow, the bread is done. For a more accurate test of doneness, the bread is done when an instant read thermometer inserted in the center reads 195\u00b0F (90\u00b0C).", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-artisan-bread/#instruction-step-8"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Remove the bread from the oven and allow to cool for at least 20 minutes before slicing and serving. Store leftovers loosely covered at room temperature for up to 5 days or in the refrigerator for up to 1 week.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-artisan-bread/#instruction-step-9"}], "prepTime": "PT4H", "cookTime": "PT25M", "totalTime": "PT4H25M", "recipeYield": ["2", "2 8-inch loaves"], "recipeCategory": "Bread", "cookingMethod": "Baking", "recipeCuisine": "American", "aggregateRating": {"@type": "AggregateRating", "reviewCount": "1084", "ratingValue": "4.8"}, "nutrition": {"servingSize": "2 slices", "calories": "136 calories", "sugarContent": "0.1 g", "sodiumContent": "389.8 mg", "fatContent": "0.7 g", "saturatedFatContent": "0.1 g", "transFatContent": "0 g", "carbohydrateContent": "27.2 g", "fiberContent": "1.1 g", "proteinContent": "4.7 g", "cholesterolContent": "0 mg", "@type": "nutritionInformation"}, "video": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "VideoObject", "name": "Homemade Artisan Bread (4 Ingredients) | Sally's Baking", "description": "If you\u2019ve never made homemade bread or worked with yeast before, this homemade crusty artisan bread is for you. Set aside.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/cream-cheese-cookies-nutella-glaze/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a large bowl using a handheld or stand mixer fitted with a paddle attachment, beat the butter and cream cheese together on medium-high speed until completely smooth and creamy, about 2 minutes. Add the granulated sugar and beat until mixture is fluffy and combined, about 1 minute. Add the egg, vanilla extract, and almond extract and beat on high speed until combined, about 1 minute. Scrape down the sides and up the bottom of the bowl and beat again as needed to combine.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/cream-cheese-cookies-nutella-glaze/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Add the dry ingredients to the wet ingredients and mix on low speed until combined. Dough will be very soft and creamy.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/cream-cheese-cookies-nutella-glaze/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Generously flour your hands and rolling pin. Divide the dough into 2 equal parts. Roll each portion out on a lightly floured piece of parchment paper or silicone baking mat to about 1/4-inch thickness. The rolled-out dough can be any shape, as long as it is evenly 1/4-inch thick.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/cream-cheese-cookies-nutella-glaze/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Lightly dust one of the rolled-out doughs with flour. Place a piece of parchment on top. (This prevents sticking.) Place the 2nd rolled-out dough on top. Cover with plastic wrap or aluminum foil, then refrigerate for at least 2 hours and up to 2 days.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/cream-cheese-cookies-nutella-glaze/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Once chilled, preheat oven to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C). Line 2-3 large baking sheets with parchment paper or silicone baking mats. Carefully remove the top dough piece from the refrigerator. If it\u2019s sticking to the bottom, run your hand under it to help remove it. Using a cookie cutter, cut the dough into shapes. (I like these heart cookie cutters.) Re-roll the remaining dough and continue cutting until all is used. Repeat with 2nd piece of dough. Note: It doesn\u2019t seem like a lot of dough, but you get a lot of cookies from the dough scraps you re-roll.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/cream-cheese-cookies-nutella-glaze/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Arrange cookies on baking sheets 3 inches apart. Bake for 12-13 minutes until very lightly browned around the edges. If your oven has hot spots, rotate the baking sheet halfway through bake time. Allow cookies to cool on the baking sheet for 5 minutes then transfer to a wire rack to cool completely before decorating. I like to decorate the cookies directly on baking sheets so I can stick the entire baking sheet in the refrigerator to help set the Nutella glaze. If you&#8217;d like to do it that way, place the cooled cookies back on baking sheets.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/cream-cheese-cookies-nutella-glaze/#instruction-step-7"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a medium\u00a0bowl using a handheld mixer or stand mixer fitted with a whisk attachment, beat all of the ingredients together on medium-high speed until creamy and smooth, about 2 minutes. Taste. Add another pinch of salt if frosting is too sweet. Spread on each cooled cookie then decorate with hazelnuts, if desired. Nutella glaze will set at room temperature after 3-4 hours and even quicker in the refrigerator, about 1 hour.", "name": "Make the glaze", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/cream-cheese-cookies-nutella-glaze/#instruction-step-8"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cookies stay fresh covered at room temperature for up to 3 days or in the refrigerator for up to 1\u00a0week.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/cream-cheese-cookies-nutella-glaze/#instruction-step-9"}], "prepTime": "PT3H30M", "cookTime": "PT13M", "totalTime": "PT3H45M", "recipeYield": ["36", "36 3-inch cookies"], "recipeCategory": "Cookies", "cookingMethod": "Baking", "recipeCuisine": "American", "aggregateRating": {"@type": "AggregateRating", "reviewCount": "34", "ratingValue": "4.8"}, "review": [{"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Paula"}, "datePublished": "2022-07-25", "reviewBody": "Delicious cookies! Enjoy!\u00a0", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "angel food cake", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/05/angel-food-cake-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/05/angel-food-cake-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/05/angel-food-cake-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/05/angel-food-cake.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/angel-food-cake/", "recipeIngredient": ["1 and 3/4 cups (350g) granulated sugar*", "1 cup + 2 Tablespoons (133g) cake flour (spooned &amp; leveled)", "1/4 teaspoon salt", "12 large egg whites, at room temperature*", "1 and 1/2 teaspoons cream of tartar", "1 and 1/2 teaspoons pure vanilla extract", "optional: confectioners&#8217; sugar for dusting, whipped cream, and berries"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Adjust the oven rack to the lower middle position and preheat oven to 325\u00b0F (163\u00b0C).", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/angel-food-cake/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a food processor or blender, pulse the sugar until fine and powdery. Remove 1 cup and set aside to use in step 3; keep the rest inside the food processor. Add the cake flour and salt to the food processor. Pulse 5-10 times until sugar/flour/salt mixture is aerated and light.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/angel-food-cake/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a large bowl using a hand mixer or a stand mixer fitted with a whisk attachment, whip egg whites and cream of tartar together on medium-low until foamy, about 1 minute. Switch to medium-high and slowly add the 1 cup of sugar you set aside. Whip until soft peaks form, about 5-6 minutes. See photo and video above for a visual. Add the vanilla extract, then beat just until incorporated.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/angel-food-cake/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In 3 additions, slowly sift the flour mixture into the egg white mixture using a fine mesh strainer, gently folding with a rubber spatula after each addition. To avoid deflating or a dense cake, don\u2019t add the flour mixture all at once. Sift and very slowly fold in several additions. This is important! Pour and spread batter into an ungreased 9 or 10 inch tube pan. Shimmy the pan on the counter to smooth down the surface.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/angel-food-cake/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake the cake until a toothpick inserted comes out clean, about 40-45 minutes. Rotate the pan halfway through baking. The cake will rise up very tall while baking. Remove from the oven, then cool the cake completely upside-down set on a wire rack, about 3 hours. (Alternatively, you can temper the chocolate.) If using the microwave: place the chocolate in a medium heat-proof bowl. I like to use a liquid measuring cup. Its depth\u00a0makes it easier for dipping. This biscuit recipe only requires 7 simple ingredients and they're ready in about 35 minutes.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "homemade biscuits", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/10/biscuit-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/10/biscuit-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/10/biscuit-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/10/biscuit.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/flaky-buttermilk-biscuits/", "recipeIngredient": ["2 and 1/2 cups (313g) all-purpose flour (spooned &amp; leveled), plus more as needed for hands and work surface", "1 Tablespoon baking powder (see Note)", "1/2 teaspoon baking soda (see Note)", "1 teaspoon salt", "1/2 cup (8 Tbsp; 113g) unsalted butter, cubed and very cold", "1 cup + 2 Tablespoons (270ml/g) cold buttermilk, divided", "2 teaspoons (14g)\u00a0honey", "2 Tablespoons (28g)\u00a0butter, melted", "1 Tablespoon (21g) honey"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat oven to 425\u00b0F (218\u00b0C).", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/flaky-buttermilk-biscuits/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Place the flour, baking powder, baking soda, and salt in a large bowl or in a large food processor. Whisk or pulse until combined. Add the cubed butter and cut into the dry ingredients with a pastry cutter or by pulsing several times in the processor. Cut/pulse until coarse crumbs form.", "name": "Make the biscuits", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/flaky-buttermilk-biscuits/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "If you used a food processor, pour the mixture into a large bowl. Make a well in the center. Pour 1 cup (240ml/g) buttermilk into the well and drizzle honey on top. Using a large spoon or spatula, fold until it begins to come together. Do not overwork the dough. The dough will be shaggy and crumbly with some wet spots.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/flaky-buttermilk-biscuits/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Pour the dough and any dough crumbles onto a floured work surface and gently bring together with generously floured hands. The dough will become sticky as you bring it together. Have extra flour nearby and use it often to flour your hands and work surface as needed in this step. Using floured hands, flatten into a 3/4-inch-thick rectangle as best you can. Fold one side into the center, then the other side on top. Turn the dough 90 degrees, so it&#8217;s now horizontal. Gently flatten into a 3/4-inch-thick rectangle again. Repeat the folding again. Turn the dough horizontally one more time. Gently flatten into a 3/4-inch-thick rectangle. Repeat the folding one last time. Flatten into the final 3/4-inch-thick rectangle.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/flaky-buttermilk-biscuits/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cut into 2.5- or 3-inch circles with a biscuit cutter. (Tip: Do not twist the biscuit cutter when pressing down into the dough because this seals off the edges of the biscuit which prevents them from fully rising.) Re-roll scraps until all the dough is used. You should have about 8\u201311 biscuits. Arrange in a 10-inch cast iron skillet (see Note) or close together on a parchment paper-lined baking sheet. Make sure the biscuits are touching.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/flaky-buttermilk-biscuits/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Brush the tops with remaining buttermilk. Bake for 18\u201320 minutes or until tops are golden brown.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/flaky-buttermilk-biscuits/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Remove from the oven. Sally\u2019s work has been featured on TODAY, Good Morning America, Taste of Home, People, and more.", "sameAs": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"]}, {"@type": "Question", "@id": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-brioche/#faq-question-1755465721549", "position": 1, "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-brioche/#faq-question-1755465721549", "name": "Should I use European-style butter in homemade brioche?", "answerCount": 1, "acceptedAnswer": {"@type": "Answer", "text": "You can use either American or European butter in brioche. European butter has a touch more butterfat (about 82\u201385% compared to 80% in American), so the flavor is a little richer and creamier. That extra bit can really shine in a bread like brioche, which is already loaded with butter, eggs, and milk. That said, the difference isn\u2019t huge. If European butter is what you have, go for it! Otherwise, American butter will bake up a perfectly soft, fluffy loaf. It's what we used in many test loaves.", "inLanguage": "en-US"}, "inLanguage": "en-US"}, {"@type": "Question", "@id": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-brioche/#faq-question-1755514133010", "position": 2, "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-brioche/#faq-question-1755514133010", "name": "Can I bake the brioche dough into rolls?", "answerCount": 1, "acceptedAnswer": {"@type": "Answer", "text": "Yes, absolutely. You can divide the dough into 12 smaller rolls, rather than 6 larger pieces. Arrange the shaped rolls in a greased 9x13-inch pan. Proceed with step 8 below. Shorten the bake time to around 25\u201328 minutes. You can also bake the rolls separated on a lined baking sheet; this style produces excellent hamburger and sandwich buns. See recipe Note below.", "inLanguage": "en-US"}, "inLanguage": "en-US"}, {"@type": "Question", "@id": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-brioche/#faq-question-1755514274258", "position": 3, "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-brioche/#faq-question-1755514274258", "name": "Can I braid this brioche dough?", "answerCount": 1, "acceptedAnswer": {"@type": "Answer", "text": "My team and I tested this dough in a braided design in the loaf pan. The finished bread was considerably dense, due to the tight braiding technique. For the tallest, fluffiest brioche, I recommend the <em>brioche nanterre</em> shape instructed in the recipe below.", "inLanguage": "en-US"}, "inLanguage": "en-US"}, {"@context": "https://schema.org/", "@type": "Recipe", "name": "Homemade Brioche", "description": "Learn how to make homemade brioche, an irresistibly rich, buttery bread with a soft, tender crumb. This recipe is a 2-day baking project, since the dough rests in the refrigerator overnight to lower its temperature, as well as develop proper flavor and texture. A stand mixer fitted with a dough hook is essential for best success. Be sure to use cold milk, eggs, and butter. Reference my Baking with Yeast Guide for answers to common yeast FAQs.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "brioche", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/brioche-bread-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/brioche-bread-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/brioche-bread-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/brioche-bread.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-brioche/", "recipeIngredient": ["3 and 1/4 cups (423g) bread flour\u00a0(spooned &amp; leveled), plus more as needed", "2 and 1/4 teaspoons (7g) active dry or instant yeast (1 standard packet)", "1/4 cup (50g) granulated sugar", "1 and 1/2 teaspoons salt", "1/2 cup (120ml) whole milk, cold", "3 large eggs, cold", "1/2 cup (113g; 8 Tbsp) unsalted butter, cold", "egg wash: 1 large egg beaten with 1 Tablespoon (15ml) milk"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In the bowl of a stand mixer fitted with a dough hook attachment, whisk together the flour, yeast, sugar, and salt. Add the milk and eggs, and mix on medium-low speed for 3 full minutes, until the dough comes together and forms a rough mass around the dough hook. It will be shaggy at first, but just keep mixing until it comes together. Stop the mixer and scrape down the sides of the bowl as needed.", "name": "Make the dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-brioche/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Increase the speed to medium and let the mixer run for 8\u201310 minutes. Do not shorten this time. The dough should wrap itself around the dough hook and be slapping the sides of the bowl. If that isn&#8217;t the case after about 8 minutes, add a little more flour, 1 Tbsp at a time, and keep mixing.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-brioche/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Place a sheet of parchment paper on a sturdy cutting board. Cut the cold butter into 8 equal pieces. Lay the pieces out on the parchment. Place a second sheet of parchment paper on top of the butter. Using a rolling pin, pound the butter to flatten it to about 1/16th of an inch thickness, or about 2mm. If the dough is not yet ready for the next step, transfer the butter, still between the sheets of parchment, to the refrigerator. The butter must be cold.", "name": "Plasticize the butter", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-brioche/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "With the mixer running on medium-low speed, add the butter, 2 pieces at a time. Use a knife or offset spatula to scrape the pieces of butter off the parchment paper and add them to the mixing bowl. Wait until the butter has completely incorporated into the dough before you add the next 2 pieces\u2014this can take about 2 minutes. If the butter gets stuck to the side of the bowl, stop the mixer and scrape it down with a spatula. Once all 8 pieces of butter have been added, increase the speed to medium and let the mixer run for another 2 minutes (again, the dough should be slapping the sides of the bowl), until the dough is smooth, shiny, and elastic. It will be very soft.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-brioche/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Grease a large bowl with butter, oil, or nonstick spray. Shape the dough into a ball and place it in the bowl, turning it to coat the dough in the butter/oil. Cover tightly and refrigerate for at least 12\u201316 hours, or up to 48 hours.", "name": "Refrigerate the dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-brioche/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Grease a 9&#215;5-inch loaf pan.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-brioche/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Remove the dough from the refrigerator and turn it out onto a lightly floured surface. Divide the dough into 6 equal pieces.\u00a0A bench scraper is always helpful for cutting dough. (Tip: If you have a kitchen scale, weigh the dough, then divide that number by 6 so you know how much each piece of dough should weigh. For example, if the dough weighs 850g, aim for each piece of dough to weigh around 140\u2013145g.) Shape each piece into a smooth ball, and place in the prepared loaf pan, staggering the dough balls in a zigzag pattern.", "name": "Shape the brioche", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-brioche/#instruction-step-7"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cover the loaf lightly and let it rise at room temperature for 1.5 to 2 hours until it&#8217;s puffy and just reaches the rim of the pan.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-brioche/#instruction-step-8"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Adjust an oven rack to a lower position and preheat the oven to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C).\u00a0", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-brioche/#instruction-step-9"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "When the brioche has risen to the rim of the pan, brush the top of the loaf with egg wash. Bake for 35\u201340 minutes, until golden brown on top. For a more accurate test, insert an instant-read thermometer into the brioche; it&#8217;s done when the internal temperature reaches 195\u00b0F (91\u00b0C). If you notice the top browning too quickly, loosely tent the pan with aluminum foil. (I always tent aluminum foil over the loaf around the 20-minute mark.)", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-brioche/#instruction-step-10"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Let the brioche cool in the pan set on a cooling rack for at least 10 minutes, then carefully flip the bread out of the pan and onto the rack to continue cooling. Cool for at least 1 hour before slicing. (The crumb sets as it cools, giving you neat, fluffy slices\u2014but if you sneak a warm piece, just know it\u2019ll be extra soft!)", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-brioche/#instruction-step-11"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cover leftover brioche tightly and store at room temperature for up to 5 days or in the refrigerator for up to 1 week.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-brioche/#instruction-step-12"}], "prepTime": "PT15H", "cookTime": "PT40M", "totalTime": "PT15H40M", "recipeYield": ["1", "1 loaf; 8-10 slices"], "recipeCategory": "Bread", "cookingMethod": "Baking", "recipeCuisine": "French", "aggregateRating": {"@type": "AggregateRating", "reviewCount": "11", "ratingValue": "4.9"}, "video": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "VideoObject", "name": "Homemade Brioche | Sally's Baking", "description": "Learn how to make homemade brioche, an irresistibly rich, buttery bread with a soft, tender crumb. https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/multigrain-bread/	[{"@context": "https://schema.org", "@graph": [{"@type": "Article", "@id": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/multigrain-bread/#article", "isPartOf": {"@id": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/multigrain-bread/"}, "author": {"name": "Sally McKenney", "@id": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/#/schema/person/3744271f85efc7e271411c4968f1c4ba"}, "headline": "Soft Multigrain Bread", "datePublished": "2021-01-25T05:00:09+00:00", "dateModified": "2025-04-04T17:41:01+00:00", "wordCount": 1359, "commentCount": 921, "publisher": {"@id": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/#organization"}, "image": {"@id": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/multigrain-bread/#primaryimage"}, "thumbnailUrl": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/01/multigrain-bread-loaf-2.jpg", "keywords": ["bread flour", "brown sugar", "butter", "multigrain cereal", "oats", "sunflower seeds", "yeast"], "articleSection": ["Bread", "Intermediate", "Nut Free", "Videos", "Yeast Bread"], "inLanguage": "en-US", "potentialAction": [{"@type": "CommentAction", "name": "Comment", "target": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/multigrain-bread/#respond"]}]}, {"@type": "WebPage", "@id": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/multigrain-bread/", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/multigrain-bread/", "name": "Homemade Soft Multigrain Bread - Sally&#039;s Baking", "isPartOf": {"@id": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/#website"}, "primaryImageOfPage": {"@id": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/multigrain-bread/#primaryimage"}, "image": {"@id": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/multigrain-bread/#primaryimage"}, "thumbnailUrl": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/01/multigrain-bread-loaf-2.jpg", "datePublished": "2021-01-25T05:00:09+00:00", "dateModified": "2025-04-04T17:41:01+00:00", "description": "This homemade soft multigrain bread is prepared with multigrain hot cereal mix, such as 7 grain cereal.
