For best success, take the time to review the recipe notes before starting. Though not required, an instant read thermometer is helpful in a few of these steps.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "multigrain, bread, homemade bread", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/01/multigrain-bread-loaf-2-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/01/multigrain-bread-loaf-2-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/01/multigrain-bread-loaf-2-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/01/multigrain-bread-loaf-2.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/multigrain-bread/", "recipeIngredient": ["1/2 cup (60g) dry multigrain cereal mix or old-fashioned whole\u00a0rolled oats (see note)", "1 and 3/4 cups (410ml) boiling water", "2 and 1/4 teaspoons (7g) instant or active dry yeast\u00a0(1 standard packet)", "3 Tablespoons (37g) packed light or dark brown sugar", "3 Tablespoons (43g) unsalted butter, softened to room temperature", "1 and 1/2 teaspoons salt", "3 and 1/3 cups (433g) bread flour (spooned and leveled), plus more as needed and for hands/work surface", "optional: 1/2 cup (60g) sunflower seeds, chopped nuts, pepitas, raisins, or dried cranberries"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Place cereal mix in a large heatproof bowl (you can also use the bowl of your stand mixer). Pour boiling water on top. Let the mixture cool until a digital thermometer reads about 110\u00b0F (43\u00b0C). This usually takes 20 minutes. Pay attention to the temperature because if it&#8217;s too hot, it will kill the yeast. If it became too cool, however, it&#8217;s not a problem\u2014the dough may just take a few extra minutes to rise.", "name": "Prepare the dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/multigrain-bread/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Whisk the yeast, sugar, and all of the warm water/cereal mixture in the bowl of your stand mixer fitted with a dough hook or paddle attachment. Cover and allow to sit for 5-10 minutes or until foamy and bubbly on the surface.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/multigrain-bread/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Add the butter, salt, and 1 cup (about 130g) flour. Beat on low speed for 30 seconds, scrape down the sides of the bowl with a silicone spatula, then add another cup of flour. Beat on medium speed until relatively incorporated (there may still be chunks of butter). Add all of the remaining flour and the seeds/nuts (if using), then beat on medium speed until the dough comes together and pulls away from the sides of the bowl, about 2 minutes. If it seems too sticky, add more flour, 1 Tablespoon at a time until it begins to pull away from the sides of the bowl. *If you do not own a mixer, you can mix this dough with a large wooden spoon or silicone spatula. It will take a bit of arm muscle!*", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/multigrain-bread/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "\u00a0Keep the dough in the mixer and beat for an additional 3-5 full minutes, or knead by hand on a lightly floured surface for 3-5 full minutes. (If you\u2019re new to bread-baking, my How to Knead Dough video tutorial can help here.) If the dough becomes too sticky during the kneading process, sprinkle 1 teaspoon of flour at a time on the dough or on the work surface/in the bowl to make a soft, slightly tacky dough. Do not add more flour than you need because you do not want a dry dough. After kneading, the dough should still feel a little soft. Poke it with your finger\u2014if it slowly bounces back, your dough is ready to rise. You can also do a \u201cwindowpane test\u201d to see if your dough has been kneaded long enough: tear off a small (roughly golfball-size) piece of dough and gently stretch it out until it\u2019s thin enough for light to pass through it. Hold it up to a window or light. Does light pass through the stretched dough without the dough tearing first? If so, your dough has been kneaded long enough and is ready to rise. If not, keep kneading until it passes the windowpane test.", "name": "Knead the dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/multigrain-bread/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "\u00a0Lightly grease a large bowl with olive oil or nonstick spray. Place the dough in the bowl, turning it to coat all sides in the oil. Cover the bowl with aluminum foil, plastic wrap, or a clean kitchen towel. Allow the dough to rise in a relatively warm environment for 1-2 hours or until double in size. (I always let it rise on the counter. Takes about 2 hours. For a tiny reduction in rise time, see my answer to\u00a0Where Should Dough Rise?\u00a0in my\u00a0Baking with Yeast Guide.)", "name": "1st Rise", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/multigrain-bread/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Grease a 9\u00d75-inch loaf pan.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/multigrain-bread/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "When the dough is ready, punch it down to release the air. Lightly flour a work surface, your hands, and a rolling pin. Roll the dough out into a large rectangle, about 8\u00d715 inches. It does not have to be perfect\u2013 in fact, it will probably be rounded on the edges. That\u2019s ok! Roll it up into an 8 inch log and place in the prepared loaf pan.", "name": "Shape the bread:\u00a0", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/multigrain-bread/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cover shaped loaf with aluminum foil, plastic wrap, or a clean kitchen towel. Allow to rise until it\u2019s about 1-2 inches above the top of the loaf pan, about 1 hour. (See photo above for a visual.)", "name": "2nd Rise:\u00a0", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/multigrain-bread/#instruction-step-7"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Adjust oven rack to a lower position and preheat oven to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C).\u00a0(It\u2019s best to bake the bread towards the bottom of the oven so the top doesn\u2019t burn.)", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/multigrain-bread/#instruction-step-8"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake for 35-40 minutes&#8211; if you notice the top browning too quickly during bake time, loosely tent the pan with aluminum foil. How to test for doneness&#8211; give the loaf a light tap. If it sounds hollow, it&#8217;s done. For a more accurate test, the bread is done when an instant read thermometer reads the center of the loaf as 195\u00b0F-200\u00b0F (90\u00b0C-93\u00b0C).", "name": "Bake the bread", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/multigrain-bread/#instruction-step-9"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Remove from the oven and allow bread to cool for a few minutes before slicing and serving. The dough may become a little wet from the added sugar&#8211; that&#8217;s ok.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-cinnamon-raisin-bagels/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Lightly grease a large bowl with oil or nonstick spray. Cover the bowl with aluminum foil, plastic wrap, or a clean kitchen towel.\u00a0 Allow the dough to rise at room temperature\u00a0for 60-90 minutes or until double in size.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-cinnamon-raisin-bagels/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Line two large baking sheets with parchment paper or silicone baking mats.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-cinnamon-raisin-bagels/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "When the dough is ready, punch it down to release any air bubbles. Divide the dough into 8 equal pieces. (Just eyeball it&#8211; doesn&#8217;t need to be perfect!) Shape each piece into a ball. Press your index finger through the center of each ball to make a hole about 1.5 &#8211; 2 inches in diameter. Watch video below for a visual. Loosely cover the shaped bagels with kitchen towel and rest for a few minutes as you prepare the water bath.", "name": "Shape the bagels", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-cinnamon-raisin-bagels/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat oven to\u00a0425\u00b0F (218\u00b0C).", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-cinnamon-raisin-bagels/#instruction-step-7"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "\u00a0Fill a large, wide pot with 2 quarts of water. Stir in egg, yogurt, 3/4 cup milk, and vanilla extract until combined. Slowly mix in dry ingredients until no lumps remain. Batter will be thick. Transfer 3/4 cup of batter to another medium bowl. We made a strawberry buttercream and strawberry puree drizzle for the top, creating the ultimate Neapolitan cupcake! So good. If the cookie dough is particularly sticky, it would be difficult to roll into balls AND also roll into balls that won\u2019t stick together in the freezer. I always suggest chilling if your cookie dough recipe calls for it, and then scooping and rolling into balls to freeze.", "inLanguage": "en-US"}, "inLanguage": "en-US"}, {"@type": "Question", "@id": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/baking-basics-how-to-freeze-cookie-dough/#faq-question-1700486063231", "position": 2, "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/baking-basics-how-to-freeze-cookie-dough/#faq-question-1700486063231", "name": "Can you freeze cookie bar dough?", "answerCount": 1, "acceptedAnswer": {"@type": "Answer", "text": "Want to make <a href=\"https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/mm-cookie-bars/\">M&amp;M cookie bars</a> or even <a href=\"https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-chip-cookie-cake/\">chocolate chip cookie cake</a>? You can freeze that dough, too. Prepare the cookie dough according to the recipe's instructions. Refrigerate the dough for about 30 minutes, and then wrap the cold dough tightly in plastic wrap and add a label with the name of the recipe and the date. Freeze for up to 3 months. Thaw overnight in the refrigerator, and then press the dough into the baking dish and bake per the recipe's instructions.", "inLanguage": "en-US"}, "inLanguage": "en-US"}, {"@type": "Question", "@id": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/baking-basics-how-to-freeze-cookie-dough/#faq-question-1700486192184", "position": 3, "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/baking-basics-how-to-freeze-cookie-dough/#faq-question-1700486192184", "name": "What types of cookie doughs do not freeze well?", "answerCount": 1, "acceptedAnswer": {"@type": "Answer", "text": "Delicate cookie doughs/batters don't hold up well in the freezer. Make sure the cakes are completely cool before you level them. You can use a tool called a cake leveler or use a serrated knife. Slice off the domed top of your cakes so the top is flat. You can discard the bit you sliced off, or crumble it up and use it as garnish on top or around the cake. (Or enjoy the cake crumbles over ice cream\u2014my favorite!)", "name": "Level the Cake Layers", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/how-to-assemble-layer-cake/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Place the bottom layer right side up on a cake turntable or cake stand. Place 3/4 to 1 cup of frosting (anywhere between 180\u2013240g) on top. Using an offset spatula, straight spatula, or a regular knife, spread the frosting all the way to the edges of the cake. Place the second cake layer upside down evenly on top, which creates a flat base for the top layer to sit on. (*See end of this step if you are making a 2-layer cake.) Check to make sure it&#8217;s level all the way around. Then add another 3/4\u20131 cup of frosting (180\u2013240g) on top, again spreading it to the edges. Place the top layer on top. You can place it upside down again if you want your cake to have a very straight look on the sides and a perfectly flat top, or you can place it right side up to have a bit of a rounded edge. *If your cake is only 2 layers, the 2nd/top layer can be upside down or right side up, depending if you want a straight edge or rounded edge on top of your cake.", "name": "Stack the Layers", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/how-to-assemble-layer-cake/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "A crumb coat is an extremely thin layer of frosting applied to the top and sides of the cake, which helps lock in any loose crumbs and adds stability to the finished layer cake. For a 3-layer cake, use about 1 cup of frosting (240g) for it. For a 2-layer cake, around 3/4 cup (180g). Spread it all over the top and sides. To smooth out the sides, run a bench scraper around the cake. Refrigerate uncovered for 20 minutes to 1 hour to set the crumb coat.", "name": "Add the Crumb Coat", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/how-to-assemble-layer-cake/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Once your crumb coat has set, finish the cake with a thicker layer of frosting using a\u00a0straight icing spatula. You can use your bench scraper again for smooth sides, or keep the sides textured as shown in the video. If you used a cake turntable and want to transfer your cake to a serving platter or cake stand, it&#8217;s helpful to have a cake lifter tool and a second set of hands to lift and transfer it. If you have some extra frosting, you can fill a piping bag and add some decoration. Here I used the Wilton 1M tip to pipe a shell border around the top and bottom of the cake.", "name": "Finish Decorating the Cake", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/how-to-assemble-layer-cake/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "When you have finished decorating your cake, it&#8217;s best to refrigerate it uncovered for at least 20 minutes before slicing and serving. Depending on the cake, you can refrigerate it for up to 4 to 6 hours. To store leftover cake or if you plan to transport the cake, I recommend a cake carrier because it keeps the cake fresh without touching or smearing the frosting.", "url": No cookie dough chilling required!", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "pumpkin cookies", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/soft-pumpkin-cookies-2-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/soft-pumpkin-cookies-2-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/soft-pumpkin-cookies-2-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/soft-pumpkin-cookies-2.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/pumpkin-cookies/", "recipeIngredient": ["1 and 1/2 cups (340g) fresh or canned pumpkin puree", "3 cups (375g) all-purpose flour\u00a0(spooned &amp; leveled)", "1 and 1/2 teaspoons baking powder", "1 teaspoon\u00a0baking soda", "1 teaspoon\u00a0salt", "2 teaspoons pumpkin pie spice*", "1\u00a0and 1/2 teaspoons\u00a0ground cinnamon", "1/4 teaspoon ground ginger", "3/4 cup (12 Tbsp; 170g) unsalted butter, softened to room temperature", "1 cup\u00a0(200g) packed light or dark\u00a0brown sugar (I use and recommend dark)", "3/4 cup (150g) granulated sugar", "1\u00a0large\u00a0egg, at room temperature", "2 teaspoons pure maple syrup, milk, or orange juice (see note)", "1 and 1/2 teaspoons pure vanilla extract", "3 ounces\u00a0(85g) full-fat brick cream cheese, softened to room temperature", "2 Tablespoons (28g) unsalted butter, softened to room temperature", "3/4 cup (90g) confectioners&#8217; sugar", "2 Tablespoons (30ml) pure maple syrup", "pinch ground cinnamon (about 1/8 teaspoon)"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In this recipe, it&#8217;s best to use pumpkin that has had some moisture removed. Blot the pumpkin with paper towels to rid excess moisture. No need to squeeze it completely dry. I usually place it in a paper towel lined bowl and let the paper towel soak up some moisture. A clean kitchen towel works too, but the pumpkin can stain. After ridding some moisture, you&#8217;ll have a little less than 1 and 1/2 cups of pumpkin\u2014I usually have about 1 and 1/3 cups (315g). Using anywhere between 1.33 &#8211; 1.5 cups of pumpkin is fine. Set aside until step 4. Or cover and refrigerate for up to 1 day. It can be cold when you add it to the dough.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/pumpkin-cookies/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat oven to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C). Add the egg and mix on high until combined, about 1 minute. Scrape down the sides and bottom of the bowl as needed. Add the maple syrup, vanilla, and blotted pumpkin and mix on high until combined. Mixture will look a little curdled\u2014that&#8217;s ok.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/pumpkin-cookies/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Add the dry ingredients to the wet ingredients, then mix on low speed until combined. The dough rests and rises overnight, so most of the process is completely hands-off\u2014no kneading or tricky shaping required. The result is a bakery-style loaf with a crispy golden crust and a soft, chewy interior, packed with bits of pepperoni, sun-dried tomatoes, olives, and mozzarella. Serve slices warm with pizza sauce or tomato soup for dipping, or slathered in hot honey butter for a touch of sweet heat! If you're new to working with yeast, reference my Baking with Yeast Guide for answers to common yeast FAQs.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally McKenney", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "no-knead pizza bread", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/pizza-bread-no-knead-3-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/pizza-bread-no-knead-3-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/pizza-bread-no-knead-3-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/pizza-bread-no-knead-3.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/crusty-no-knead-pizza-bread/", "recipeIngredient": ["3 and 1/3 cups (about 440g) bread flour\u00a0(spooned &amp; leveled), plus more as needed for shaping and pan", "2 teaspoons instant\u00a0or\u00a0active dry yeast", "2 teaspoons\u00a0coarse salt*", "1 teaspoon granulated sugar (or honey, see Note)", "2 teaspoons dried oregano", "1 teaspoon dried basil", "1 and 1/2 teaspoons garlic powder", "1/4 teaspoon crushed red pepper flakes, optional", "1 heaping cup (about 135g) chopped pepperoni, sun-dried tomatoes (packed in oil &amp; drained), and/or\u00a0olives", "1 cup (113g) shredded mozzarella cheese", "1 and 1/2 cups (360ml) water, close to room temperature at about 70\u00b0F (21\u00b0C)", "1/2 cup (8 Tbsp; 113g) unsalted butter, softened to room temperature*", "3 Tablespoons (63g) honey", "1 Tablespoon confectioners&#8217; sugar", "1/8\u20131/4 teaspoon flaky sea salt or\u00a0coarse salt", "pinch of crushed red pepper flakes, to taste"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "*No need to grease the bowl, and do not use a mixer in this step because the dough is too sticky for a mixer.* In a large mixing bowl, whisk together the flour, yeast, salt, sugar, oregano, basil, garlic powder, and crushed red pepper (if using). Using a silicone spatula or wooden spoon, mix in the chopped add-ins (pepperoni, sun-dried tomatoes, olives) and mozzarella cheese. Pour in the water and gently mix together. The dough will seem dry and shaggy, but keep working it until all the flour is moistened. If needed, use your hands to work the dough ingredients together until all the flour is moistened. The dough will be sticky. Shape into a ball in the bowl as best you can.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/crusty-no-knead-pizza-bread/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cover the bowl tightly with plastic wrap or aluminum foil and set on the counter at room temperature. Allow to rise for 3 hours. The dough will just about double in size, stick to the sides of the bowl, and have a lot of air bubbles. Place the risen dough, still covered, in the refrigerator for at least 12 hours and up to 3 days. The dough will puff up during this time, but may begin to deflate after 2 days. That&#8217;s normal.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/crusty-no-knead-pizza-bread/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Turn the dough out onto a lightly floured work surface and, using generously floured hands, shape into a ball as best you can. It doesn&#8217;t have to be perfect. Transfer the dough to a large piece of parchment paper. (Large enough to fit inside your pot and one that is safe for high heat. I use this parchment and it&#8217;s never been an issue.) Place the ball of dough + parchment inside a medium-size mixing bowl so the dough doesn&#8217;t spread out as it rests. Cover and let it rest for 30 minutes.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/crusty-no-knead-pizza-bread/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "During this rest, preheat the oven to 450\u00b0F (232\u00b0C). (Yes, very hot!) Place a 6-quart or larger Dutch oven (with the lid) or heavy-duty pot in the oven for 30 minutes so that it&#8217;s extremely hot before the dough is placed inside.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/crusty-no-knead-pizza-bread/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "After 30 minutes, using a very sharp knife or bread lame (some even use kitchen shears), score the dough with an X, about 1/2 inch deep. (&#8220;Score&#8221; = shallow cut.) Remove the Dutch oven from the oven and carefully place the scored dough inside by lifting it up with the parchment paper and placing it all\u2014the parchment paper included\u2014inside the pot. Cover with the lid.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/crusty-no-knead-pizza-bread/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake for 25 minutes with the lid on. Carefully remove the lid and continue baking for around 10\u201315 minutes more until the bread is golden brown. How to test for doneness: Give the warm bread a light tap. If it sounds hollow, it\u2019s done. For a more accurate test, the bread is done when an instant-read thermometer reads the center of the loaf as 195\u00b0F (90\u00b0C).", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/crusty-no-knead-pizza-bread/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Remove pot from the oven, carefully remove the bread from the pot, and allow to cool on a cooling rack for at least 20 minutes before slicing. Because of the heavy add-ins and cheese, this bread is flatter than most boules. But this just means a higher crust to interior ratio! Slice and serve with homemade hot honey butter, if desired.\u00a0", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/crusty-no-knead-pizza-bread/#instruction-step-7"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a large bowl using a handheld mixer or stand mixer fitted with a paddle attachment, beat the butter on medium speed until completely smooth and creamy, about 1 minute. Add the remaining ingredients, starting with only 1/8 teaspoon of salt and a small pinch of red pepper flakes. Beat on medium-high speed until completely smooth, about 1 minute. Scrape down the sides of the bowl with a silicone spatula and beat again as needed to combine. Taste. Set aside. Whisk the egg and brown sugar together in a medium bowl until smooth. Whisk in the\u00a0butter, mashed banana, vanilla, and buttermilk\u00a0until smooth and combined. Sally\u2019s work has been featured on TODAY, Good Morning America, Taste of Home, People, and more.", "sameAs": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"]}, {"@context": "https://schema.org/", "@type": "Recipe", "name": "How to Make Croissants", "description": "Buttery, flaky, and perfect homemade croissants!", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "croissants, homemade croissants", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/03/april-baking-challenge-croissants-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/03/april-baking-challenge-croissants-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/03/april-baking-challenge-croissants-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/03/april-baking-challenge-croissants.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-croissants/", "recipeIngredient": ["1/4 cup (4 Tbsp; 56g) unsalted butter, softened to room temperature", "4 cups (500g) all-purpose flour (spooned &amp; leveled), plus more for rolling/shaping", "1/4 cup (50g) granulated sugar", "2 teaspoons salt", "1 Tablespoon active dry or instant yeast", "1 and 1/2 cups (360ml) cold whole milk", "1 and 1/2 cups (340g) unsalted butter, softened to room temperature", "2 Tablespoons (16g) all-purpose flour", "1 large egg", "2 Tablespoons (30ml) whole milk"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Watch the video below and use the step-by-step photos before you begin. Read the recipe before beginning. Make room in the refrigerator for a baking sheet. In step 6 and again in step 13, you will need room for 2 baking sheets.", "name": "Preliminary notes", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-croissants/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cut the butter in four 1-Tablespoon pieces and place in the bowl of an electric stand mixer fitted with the dough hook attachment (or you can use a handheld mixer or no mixer, but a stand mixer is ideal). Add the flour, sugar, salt, and yeast. Turn the mixer on low-medium speed to gently combine the ingredients for 1 minute. With the mixer running, slowly pour in the milk. Once all of the milk is added, turn the mixer up to medium speed and begin to knead the dough.", "name": "Make the dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-croissants/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Knead the dough: Keep the dough in the mixer and beat for an additional 5 full minutes, or knead by hand on a lightly floured surface for 5 full minutes. (If you\u2019re new to bread-baking, my How to Knead Dough video tutorial can help here.) If the dough becomes too sticky during the kneading process, sprinkle 1 teaspoon of flour at a time on the dough or on the work surface/in the bowl to make a soft, slightly tacky dough. Do not add more flour than you need because you do not want a dry dough. After kneading, the dough should still feel a little soft. Poke it with your finger\u2014if it slowly bounces back, your dough is ready to rest. You can also do a \u201cwindowpane test\u201d to see if your dough has been kneaded long enough: tear off a small (roughly golfball-size) piece of dough and gently stretch it out until it\u2019s thin enough for light to pass through it. Hold it up to a window or light. Does light pass through the stretched dough without the dough tearing first? If so, your dough has been kneaded long enough and is ready to rest. If not, keep kneading until it passes the windowpane test.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-croissants/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Remove dough from the bowl and, with floured hands, work it into a ball. Place the dough on a lightly floured silicone baking mat lined, lightly floured parchment paper lined, or lightly floured baking sheet. (I highly recommend a silicone baking mat because you can roll the dough out in the next step directly on top and it won\u2019t slide all over the counter.) Gently flatten the dough out, as I do in the video below, and cover with plastic wrap or aluminum foil. Place the entire baking sheet in the refrigerator and allow the covered dough to rest in the refrigerator for 30 minutes.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-croissants/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Remove the dough from the refrigerator. I like to keep the dough on the silicone baking mat when I\u2019m rolling it in this step because the mat is nonstick and it\u2019s a handy guide for the exact measurement. Begin flattening out the dough with your hands. You\u2019re rolling it out into a rectangle in this step, so shaping it with your hands first helps the stretchy dough. Roll it into a 14&#215;10-inch rectangle. The dough isn&#8217;t extremely cold after only 30 minutes in the refrigerator, so it will feel more like soft play-doh. Be precise with the measurement. The dough will want to be oval shaped, but keep working the edges with your hands and rolling pin until you have the correct size rectangle.", "name": "Shape the dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-croissants/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToSection", "name": "=\"instruction-step-6\">Long rest", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Place the rolled out dough back onto the baking sheet (this is why I prefer a silicone baking mat or parchment because you can easily transfer the dough). Cover the rolled out dough with plastic wrap or aluminum foil, place the entire baking sheet in the refrigerator and allow the covered dough to rest in the refrigerator for 4 hours or overnight.\u00a0(Up to 24 hours is ok.)", "name": "Long rest", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-croissants/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a large bowl using a hand-held mixer or stand mixer fitted with a paddle or whisk attachment, beat the butter and flour together until smooth and combined. Transfer the mixture to a silicone baking mat lined or parchment paper lined baking sheet. (Silicone baking mat is preferred because you can easily peel the butter off in the next step.) Using a spoon or small spatula, smooth out into a 7&#215;10-inch rectangle. Be as precise as you can with this measurement. Place the entire baking sheet in the refrigerator and chill the butter layer for 30 minutes. (No need to cover it for only 30 minutes.) You want the butter layer firm, but still pliable. If it gets too firm, let it sit out on the counter for a few minutes to gently soften. The more firm the butter layer is the more difficult it will be to laminate the dough in the next step.", "name": "Butter layer (begin this 35 minutes before the next step so the butter can chill for 30 minutes)", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-croissants/#instruction-step-7"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "\u00a0In this next step, you will be rolling out the dough into a large rectangle. Do this on a lightly floured counter instead of rolling out on your silicone baking mat. The counter is typically a little cooler (great for keeping the dough cold) and the silicone baking mat is smaller than the measurement you need. Remove both the dough and butter layers from the refrigerator. Place the butter layer in the center of the dough and fold each end of the dough over it. If the butter wasn\u2019t an exact 7&#215;10-inch rectangle, use a pizza cutter or sharp knife to even out the edges. Seal the dough edges over the butter layer as best you can with your fingers. On a lightly floured counter, roll the dough into a 10&#215;20-inch rectangle. It\u2019s best to roll back and forth with the shorter end of the dough facing you, like I do in the video below. Use your fingers if you need to. The dough is very cold, so it will take a lot of arm muscle to roll. Again, the dough will want to be oval shaped, but keep working it with your hands and rolling pin until you have the correct size rectangle. Fold the dough lengthwise into thirds as if you were folding a letter. This was the 1st turn.", "name": "Laminate the dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-croissants/#instruction-step-8"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "If the dough is now too warm to work with, place folded dough on the baking sheet, cover with plastic wrap or aluminum foil, and refrigerate for 30 minutes before the 2nd turn.\u00a0I usually don\u2019t have to.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-croissants/#instruction-step-9"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "\u00a0Turn the dough so the short end is facing you. Roll the dough out once again into a 10&#215;20-inch rectangle, then fold the dough lengthwise into thirds as if you were folding a letter. The dough must be refrigerated between the 2nd\u00a0and 3rd turn because it has been worked with a lot by this point. Place the folded dough on the baking sheet, cover with plastic wrap or aluminum foil, and refrigerate for 30 minutes before the 3rd turn.", "name": "2nd turn", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-croissants/#instruction-step-10"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Roll the dough out once again into a 10&#215;20-inch rectangle. Fold the dough lengthwise into thirds as if you were folding a letter.", "name": "3rd turn", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-croissants/#instruction-step-11"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Place the folded dough on the lined baking sheet, cover with plastic wrap or aluminum foil, and refrigerate for 4 hours or overnight.\u00a0(Up to 24 hours is ok.)", "name": "\u00a0Long rest", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-croissants/#instruction-step-12"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "At the end of the next step, you\u2019ll need 2 baking sheets lined with silicone baking mats or parchment paper. The dough is currently on a lined baking sheet in the refrigerator, so you already have 1 prepared!", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-croissants/#instruction-step-13"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Remove the dough from the refrigerator. On a lightly floured counter, roll the dough out into an 8&#215;20-inch rectangle. Use your fingers if you need to. Once again, the dough is very cold, so it will take a lot of arm muscle to roll. The dough will want to be oval shaped, but keep working it with your hands and rolling pin until you have the correct size rectangle. Using a pizza cutter or sharp knife, slice the dough in half vertically. Each skinny rectangle will be 4-inches wide. Then cut 3 even slices horizontally, yielding 8 4&#215;5-inch rectangles. See photo above for a visual. Cut each rectangle diagonally to make 2 triangles. You have 16 triangles now. Work with one triangle at a time. Using your fingers or a rolling pin, stretch the triangle to be about 8 inches long. Do this gently as you do not want to flatten the layers. Cut a small slit at the wide end of the triangle, then tightly roll up into a crescent shape making sure the tip is underneath. Slightly bend the ends in towards each other. Repeat with remaining dough, placing the shaped croissants on 2 lined baking sheets, 8 per sheet. Loosely cover with plastic wrap or aluminum foil and allow to rest at room temperature (no warmer\u2014I suggest keeping on the counter) for 1 hour, then place in the refrigerator to rest for 1 hour or up to 12 hours. (Or freeze, see freezing instructions.) I prefer the shaped croissants to be cold going into the oven.", "name": "Shape the croissants", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-croissants/#instruction-step-14"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat oven to 400\u00b0F (204\u00b0C).", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-croissants/#instruction-step-15"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Whisk the egg wash ingredients together.\u00a0Remove the croissants from the refrigerator. Brush each lightly with egg wash.", "name": "Egg wash", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-croissants/#instruction-step-16"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "\u00a0Bake until croissants are golden brown, about 20 minutes. Rotate the pans halfway through baking. If croissants show signs of darkening too quickly, reduce the oven to 375\u00b0F (190\u00b0C).", "name": "Bake the croissants", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-croissants/#instruction-step-17"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Remove croissants from the oven and place on a wire rack to cool for a few minutes before serving. They will slightly deflate as they cool.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-croissants/#instruction-step-18"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Croissants taste best the same day they\u2019re baked. Cover any leftover croissants and store at room temperature for a few days or in the refrigerator for up to 1 week. You can also freeze for up to 3 months, then thaw on the counter or overnight in the refrigerator. Warm up to your liking.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-croissants/#instruction-step-19"}]}], "prepTime": "PT12H45M", "cookTime": "PT20M", "totalTime": "PT13H10M", "recipeYield": ["16", "16 croissants"], "recipeCategory": "Pastries", "cookingMethod": "Baking", "recipeCuisine": "French", "aggregateRating": {"@type": "AggregateRating", "reviewCount": "292", "ratingValue": "4.7"}, "video": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "VideoObject", "name": "How to Make Croissants | Sally's Baking Addiction", "description": "Buttery, flaky, and perfect homemade croissants!\n\nGet the full recipe: https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-croissants/\n\n\u2022 Ask your recipe question or leave a review over on the recipe page.\n\n#baking #recipes #croissants\n\n\u2022 More of our favorite recipes: https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/", "duration": "PT7M", "embedUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/embed/SuAigX8OQ08?feature=oembed", "contentUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SuAigX8OQ08", "thumbnailUrl": ["https://i.ytimg.com/vi/SuAigX8OQ08/hqdefault.jpg"], "uploadDate": "2020-05-23T15:03:14+00:00"}, "review": [{"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Jackie"}, "datePublished": "2025-07-12", "reviewBody": "I make these at least once a month and they are phenomenal! \r\nCurious if anyone has tried using GF flour in this recipe? \r\nI have a friend who is celiac and mentioned how she would love a croissant."}, {"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Keira"}, "datePublished": "2025-07-26", "reviewBody": "Great recipe with really easy to follow steps! Filled with comforting warm spices, this dessert is perfect for cool fall days.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "spice cake", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/easy-super-moist-spice-cake-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/easy-super-moist-spice-cake-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/easy-super-moist-spice-cake-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/easy-super-moist-spice-cake.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/super-moist-spice-cake/", "recipeIngredient": ["2 and 1/2 cups (313g) all-purpose flour (spooned &amp; leveled)", "2 teaspoons baking powder", "1 teaspoon baking soda", "1/2 teaspoon salt", "1 and 1/2 teaspoon ground cinnamon", "1 teaspoon ground ginger", "1/2 teaspoon ground nutmeg", "1/2 teaspoon ground\u00a0cloves", "1 cup (240ml) vegetable oil", "1 and 3/4 cup (350g) packed light or dark brown sugar", "1 cup (240g) unsweetened applesauce", "4 large eggs", "2 teaspoons pure vanilla extract", "1 cup (150g) shredded apple (or shredded carrot/zucchini)", "optional: 1 Tablespoon (21g) unsulphured or dark molasses (not blackstrap; I prefer Grandma&#8217;s brand)", "1/4 cup (4 Tbsp; 56g) unsalted butter, cut into 4 slices", "8 ounces (226g) full-fat brick cream cheese, softened to room temperature", "2 and 1/2 cups (300g) confectioners&#8217; sugar", "1 teaspoon pure vanilla extract", "pinch of salt", "optional, for garnish: sprinkle of ground cinnamon or nutmeg"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat the oven to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C) and grease a 9&#215;13-inch pan. I always use this glass pan. See recipe Notes for other pan size options.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/super-moist-spice-cake/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a large bowl, whisk together the flour, baking powder, baking soda, salt, cinnamon, ginger, nutmeg, and cloves. Set aside.", "name": "Make the cake", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/super-moist-spice-cake/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a medium bowl, whisk together the oil, brown sugar, applesauce, eggs, vanilla extract, and molasses (if using). Pour the wet ingredients into the dry ingredients and whisk until combined. Some small lumps are OK. Fold in the shredded apple until combined.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/super-moist-spice-cake/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Spread the batter evenly into the prepared pan. Bake for 38\u201340 minutes. Baking times vary, so keep an eye on yours. The cake is done when a toothpick inserted in the center comes out clean with just a few moist crumbs. If you find the top of the cake is browning too quickly in the oven, loosely cover it with aluminum foil (I usually do this around the 25-minute mark).", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/super-moist-spice-cake/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Remove the cake from the oven and set on a cooling rack. Allow to cool completely.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/super-moist-spice-cake/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Set out a medium heatproof bowl because you\u2019ll need it at the end of this step. Place the sliced butter in a light-colored skillet or saucepan. A light-colored interior is crucial for determining when the butter begins to brown. Melt the butter over medium heat and stir or whisk constantly. Once melted, the butter will begin to foam. Continue stirring/whisking, keeping a close eye on it. After about 5\u20137 minutes, the butter will begin browning and you\u2019ll notice lightly browned specks forming at the bottom of the pan. The butter will have a nutty aroma. The color will gradually deepen, from yellow to golden to golden-brown; once it\u2019s a light caramel-brown color, immediately remove from heat and pour into the bowl, including any brown solids that have formed on the bottom of the pan. Cool for 10 minutes, then transfer to the refrigerator to cool completely and solidify.", "name": "Brown the butter for the frosting", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/super-moist-spice-cake/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a large bowl using a handheld or stand mixer fitted with a paddle attachment, beat the solidified brown butter on high speed until creamy and smooth. Add the cream cheese and beat again until smooth and combined. Scrape down the sides and bottom of the bowl as needed. Add confectioners&#8217; sugar, vanilla, and salt. Beat on low speed for 30 seconds, then gradually increase to high speed and beat for 2 minutes.\u00a0", "name": "Make the frosting", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/super-moist-spice-cake/#instruction-step-7"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Spread the frosting on the cooled cake. If desired, top with a sprinkle of cinnamon or nutmeg. Refrigerate for 30 minutes before serving. This helps sets the frosting and makes slicing easier.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/super-moist-spice-cake/#instruction-step-8"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cover leftover cake tightly and store in the refrigerator for up to 5 days.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/super-moist-spice-cake/#instruction-step-9"}], "prepTime": "PT45M", "cookTime": "PT50M", "totalTime": "PT5H", "recipeYield": ["12", "serves 12"], "recipeCategory": "Cake", "cookingMethod": "Baking", "recipeCuisine": "American", "aggregateRating": {"@type": "AggregateRating", "reviewCount": "112", "ratingValue": "4.9"}, "video": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "VideoObject", "name": "Spice Cake", "description": "Moist, flavorful, and tender yet dense homemade spice cake is topped with a generous layer of the silkiest brown butter cream cheese frosting.", "contentUrl": "https://content.jwplatform.com/videos/BngOFiXl.mp4", "thumbnailUrl": ["https://content.jwplatform.com/thumbs/BngOFiXl-720.jpg"], "uploadDate": "2025-10-12T13:24:27+00:00"}, "review": [{"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Candice"}, "datePublished": "2025-11-26", "reviewBody": "Unbelievable cake - truly the best spice cake I have had during my 44 years on earth. leveled), plus more as needed for hands and work surface", "6 Tablespoons (85g) unsalted butter, softened to room temperature", "1/2 cup (100g) packed light or dark brown sugar", "1 Tablespoon ground cinnamon", "1/2 teaspoon ground nutmeg", "1/2 teaspoon ground allspice", "1/4 teaspoon ground ginger", "1/4 teaspoon ground cloves", "4 ounces (113g) full-fat brick cream cheese, softened to room temperature", "3 Tablespoons (45ml) pure maple syrup", "1 Tablespoons (15ml) whole milk", "2/3 cup (80g) confectioners&#8217; sugar, sifted", "optional: 1/8 teaspoon ground cinnamon"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Warm the milk and butter together over the stove or in the microwave. Warm the two together until the butter is *just* melted. You want the mixture lukewarm (105\u00b0F (41\u00b0C)-115\u00b0F (46\u00b0C)), not scorching hot. Set aside. Whisk the pumpkin puree, sugar, nutmeg, and salt together in a large bowl or in the bowl of your stand mixer. Whisk in the warmed milk/butter, egg, and yeast until combined. Using the dough hook or paddle attachment on low speed or mixing by hand using a silicone spatula or wooden spoon, mix in 1 cup of flour. Mix for 1 minute, scraping down the sides of the bowl as needed. Add 1 and 2/3 cups more flour and beat for 1 more minute.", "name": "Make the dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/pumpkin-cinnamon-rolls/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "\u00a0Keep the dough in the mixer (and switch to the dough hook if using the paddle) and beat for an additional 5 full minutes, or knead by hand on a lightly floured surface for 5 full minutes. (If you\u2019re new to bread-baking, my How to Knead Dough video tutorial can help here.) If the dough becomes too sticky during the kneading process, sprinkle 1 teaspoon of flour at a time on the dough or on the work surface/in the bowl to make a soft, slightly tacky dough. Do not add more flour than you need because you do not want a dry dough. After kneading, the dough should still feel a little soft. Poke it with your finger\u2014if it slowly bounces back, your dough is ready to rise. You can also do a \u201cwindowpane test\u201d to see if your dough has been kneaded long enough: tear off a small (roughly golfball-size) piece of dough and gently stretch it out until it\u2019s thin enough for light to pass through it. Hold it up to a window or light. Does light pass through the stretched dough without the dough tearing first? If so, your dough has been kneaded long enough and is ready to rise. If not, keep kneading until it passes the windowpane test.", "name": "Knead the dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/pumpkin-cinnamon-rolls/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "\u00a0Lightly grease a large bowl with oil or use nonstick spray. Place the dough in the bowl, turning it to coat all sides in the oil. Cover the bowl with aluminum foil, plastic wrap, or a clean kitchen towel. Allow the dough to rise in a relatively warm environment for 2 hours or until double in size. (I always let it rise on the counter and it takes about 2 hours. For a tiny reduction in rise time, see my answer to\u00a0Where Should Dough Rise?\u00a0in my\u00a0Baking with Yeast Guide.)", "name": "1st Rise", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/pumpkin-cinnamon-rolls/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Grease the bottom and sides of a 9-inch square baking dish, 9-inch round baking dish, 9&#215;13-inch baking dish, or 11&#215;7-inch baking dish. This recipe yields 10-12 rolls and they can fit into any of those size pans.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/pumpkin-cinnamon-rolls/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Punch down the dough to release the air. Place dough on a lightly floured work surface and using a lightly floured rolling pin, roll dough into a 10\u00d714-inch rectangle. Make sure the dough is smooth and evenly thick. If the dough keeps shrinking as you roll it out, stop what you\u2019re doing, cover it lightly, and let it rest for 10 minutes to relax the gluten. When you return to the dough, it should stretch out much easier.", "name": "Roll out the dough:\u00a0", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/pumpkin-cinnamon-rolls/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Spread softened butter evenly on top of the rolled-out dough. Combine the brown sugar, cinnamon, and spices into a small bowl. Sprinkle all over the top. Roll it up tightly. Using a very sharp knife, cut into 10-12 even rolls. Arrange rolls in the prepared pan.", "name": "Add the filling", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/pumpkin-cinnamon-rolls/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "\u00a0Cover the rolls tightly and allow to rise until doubled in size, about 1 hour. After about 15 minutes, tent a piece of aluminum foil over the top of the pan to prevent the tops from browning too quickly and baking unevenly. Remove pan from the oven and place pan on a wire rack for about 10 minutes as you make the icing.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/pumpkin-cinnamon-rolls/#instruction-step-9"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Using a handheld or stand mixer fitted with a paddle or whisk attachment, beat the softened cream cheese in a medium bowl on medium speed until smooth. Grease three 9-inch round cake pans, line with parchment paper rounds, then grease the parchment paper. Parchment paper helps the cakes seamlessly release from the pans. (If it&#8217;s helpful, see this parchment paper rounds for cakes video &amp; post.)", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/tuxedo-cake/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Whisk the flour, cocoa powder, sugar, baking soda, baking powder, salt, and espresso powder (if using)\u00a0together in a large bowl. Set aside. Using a handheld or stand mixer fitted with a whisk attachment (or you can use a whisk) mix the oil, eggs, sour cream, buttermilk, and vanilla together until combined. Pour the wet ingredients into the dry ingredients, add the hot water or coffee, and whisk or beat it all until the batter is completely combined.", "name": "Make the cake", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/tuxedo-cake/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Divide batter evenly between 3 pans. Bake for 21-25 minutes. Baking times vary, so keep an eye on yours. The cakes are done when a toothpick inserted in the center comes out clean.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/tuxedo-cake/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Remove the cakes from the oven and set on a wire rack.\u00a0Allow to cool completely in the pan.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/tuxedo-cake/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "so it can cool and be ready at the same time. Place chopped white chocolate in a bowl. Heat the cream in a small saucepan until it begins to gently simmer. (Do not let it come to a rapid boil\u2014that&#8217;s too hot!) Pour over white chocolate and stir until completely combined and chocolate has melted. Cover and refrigerate until it&#8217;s thick and a spreadable consistency, about 1-2 hours. You don&#8217;t want it runny.", "name": "As the cake cools, prepare the white chocolate ganache", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/tuxedo-cake/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a large\u00a0bowl using a handheld or stand mixer fitted with a paddle or whisk attachment, beat the butter on high speed until creamed, about 2 minutes. Add 4 cups confectioners&#8217; sugar, the cocoa powder, milk/cream, corn syrup, vanilla, and salt. Beat on low speed for 30 seconds, then switch to high speed and beat for 2 minutes until combined and smooth. If you want the frosting a little thicker, add the extra 1/2 cup of confectioners sugar. (I add it.)", "name": "Make the frosting", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/tuxedo-cake/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Place 1 cake layer on your cake stand, cake turntable, or serving plate. Evenly cover the top with 1/2 of the white chocolate ganache. Top with 2nd layer and evenly cover the top with remaining ganache (if there is too much ganache, serve a dollop/spoonful with each slice!). Top with the third cake layer. Spread the frosting into a thick layer all over the top and sides. Garnish with raspberries and mint, if desired. Sally\u2019s work has been featured on TODAY, Good Morning America, Taste of Home, People, and more.", "sameAs": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"]}, {"@type": "Question", "@id": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-covered-pretzels/#faq-question-1734694893857", "position": 1, "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-covered-pretzels/#faq-question-1734694893857", "name": "Do I temper the chocolate for chocolate-covered pretzels?", "answerCount": 1, "acceptedAnswer": {"@type": "Answer", "text": "You certainly can. I have a How to Temper Chocolate tutorial in my cookbook, <em>Sally's Candy Addiction</em>, and there are many available online. Tempering chocolate is a method of carefully and slowly heating and cooling chocolate. The benefit of tempering is that it maintains that delicious \"snap\" when biting into the chocolate. Also, when simply melting chocolate (without tempering), you may notice a dull appearance and streaks in the chocolate as it sets. When tempering, chocolate remains a bit shiny, and the streaks do not form. Tempered chocolate should not be refrigerated, so if you decide to temper the chocolate for these pretzels, keep them at room temperature.", "inLanguage": "en-US"}, "inLanguage": "en-US"}, {"@context": "https://schema.org/", "@type": "Recipe", "name": "Classic Chocolate Covered Pretzels", "description": "Chocolate-covered pretzels are so simple to make, yet always a crowd-pleaser. Have fun with all the variations including different shaped pretzels, white chocolate and semi-sweet chocolate, and various toppings like sprinkles, crushed candy canes, Oreo cookie crumbs, and more. Set aside.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-covered-pretzels/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "You can melt it in a double boiler or use the microwave. Use a fork to lift it out, and tap the fork on the side of the bowl to allow excess chocolate to drip off. Use a toothpick to help slide the pretzel off the fork and onto the lined baking sheet. Top with sprinkles (if using) while the chocolate is still wet. If you have leftover melted chocolate, you can reheat it (if needed to keep it fluid) and drizzle it on top of the coated pretzels. A few larger pieces of nuts is OK. Pour into a medium bowl and stir in the sugar. Add the melted butter and stir until combined. The mixture will be thick, coarse, and sandy. Try to smash/break up any large chunks. Pour the mixture into an ungreased 9-inch pie dish. Use your hand to pat down the crumbs into the bottom and up the sides to make a crust. Use medium pressure\u2014simply pat down until the mixture is no longer crumbly.\u00a0Tips: You can use a small flat-bottomed measuring cup to help press down the bottom crust and smooth out the surface, but do not pack down too hard. And run a spoon around the bottom \u201ccorner\u201d where the edge and bottom meet to help make a rounded crust\u2060\u2014this helps prevent the crust from falling apart when you slice into the pie. For more shaping technique tips, see the graham cracker crust\u00a0recipe page.", "name": "Make the crust", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/key-lime-pie/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Pre-bake crust for 8 minutes. We so loved the incredulity of flavor using it that I completely kicked vanilla out of the mix. I did the same with these cinnamon \u201ccuffins\u201d as I call them, using almond extract exclusively. The result is a spectral partnership of both flavor and scent. \r\nAs for shape retention, I rolled and stored them in the fridge overnight and baked them at dawn. Before baking I flip them over to keep them uniformly flatter. \r\nCutting the cold rolls was easy and any misshapen casualties were easily re rolled.\r\nAfter removing from oven, I placed them on the cooling rack in my freezer for ten minutes and then iced them.\r\nFor the icing, I added about half C more of 10x to provide more form and white icing color. I wonder, Sally, if one might add a touch of meringue powder to provide more structure instead of adding more 10X? Using a plastic squeeze bottle with a 1 mm opening, I was able to control a nice patterned drizzle. \r\n\r\nThe silicone mats are a housekeeping timesaver, as Sally suggests. I used to use parchment paper and swapping out the two has made baking a sheer pleasure.\r\nSally, thank you for this. For best success, review the blog post, video tutorial, and recipe notes before beginning.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "doughnuts, maple bacon doughnuts", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/homemade-maple-bacon-doughnuts-2-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/homemade-maple-bacon-doughnuts-2-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/homemade-maple-bacon-doughnuts-2-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/homemade-maple-bacon-doughnuts-2.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-maple-bacon-doughnuts/", "recipeIngredient": ["1 cup (240ml) whole milk, warmed to about 110\u00b0F (43\u00b0C)*", "1 Tablespoon active dry yeast*", "1/3 cup (65g) granulated sugar", "2 large eggs", "6 Tablespoons (85g) unsalted butter, melted and slightly cooled", "1 teaspoon pure vanilla extract", "1/4 teaspoon ground nutmeg", "1/2 teaspoon salt", "4 cups (500g) all-purpose flour (spooned &amp; leveled), plus more as needed", "1 &#8211; 2 quarts vegetable oil*", "3 Tablespoons (43g) unsalted butter", "1/2 cup (120ml) pure maple syrup", "1 and 3/4 cups (195g) sifted confectioners\u2019 sugar*", "1/8 teaspoon salt", "1/4 teaspoon maple extract (optional)", "12 slices cooked bacon, cut in half"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Whisk the warm milk, yeast, and sugar together in the bowl of your stand mixer fitted with a dough hook or paddle attachment. Cover and allow to sit for 5 minutes. The mixture should be a little frothy on top after 5 minutes. If not, start over with new yeast.", "name": "Prepare the dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-maple-bacon-doughnuts/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Add the eggs, butter, vanilla, nutmeg, salt, and 2 cups (245g) flour. Beat on low speed for 1 minute. Scrape down the sides of the bowl with a silicone spatula as needed. Add remaining flour and beat on medium speed until the dough comes together and pulls away from the sides of the bowl, about 2 minutes. If needed, add more flour, 1 Tablespoon at a time, until the dough pulls away from the sides of the bowl. Don&#8217;t add too much flour, though. You want a slightly sticky dough. *If you do not own a mixer, you can mix this dough with a large wooden spoon or silicone spatula. It will take a bit of arm muscle!*", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-maple-bacon-doughnuts/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Keep the dough in the mixer and beat for an additional 5-7 full minutes, or knead by hand on a lightly floured surface for 5-7 full minutes. (If you\u2019re new to bread-baking, my How to Knead Dough video tutorial can help here.) If the dough becomes too sticky during the kneading process, sprinkle 1 teaspoon of flour at a time on the dough or on the work surface/in the bowl to make a soft, slightly tacky dough. Do not add more flour than you need because you do not want a dry dough. After kneading, the dough should still feel a little soft. Poke it with your finger\u2014if it slowly bounces back, your dough is ready to rise. You can also do a \u201cwindowpane test\u201d to see if your dough has been kneaded long enough: tear off a small (roughly golfball-size) piece of dough and gently stretch it out until it\u2019s thin enough for light to pass through it. Hold it up to a window or light. Does light pass through the stretched dough without the dough tearing first? If so, your dough has been kneaded long enough and is ready to rise. If not, keep kneading until it passes the windowpane test.", "name": "Knead the dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-maple-bacon-doughnuts/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Lightly grease a large bowl with oil or nonstick spray. Place the dough in the bowl, turning it to coat all sides in the oil. Cover the bowl with aluminum foil, plastic wrap, or a clean kitchen towel. Allow the dough to rise in a relatively warm environment for 1.5-2 hours or until double in size. (For a tiny reduction in rise time, see my answer to Where Should Dough Rise?\u00a0in my\u00a0Baking with Yeast Guide.)", "name": "Let Dough Rise", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-maple-bacon-doughnuts/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "When the dough is ready, punch it down to release the air. Remove dough from the bowl and turn it out onto a lightly floured surface. If needed, punch down again to release any more air bubbles. Using a rolling pin, roll the dough out until it is 1/2 inch thick. Using a 3-3.5 inch doughnut cutter, cut into 12 doughnuts. If you can&#8217;t quite get 12, re-roll the scraps and cut more. (*If you don&#8217;t have a doughnut cutter, you can use 1 large + 1 smaller circle cookie cutter. Large should be about 3 and 1/2 inches.)", "name": "Shape Doughnuts", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-maple-bacon-doughnuts/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Line 1 or 2 baking sheets with parchment paper or silicone baking mats. Place doughnuts and doughnut holes on each. (Feel free to discard doughnut holes if you don&#8217;t want to make them.) Loosely cover and allow to rest as you heat the oil. They will rise a bit as they rest. Place a cooling rack over another baking sheet.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-maple-bacon-doughnuts/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Pour oil into a large heavy-duty pot set over medium heat. Heat oil to 375\u00b0F (191\u00b0C). Add 2-3 doughnuts at a time and cook for 1 minute on each side. Carefully remove with a metal spatula or metal slotted spoon. Wear kitchen gloves if oil is splashing. Place fried doughnuts onto prepared cooling rack. Repeat with remaining doughnuts, then turn off heat.* (See note for doughnut holes.)", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-maple-bacon-doughnuts/#instruction-step-7"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a small saucepan over low heat, melt the butter and maple syrup together, whisking occasionally. Once the butter has melted, remove from heat and whisk in the sifted confectioners\u2019 sugar, salt, and maple extract. Dip each warm doughnut into the icing. The icing quickly thickens, so feel free to place it back over heat as you dip the doughnuts. Place dipped doughnuts back onto cooling rack as excess icing drips down. Gently press bacon slices on top of each. (You can also crumble/chop up the bacon for topping.) After about 30 minutes, the glaze will set + harden.", "name": "Make the icing:\u00a0", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-maple-bacon-doughnuts/#instruction-step-8"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Doughnuts are best enjoyed the same day. Set aside. Using a handheld or stand mixer fitted with a paddle or whisk attachment, beat the butter and granulated sugar together on high speed until smooth and creamy, about 3 minutes. (Here\u2019s a helpful tutorial if you need guidance on\u00a0how to cream butter and sugar.) Add the eggs and then beat on medium speed until combined. Scrape down the sides and up the bottom of the bowl as needed. Beat in the applesauce and vanilla extract on medium speed until combined. Mixture will look chunky and curdled\u2014this is normal and expected. Pour the dry ingredients into the wet ingredients, turn the mixer on low speed and with the mixer running, slowly pour in the milk. Beat just until combined and do not overmix. You may need to whisk it all by hand to make sure there are no lumps at the bottom of the bowl. The batter will be sticky and slightly thick. You&#8217;ll have about 3 cups of batter.", "name": "Batter", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/apple-cinnamon-bread/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Pour and spread about 1/2 of the batter into the bottom of the prepared loaf pan. Serve with some vanilla ice cream for an unforgettable summer treat.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "blueberry peach pie", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/06/homemade-blueberry-peach-pie-2-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/06/homemade-blueberry-peach-pie-2-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/06/homemade-blueberry-peach-pie-2-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/06/homemade-blueberry-peach-pie-2.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/blueberry-peach-pie/", "recipeIngredient": ["All-Butter Pie Crust (recipe makes 2 crusts, 1 for bottom and 1 for top)", "6 cups (around 950g) peeled chopped peaches, cut into 1-inch chunks", "1 and 1/2 cups (210g) fresh blueberries", "3/4 cup (150g) granulated sugar", "3 Tablespoons (23g) cornstarch", "2 Tablespoons (25g) all-purpose flour", "3/4 teaspoon ground cinnamon", "1/8 teaspoon ground allspice", "1 Tablespoon (15ml) fresh lemon juice", "1 Tablespoon (14g) cold unsalted butter, cut into small cubes", "egg wash: 1 large egg beaten with 1 Tablespoon (15ml) milk", "optional: coarse sugar for sprinkling on crust"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Prepare the pie crust recipe through step 5.", "name": "The crust", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/blueberry-peach-pie/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Peel the peaches and then cut into 1-inch chunks. You need about 6 cups of peach chunks, which is around 950g.", "name": "Prep the peaches", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/blueberry-peach-pie/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a large bowl, stir the peach chunks, blueberries, granulated sugar, cornstarch, flour, cinnamon, allspice, and lemon juice together until thoroughly combined. Set filling in the refrigerator while you roll out the dough. No need to cover it.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/blueberry-peach-pie/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Adjust the oven rack to the lower third position and preheat to 425\u00b0F (218\u00b0C). Turn the dough about a quarter turn after every few rolls until you have a circle 12 inches in diameter. Carefully place the dough into a 9-inch round pie dish. Tuck it in with your fingers, making sure it is smooth.", "name": "Roll out the chilled pie dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/blueberry-peach-pie/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Use a slotted spoon to transfer the filling into the crust. Reserve the juice in the bowl for the next step. Refrigerate pie, uncovered, as you reduce the juice in the next step.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/blueberry-peach-pie/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Pour the leftover juice into a small saucepan. Cook over low heat, stirring, until juice has slightly reduced and thickened into an applesauce-like consistency, about 1\u20132 minutes. Cool for 5 minutes, then pour over the filling. Do your best to gently toss together. The reduction will harden and thicken as a result of mixing with the cold fruit\u2014this is normal. Dot the pieces of cold butter on top of the filling. Place the pie in the refrigerator while you roll out the top crust.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/blueberry-peach-pie/#instruction-step-7"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Remove the other disc of chilled pie dough from the refrigerator. Roll the dough into a circle that is around 12\u201315 inches diameter. Using a pastry wheel, sharp knife, or pizza cutter, cut strips of dough; in the pictured pie, I cut 10 1.25-inch-wide strips. Carefully thread the strips over and under one another, pulling back strips as necessary to weave. (Here&#8217;s a lattice pie crust tutorial if you need visuals.) To seal the edges, use a small paring knife or kitchen shears to trim excess dough that extends more than 1.5\u20132 inches over the edge. Fold bottom pie dough edges back over and press/meld into the lattice edges to form a smooth, neat rim. Flute or crimp the pie crust edges with a fork.", "name": "Arrange\u00a0the lattice", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/blueberry-peach-pie/#instruction-step-8"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Lightly brush the top of the pie crust with the egg\u00a0wash. Sprinkle the top with coarse sugar, if using.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/blueberry-peach-pie/#instruction-step-9"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake the pie at 425\u00b0F for 20 minutes; then, keeping the pie in the oven, reduce the oven temperature down to 375\u00b0 (190\u00b0C). Place a pie crust shield (see Note for homemade shield) on the edges to prevent them from over-browning. Continue baking the pie until the filling&#8217;s juices are bubbling everywhere, including in the center, 45\u201350 more minutes. This sounds like a long time, but under-baking the pie means a soupy, paste-like filling. If you want to be precise, the internal temperature of the filling taken with an instant-read thermometer should be around 200\u00b0F (93\u00b0C) when done. Tip: If needed towards the end of bake time, remove the pie crust shield and tent a large piece of foil over the entire pie if the top looks like it&#8217;s getting too brown.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/blueberry-peach-pie/#instruction-step-10"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Remove pie from the oven, place on a cooling rack, and cool for at least 5 hours before slicing and serving. It turned out great!  The family loved it! \r\nA couple of things:  The filling was too much to put in my 10\" pie pan so I will adjust the fruit.  For my tastes it needed more huckleberries to peaches so my changes will be to decrease the peaches to 4 cups and increase the huckleberries to 2 cups. The amount of sugar in the original recipe is good.   \r\nI plan on making a number of peach/huckleberry pie fillings and freezing them for future pies. I see where it is not recommended but I have been freezing fruit pie fillings for many years. The trick is -- don't let them completely thaw before putting them in crust.  Defrosting completely does NOT work well but it has worked well to partially defrost with all the different fruit fillings I have made pie filling out of and I have frozen apricot, peach, pie cherry, blackberry, apple, and rhubarb pie fillings."}, {"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Lola"}, "datePublished": "2025-09-13", "reviewBody": "Great pie! You can follow the same instructions on <a href=\"https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/how-to-freeze-cakes/\">how to freeze cakes</a>: cool completely, wrap in a layer of plastic wrap followed by a layer of foil, and freeze for up to 3 months. Sally\u2019s work has been featured on TODAY, Good Morning America, Taste of Home, People, and more.", "sameAs": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"]}, {"@context": "https://schema.org/", "@type": "Recipe", "name": "Strawberry Blackberry Slab Pie", "description": "Simple strawberry blackberry slab pie recipe with an all butter flaky pie crust feeds a crowd! This is a free form summer pie assembled and baked on a baking sheet.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "strawberry blackberry slab pie", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/06/strawberry-blackberry-slab-pie-7-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/06/strawberry-blackberry-slab-pie-7-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/06/strawberry-blackberry-slab-pie-7-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/06/strawberry-blackberry-slab-pie-7.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/strawberry-blackberry-slab-pie/", "recipeIngredient": ["4\u00a0cups (500g) all-purpose flour (spooned &amp; leveled)", "1 and 1/2 teaspoons salt", "1 teaspoon granulated sugar", "1 and 3/4 cup (396g) unsalted butter, very cold and cubed", "3/4 cup (180ml) ice cold water", "egg wash:\u00a01 large egg, lightly beaten with 1\u00a0Tablespoon (15ml) milk", "optional:\u00a0coarse sugar for sprinkling on top", "4 cups (650g) hulled and chopped fresh strawberries", "4 cups (500g) halved fresh blackberries", "1/2 cup (100g)\u00a0granulated sugar", "1/4 cup (28g)\u00a0cornstarch", "1 Tablespoon (15ml)\u00a0lemon juice", "1 teaspoon pure vanilla extract", "pinch salt"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "\u00a0Mix the flour, salt, and sugar together in a large bowl. Add\u00a0the butter.\u00a0Using a pastry cutter, a food processor, or two forks, cut the butter into\u00a0the mixture until you have pea-size crumbles with a few larger crumbs of fat. (I prefer a pastry cutter for control, ease, and so it&#8217;s not accidentally over-mixed.) Drizzle the cold water in, 1 Tablespoon (15ml) at a time, and stir after every Tablespoon added.\u00a0Do not add any more water than you need to. Stop adding water when the dough begins to form large clumps. I always use about 3/4 cup\u00a0(180ml) water.\u00a0Transfer the pie dough\u00a0to\u00a0a floured work surface. Using floured\u00a0hands, fold the dough into itself until the flour is fully incorporated into the butter\u00a0pieces.\u00a0The dough should come together easily and should not feel overly sticky. Form dough\u00a0into a ball.\u00a0Divide dough in half. Flatten each half into 1-inch thick discs using your hands.\u00a0Wrap each tightly in plastic wrap. Refrigerate for at least 2\u00a0hours (and up to 5 days) or freeze for up to 3 months. Thaw overnight in the fridge before using.", "name": "Make the pie crust", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/strawberry-blackberry-slab-pie/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "\u00a0Gently mix all of the filling ingredients together in a large bowl.\u00a0Set aside.", "name": "Make the filling", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/strawberry-blackberry-slab-pie/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat oven to 375\u00b0F (190\u00b0C).", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/strawberry-blackberry-slab-pie/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Remove 1 disc of\u00a0pie dough from the refrigerator. Keep the other in the refrigerator as you work. I highly suggest rolling the dough out onto a piece of parchment paper or silicone baking mat fitted to your baking sheet. This way you can lift the entire piece of parchment/silicone baking mat off the counter (with the rolled out dough on top) and place on the baking sheet. Roll the dough out into a rectangle or oval shape. I find anywhere around a 10&#215;16-inch size is great, though I&#8217;ve stretched it to a 13&#215;18-inch size. Anywhere around this measurement will work. Dough should be about 1/8-inch thick. Make sure to turn the dough about a quarter turn after every few rolls. Carefully place the dough (with parchment/silicone baking mat) onto a large rimmed baking sheet.", "name": "Roll out the chilled pie crust:\u00a0", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/strawberry-blackberry-slab-pie/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Spoon filling\u00a0evenly on top of crust, leaving any excess liquid in the bowl. Leave a bare 1-inch border around the edges.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/strawberry-blackberry-slab-pie/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Roll out the 2nd pie dough disc in the same-ish shape as the 1st. (If desired, you can cut into strips to weave a lattice on top.) Drape over filling, then use your hands to seal the top and bottom crusts together around the edges. Flute the edges or crimp with a fork. (See my how to crimp and flute pie crust tutorial if you need extra help with this step.) Cut slits into the top of the crust, then brush with a thin coating of egg wash. Sprinkle with coarse sugar, if desired.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/strawberry-blackberry-slab-pie/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake the slab pie for about 45-55 minutes until the crust is golden brown and you can see the filling bubbling. Remove from the oven and, if serving as handheld bars, allow to cool completely in the pan set on a wire rack. If serving on plates, allow to cool for at least 45 minutes in the pan set on a wire rack. On a lightly floured work surface using lightly floured hands or rolling pin, gently flatten the dough into a disc. Place on prepared pan and, using lightly floured hands, stretch and flatten the disc into a 12-inch circle, about 1/2-inch thick. If the dough keeps shrinking back as you try to stretch it, stop what you&#8217;re doing, cover it lightly and let it rest for 5\u201310 minutes, then try again.
